editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: DON SEBASTIAN, King of Portuagal: A TRAGEDY Acted at the Theatre Royal.
LONDON: Printed for Jo. Hindmarh, at the Golden Ball in Cornhil. MDCXC.

div.head: Don Sebatian King of Portugal. A Tragedy. Perons Repreented.

list.label: 1 Don Sebatian King of Portugal,
2 Muley-Moluch Emperor of Barbary,
3 Dorax, a Noble Portuguee now a Renegade, formerly Don Alonzo de Sylvera Alcalde, or Governor of Alcazar
4 Benducar, C • ief Miniter and Favourite to the Emperor,
5 The Mufti Abdalla,
6 Muley-Zeydan Brother to the Emperor,
7 Don Antonio, a Young Noble amorous Portuguee. now a Slave,
8 Don Alvarez, an old Counellor to Don Sebatian, now a Slave alo,
9 Muftapha Captain of the Rabble.
10 Almeyda a Captive Queen of Barbary,
11 Morayma, Daughter to the Mufti,
12 Johayma, Chief Wife to the Mufti,

list.item: Scene in the Catle of Alcazar.

div.head: TO THE Right Honourable Philip Earl of Leyceter, &c.
div.p:
FAR be it from me, (My mot Noble Lord) to think, that any thing which my meannes can produce, hould be worthy to be offer'd to your Patronage; or that ought which I can ay of you hou'd recommend you farther, to the eteem of good men in this preent Age, or to the veneration which will certainly be paid you by Poterity. On th • other ide, I mut acknowledg it a great preumption in me, to make you this Addres; and o much the greater, becaue by the common uffrage even of contrary parties, yon have been always regarded, as one of the firt Perons of the Age, and yet no one Writer has dar'd to tell you o: Whether we have been, all concious to our elves that it was a needles labour to give this notice to Mankind, as all men are aham'd to tell tale news, or that we were jutly diffident of our own performances, as even Cicero is oberv'd to be in awe when he writes to Atticus; where knowing himelf overmatch'd in good ene, and truth of knowledg, he drops the gawdy train of words, and is no longer the vain-glorious Orator. From whatever reaon it may be, I am the firt bold offender of this kind: I have broken down the fence, and ventur'd into the Holy Grove; how I may be punih'd for my profane attempt, I know not; but I wih it may not be of ill Omen to your Lordhip; and that a crowd of bad Writers, do not ruh into the quiet of your recees after me. Every man in all changes of Government, which have been, or may poibly arrive, will agree, that I cou'd not have offer'd my Incene, where it cou'd be o well deerv'd. For you, My Lord, are ecure in your own merit; and all Parties, as they rie uppermot, are ure to court you in their turns; 'tis a tribute which has ever been paid your vertue: The leading men till bring their bullion to your mint, to receive the tamp of their intrinick value, that they may afterwards hope to pas with human kind. They
rie and fall in the variety of Revolutions; and are ometimes great, and therefore wie in mens opinions, who mut court them for their interet: But the reputation of their parts mot commonly follows their ucces; few of 'em are wie, but as they are in power: Becaue indeed, they have no phere of their own, but like the Moon in the Copernican Syteme of the World, are whirl'd about by the motion of a greater Planet. This it is to be ever buie; neither to give ret to their Fellow creatures, nor, which is more wretchedly ridiculous, to themelves: Tho truly, the latter is a kind of jutice, and giving Mankind a due revenge, that they will not permit their own hearts to be at quiet, who diturb the repoe of all beide them. Ambitious Meteors! how willing they are to et themelves upon the Wing; and taking every occaion of drawing upward to the Sun: Not conidering that they have no more time allow'd them for their mounting, than the hort revolution of a day: and that when the light goes from them, they are of neceity to fall. How much happier is he, (and who he is I need not ay, for there is but one Phoenix in an Age,) who centring on himelf, remains immovable, and miles at the madnes of the dance about him. He poees the midt, which is the portion of afety and content: He will not be higher, becaue he needs it not; but by the prudence of that choice, he puts it out of Fortunes power to throw him down. 'Tis confet, that if he had not o been born, he might have been too high for happines; but not endeavoring to acend, he ecures the native height of his tation from envy; and cannot decend from what he is, becaue he depends not on another. What a glorious Character was this once in Rome; I hou'd ay in Athens, when in the diturbances of a State as mad as ours, the wie Pomponius tranported all the remaining widom and vertue of his Country, into the Sanctuary of Peace and Learning. But, I wou'd ask the World, (for you, My Lord, are too nearly concern'd to judge this Caue) whether there may not yet be found, a Character of a Noble Englihman, equally hining with that illutrious Roman? Whether I need to name a econd Atticus; or whether the World has not already prevented me, and fix'd it there without my naming. Not a econd with a longo ed proximus intervallo, not
a Young Marcellus, flatter'd by a Poet, into a reemblance of the firt, with a frons laeta parum, & dejecto lumina vultu, and the ret that follows, i qua fata apera rumpas Tu Marcellus eris: But a Peron of the ame tamp and magnitude; who owes nothing to the former, beides the Word Roman, and the Supertition of reverence, devolving on him by the precedency of eighteen hundred years. One who walks by him with equal paces, and hares the eyes of beholders with him: One, who had been firt, had he firt liv'd; and in pight of doating veneration is till his equal. Both of them born of Noble Families in unhappy Ages, of change and tumult; both of them retiring from Affairs of State: Yet, not leaving the Common-wealth, till it had left it elf; but never returning to publick b • ines, when they had once quitted it; tho courted by the Heads of either Party. But who wou'd trut the quiet of their lives, with the extravagancies of their Countrymen, when they were jut in the giddines of their turning; when the ground was tottering under them at every moment; and none cou'd gues whether the next heave of the Earthquake, wou'd ettle them on the firt Foundation, or wallow it? Both of them knew Mankind exactly well; for both of them began that tudy in themelves; and there they found the bet part of humane compoition, the wort they learn'd by long experience of the folly, ignorance, and immorality of mot beide them. Their Philoophy on both ides, was not wholly peculative, for that is barren, and produces nothing but vain Ideas of things which cannot poibly be known; or if they cou'd, yet wou'd only terminate in the undertanding; but it was a noble, vigorous, and practical Philoophy, which exerted it elf in all the offices of pity, to thoe who were unfortunate, and deerv'd not o to be. The Friend was always more conider'd by them than the caue: And an Octavius, or an Anthony in ditres, were reliev'd by them, as well as a Brutus or a Caius. For the lowermot party to a noble mind, is ever the fittet object of good will. The eldet of them, I will uppoe for his honour, to have been of the Academick Sect, neither Dogmatit nor Stoick; if he were not, I am ure he ought in common jutice, to yield the precedency to his younger Brother. For tiffnes of Opinion is the effect
of Pride, and not of Philoophy: 'Tis a mierable Preumption of that knowledg which humane Nature is too narrow to contain. And the ruggednes of a Stoick is only a illy affectation of being a God: To wind himelf up by Pulleys, to an inenibility of uffering; and at the ame time to give the lye to his own Experience, by aying he uffers not, what he knows he feels. True, Philoophy is certainly of a more pliant Nature, and more accommodated to human ue; Homo um, humani à me nihil alienum puto. A wie man will never attempt an impoibility; and uch it is to train himelf beyond the nature of his Being; either to become a Deity, by being above uffering, or to debae himelf into a Stock or Stone, by pretending not to feel it. To find in ourelves the Weaknees and Imperfections of our wretched Kind, is urely the mot reaonable tep we can make towards the Compaion of our fellow Creatures. I cou'd give Examples of this kind in the econd Atticus. In every turn of State, without meddling on either ide, he has always been favorable and aiting to oppret Merit. The Praies which were given by a great Poet to the late Queen Mother on her rebuilding Someret Palace, one part of which was fronting to the mean Houes on the other ide of the Water, are as jutly his:
For, the ditret, and the afflicted lye
Mot in his Thoughts, and always in his Eye.
Neither has he o far forgotten a poor Inhabitant of his Suburbs, whoe bet propect is on the Garden of Leiceter-Houe; but that more than once he has been offering him his Patronage, to reconcile him to a World, of which his Misfortunes have made him weary. There is another Sidney till remaining, tho there can never be another Spencer to deerve the Favor. But one Sidney gave his Patronage to the applications of a Poet; the other offer'd it unask'd. Thus, whether as a econd Atticus, or a econd Sir Philip Sidney, the latter, in all repects, will not have the wore of the comparion; and if he will take up with the econd place, the World will not o far flatter his Modety, as to eat him there, unles it be out of a deference of Manners, that he may place himelf where he pleaes at his own Table.

I may therefore afely conclude, that he, who by the conent of all men, bears o eminent a Character, will out of his inborn Noblenes, forgive the Preumption of this Addres. 'Tis an unfinih'd Picture, I confes, but the Lines and Features are o like, that it cannot be mitaken for any other; and without writing any name under it, every beholder mut cry out, at the firt ight, this was deign'd for Atticus; but the bad Artit, has cat too much of him into hades. But I have this Excue, that even the greater Maters commonly fall hort of the bet Faces. They may flatter an indifferent Beauty; but the excellencies of Nature, can have no right done to them: For there both the Pencil and the Pen are overcome by the Dignity of the Subject; as our admirable Wal • er has expres'd it; The Hero's Race trancends the Poet's Thought.

There are few in any Age who can bear the load of a Dedication; for where Praie is undeerv'd, 'tis Satyr: Tho Satyr on Folly is now no longer a Scandal to any one Peron, where a whole Age is dipt together; yet I had rather undertake a Multitude one way, than a ingle Aiticus the other; for 'tis eaier to decend, than 'tis to climb. I hou'd have gone aham'd out of the World, if I had not at leat attempted this Addres, which I have long thought owing: And if I had never attempted, I might have been vain enough to think I might have ucceeded in it: now I have made the Experiment, and have fail'd, through my Unworthines. I may ret atisfi'd, that either the Adventure is not to be atchiev'd, or that it is reerv'd for ome other hand.

Be pleas'd therefore, ince the Family of the Attici is and ought to be above the common Forms of concluding Letters, that I may take my leave in the Words of Cicero to the firt of them: Me, O Pomponi, valdè poenitet vivere: tantùm te oro, ut quoniam me ipe emper amâti, ut eodem amore is; ego nimirum, idem um. Inimici mei mea mihi non meipum ademerunt. Cura, Attice, ut valeas.

div.head: THE PREFACE·
div.p:
WHether it happen'd through a long diue of Writing, that I forgot the uual compas of a Play; or that by crowding it, with Characters and Incidents, I put a neceity upon my elf of lenghthning the main Action, I know not; but the firt days Audience ufficiently convinc • d me of my error; and that the Poem was inupportably too long. 'Tis an ill ambition of us Poets, to pleae an Audience with more than they can bear: And, uppoing that we wrote as well, as vainly we imagin our elves to write; yet we ought to conider, that no man can bear to be long tickled. There is a naueounes in a City feat when we are to it four hours after we are cloy'd. I am, therefore, in the firt place, to acknowledg with all manner of gratitude, their civility; who were pleas'd to endure it with o much patience, to be weary with o much good nature and ilence, and not to explode an entertainment, which was deign'd to pleae them; or dicourage an Author, whoe misfortunes have once more brought him againt his will, upon the Stage. While I continue in thee bad circumtances, (and truly I ee very little probability of coming out:) I mut be oblig'd to write, and if I may till hope for the ame kind uage, I hall the les repent of that hard neceity. I write not this out of any expectation to be pityed; for I have Enemies enow to wih me yet in a wore condition; but give me leave to ay, that if I can pleae by writing, as I hall endeavour it, the Town may be omewhat oblig'd to my misfortunes, for a part of their diverion. Having been longer acquainted with the Stage, than any Poet now living, and having oberv'd how difficult it was to pleae; that the humours of Comedy were almot pent, that Love and Honour (the mitaken Topicks of Tragedy) were quite worn out, that the Theaters cou'd not upport their charges, that the Audience forook them, that young men without Learning et up for Judges, and that they talk'd loudet, who undertood the leat: all thee dicouragements had not only wean'd me from the Stage, but had alo given me a loathing of it. But enough of this: the difficulties
continue; they increae, and I am till condemn'd to dig in thoe exhauted Mines. Whatever fault I next commit, ret aur'd it hall not be that of too much length: Above twelve hunder'd lines have been cut off from this Tragedy, ince it was firt deliver'd to the Actors. They were indeed o judiciouly lopt by Mr. Betterton, to whoe care and excellent action, I am equally oblig'd, that the connexion of the tory was not lot; but on the other ide, it was impoible to prevent ome part of the action from being precipitated, and coming on without that due preparation, which is requir'd to all great events: as in particular, that of raiing the Mobile, in the beginning of the Fourth Act; which a Man of Benducar's cool Character, cou'd not naturally attempt, without taking all thoe precautions, which he foreaw wou'd be neceary to render his deign uccesful. On this conideration, I have replac'd thoe lines, through the whole Poem; and thereby retor'd it, to that clearnes of conception, and (if I may dare to ay it) that lutre, and maculine vigour, in which it was firt written. 'Tis obvious to every undertanding Reader, that the mot poetical parts, which are Decriptions, Images, Similitudes, and Moral Sentences; are thoe, which of neceity were to be par'd away, when the body was woln into too large a bulk for the repreentation of the Stage. But there is a vat difference betwixt a publick entertainment on the Theatre, and a private reading in the Cloet: In the firt we are confin'd to time, and though we talk not by the hour-glas, yet the Watch often drawn out of the pocket, warns the Actors, that their Audience is weary; in the lat, every Reader is judge of his own convenience; he can take up the book, and lay it down at his pleaure; and find out thoe beauties of propriety, in thought and writing, which ecap'd him in the tumult and hurry of repreenting. And I dare boldly promie for this Play, that in the roughnes of the numbers and cadences, (which I aure was not caual, but o deign'd) you will ee omewhat more materly ariing to your view, than in mot, if not any of my former Tragedies. There is a more noble daring in the Figures and more uitable to the lotines of the Subject; and beides this ome newnees of Englih, tranlated from the Beauties of Modern Tongues, as well as from the elegancies of the Latin; and here and there ome old words are prinkled, which for their ignificance and ound, deerv'd not to be antiquated; uch as we often find in Salut amongt the
Roman Authors, and in Milton's Paradie amongt ours; though perhaps the latter intead of prinkling, has dealt them with too free a hand, even ometimes to the obcuring of his ene.

As for the tory or plot of the Tragedy, 'tis purely fiction; for I take it up where the Hitory has laid it down. We are aur'd by all Writers of thoe times, that Sebatian a young Prince of great courage and expectation, undertook that War partly upon a religious account, partly at the ollicitation of Muley-Mahumet, who had been driven out of his Dominions, by Abdelmelech, or as others call him Muley-Moluch his nigh Kinman, who decended from the ame Family of the Xeriff's; whoe Fathers Hamet and Mahomet had conquer'd that Empire with joint Forces; and har'd it betwixt them after their victory: That the body of Don Sebatian was never found in the Field of Battel; which gave occaion for many to believe, that he was not lain; that ome years after, when the Spaniards with a pretended title, by force of Arms had urp'd the Crown of Portugal, from the Houe of Braganza, a certain Peron who call'd himelf Don Sebatian, and had all the marks of his body and features of his face, appear'd at Venice, where he was own'd by ome of his Country-men; but being eiz'd by the Spaniards was firt Imprion'd, then ent to the Gallies, and at lat put to Death in private. 'Tis mot certain, that the Portuguees expected his return for almot an Age together after that Battel; which is at leat a proof of their extream love to his Memory; and the uage which they had from their new Conquerors, might poibly make them o extravagant in their hopes and wihes for their old Mater.

This ground work the Hitory afforded me, and I deire no better to build a Play upon it: For where the event of a great action is left doubtful, there the Poet is left Mater: He may raie what he pleaes on that foundation, provided he makes it of a piece, and according to the rule of probability. From hence I was only oblig'd, that Sebatian hou'd return to Portugal no more; but at the ame time I had him at my own dipoal, whether to betow him in Affrick, or in any other corner of the World, or to have elos'd the Tragedy with his death; and the lat of thee was certainly the mot eaie, but for the ame reaon, the leat artful; becaue as I have omewhere aid, the poyon and the dagger are till at hand, to butcher a Heroe, when a Poet wants the brains to ave him. It being therefore only neceary
according to the Laws of the Drama, that Sebatian hou'd no more be een vpon the Throne, I leave it for the World to judge, whether or no I have dipoed of him according to art, or have bungled up the concluion of his adventure. In the drawing of his character I forgot not piety, which any one may oberve to be one principal ingredient of it; even o far as to be a habit in him; though I how him once to be tranported from it by the violence of a udden paion, to endeavor a elf murther. This being preuppos'd, that he was Religious, the horror of his incet, tho innocently committed, was the bet reaon which the Stage cou'd give for hind'ring his return. 'Tis true I have no right to blat his Memory, with uch a crime: but declaring it to be fiction, I deire my Audience to think it no longer true, than while they are eeing it repreented: For that once ended, he may be a Saint for ought I know; and we have reaon to preume he is. On this uppoition, it was unreaonable to have kill'd him; for the Learned Mr. Rymer has well oberv'd, that in all punihments we are to regulate our elves by Poetical jutice; and according to thoe meaures an involuntary in deerves not death; from whence it follows, that to divorce himelf from the beloved object, to retire into a deart, and deprive himelf of a Throne, was the utmot punihment, which a Poet cou'd inflict, as it was alo the utmot reparation, which Sebatian cou'd make. For what relates to Almeyda, her part is wholly fictitious: I know it is the urname of a noble Family in Portugal, which was very intrumental in the Retoration of Don John de Braganza, Father to the mot Illutrious and mot Pious Princes our Queen Dowager. The French Author of a Novel, call'd Don Sebatian, has given that name to an Affrican Lady of his own invention, and makes her Siter to Muley-Mahumet. But I have wholly chang'd the accidents, and borrow'd nothing but the uppoition, that he was belov'd by the King of Portugal. Tho, if I had taken the whole tory, and wrought it up into a Play, I might have done it exactly according to the practice of almot all the Ancients; who were never accus'd of being Plagiaries, for building their Tragedies on known Fables. Thus Augutus Caear wrote an Ajax, which was not the les his own, becaue Euripides had written a Play before him on that Subject. Thus of late years Corneille writ an Oedipus after Sophocles; and I have deign'd one after him, which I wrote with Mr. Lee, yet neither the French Poet tole from the
Greek, nor we from the French man. 'Tis the contrivance, the new turn, and new characters, which alter the property and make it ours. The Materia Poetica is as common to all Writers, as the Materia Medica to all Phyicians. Thus in our Chronicles, Daniels Hitory is till his own, though Matthew Paris, Stow and Hollinghed writ before him, otherwie we mut have been content with their dull relations, if a better Pen had not been allow'd to come after them, and write his own account after a new and better manner.

I mut farther declare freely, that I have not exactly kept to the three Mechanick rules of unity: I knew them and had them in my eye, but follow'd them only at a ditance; for the Genius of the Englih cannot bear too regular a Play; we are given to variety, even to a debauchery of Pleaure. My Scenes are therefore ometimes broken, becaue my nder-plot requir'd them o to be; though the General Scene remains of the ame Catle, and I have taken the time of two days, becaue the variety of accidents, which are here repreented, cou'd not naturally be uppos'd to arrive in one: But to gain a greater Beauty, 'tis lawful for a Poet to uperede a les.

I mut likewie own, that I have omewhat deviated from the known Hitory, in the death of Muley-Moluch, who, by all relations dyed of a feaver in the Battel, before his Army had wholly won the Field; but if I have allow'd him another day of life, it was becaue I tood in need of o hining a Character of brutality, as I have given him; which is indeed the ame, with that of the preent Emperor Muley Ihmael, as ome of our Englih Officers, who have been in his Court, have credibly inform'd me.

I have been litning what objections had been made, againt the conduct of the Play, but found them all o trivial, that if I hou'd name them, a true critick wou'd imagin that I play'd booty, and only rais'd up fantoms for my elf to conquer. Some are pleas'd to ay the Writing is dull; but aetatem habet de e loquatur. Others that the double poyon is unnatural; let the common received opinion, and Auonius his famous Epigram anwer that. Latly a more ignorant ort of Creatures than either of the former, maintain that the Character of Dorax, is not only unnatural, but inconitent with it elf; let them read the Play and think again, and if yet they are not atisfied, cat their eyes on that Chapter of the Wie
Montaigne, which is intituled de l' Incontance des actions humaines. A longer reply, is what thoe Cavillers deerve not; but I will give them and their fellows to undertand, that the Earl of Doret, was pleas'd to read the Tragedy twice over before it was Acted; and did me the favour to end me word, that I had written beyond any of my former Plays; and that he was dipleas'd any thing hou'd be cut away. If I have not reaon to prefer his ingle judgment to a whole Faction, let the World be judge; for the oppoition is the ame with that of Lucan's Heroe againt an Army; concurrere bellum, atque virum. I think I may modetly conclude, that whatever errors there may be, either in the deign, or writing of this Play, they are not thoe which have been objected to it. I think alo, that I am not yet arriv'd to the Age of doating; and that I have given o much application to this Poem, that I cou'd not probably let it run into many gros aburdities; which may caution my Enemies from too rah a cenure; and may alo encourage my friends, who are many more than I cou'd reaonably have expected, to believe their kindnes has not been very undeervedly betowed on me. This is not a Play that was huddled up in hat; and to hew it was not, I will own, that beide the general Moral of it, which is given in the four lat lines, there is alo another Moral, couch'd under every one of the principal Parts and Characters, which a judicious Critick will oberve, though I point not to it in this Preface. And there may be alo ome ecret Beauties in the decorum of parts, and uniformity of deign, which my puny judges will not eaily find out; let them conider in the lat Scene of the fourth Act, whether I have not preerv'd the rule of decency, in giving all the advantage to the Royal Character; and in making Dorax firt ubmit: Perhaps too they may have thought, that it was through indigence of Characters, that I have given the ame to Sebatian and Almeyda; and conequently made them alike in all things but their Sex. But let them look a little deeper into the matter, and they will find that this identity of Character in the greatnes of their Souls; was intended for a preparation of the final dicovery, and that the likenes of their nature, was a fair hint to the proximity of their blood.

To avoid the imputation of too much vanity (for all Writers, and epecially Poets will have ome) I will give but one other intance, in relation to the niformity of the deign. I have oberv'd that
the Englih will not bear a thorough Tragedy; but are pleas'd, that it hou'd be lightned with underparts of mirth. It had been eaie for me to have given my Audience a better coure of Comedy, I mean a more diverting, than that of Antonio and Morayma. But I dare appeal even to my Enemies, if I or any man cou'd have invented one, which had been more of a piece, and more depending, on the erious part of the deign. For what cou'd be more uniform, than to draw from out of the members of a Captive Court, the Subject of a Comical entertainment? To prepare this Epiode, you ee Dorax giving the Character of Antonio, in the beginning of the Play, upon his firt ight of him at the Lottery; and to make the dependence, Antonio is ingag'd in the Fourth Act, for the deliverance of Almeyda; which is alo prepar'd, by his being firt made a Slave to the Captain of the Rabble.

I hou'd beg pardon for thee intances; but perhaps they may be of ue to future Poets, in the conduct of their Plays: At leat if I appear too poitive; I am growing old, and thereby, in poeion of ome experience, which men in years will always aume for a right of talking. Certainly, if a Man can ever have reaon to et a value on himelf, 'tis when his ungenerous Enemies are taking the advantage of the Times upon him, to ruin him in his reputation. And therefore for once, I will make bold to take the Counel of my Old Mater Virgil.
div.q: Tu, ne cede malis; ed, contrà, audentior ito.

div.head: PROLOGUE TO DON SEBASTIAN King of Portugal.

lg.l: THE Judge remov'd, tho he's no more My Lord,
May plead at Bar, or at the Council-Board:
So may cat Poets write; there's no Pretenion,
To argue los of Wit from los of Penion.
Your looks are cheerful; and in all this place
I ee not one, that wears a damning face.
The Britih Nation, is too brave to how,
Ignoble vengeance, on a vanquih'd foe,
At leat be civil to the Wretch imploring;
And lay your Paws upon him, without roaring:
Suppoe our Poet was your foe before;
Yet now, the bus'nes of the Field is o'er;
'Tis time to let your Civil Wars alone,
When Troops are into Winter-quarters gone.
Jove was alike to Latian and to Phrygian;
And you well know, a Play's of no Religion.
Take good advice, and pleae your elves this day;
No matter from what hands you have the Play.
Among good Fellows ev'ry health will pas,
That erves to carry round another glas:
When, with full bowls of Burgundy you dine,
Tho at the Mighty Monarch you repine,
You grant him till mot Chritian, in his Wine.
Thus far the Poet, but his brains grow Addle;
And all the ret is purely from this Noddle.
You've een young Ladies at the Senate door,
Prefer Petitions, and your grace implore;
How ever grave the Legilators were.
Their Caue went ne'er the wore for being fair,
Reaons as weak as theirs, perhaps I bring;
But I cou'd bribe you, with as good a thing.
I heard him make advances of good Nature;
That he for once, wou'd heath his cutting Satyr:
Sign but his Peace, he vows he'll ne'er again
The acred Names of Fops and Beaús profane.
Strike up the Bargain quickly; for I wear,
As Times go now, he offers very fair.
Be not too hard on him, with Statutes neither,
Be kind; and do not et your Teeth together,
To tretch the Laws, as Coblers do their Leather.
Hores, by Papits are not to be ridden;
But ure the Mues Hore was ne'er forbidden.
For in no Rate-Book, it was ever found
That Pegaus was valued at Five-pound:
Fine him to daily Drudging and Inditing;
And let him pay his Taxes out, in Writing.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene at Alcazar, repreenting a Market-Place under the Catle.
Muley-Zeydan, Benducar.

sp.speaker: Muly-Zeyd.
sp.l: NOW Affrica's long Wars are at an end;
And our parch'd earth is drench'd in Chritian Blood,
My conquering Brother will have Slaves enow,
To pay his cruel Vows for Victory.
What hear you of Sebatian, King of Portugal?

sp.speaker: Benducar.
sp.l: He fell among a heap of laughter'd Moors;
Though yet his mangled Carcae is not found.
The Rival of our threatned Empire, Mahumet,
Was hot purued; and in the general rout,
Mitook a welling Current for a Foord;
And in Mucazer's Flood was een to rie;
Thrice was he een; at length his Courer plung'd,
And threw him off; the Waves whelm'd over him,
And helples in his heavy arms he drownd.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.l: Thus, then, a doubtful Title is extinguih'd:
Thus, Moluch, till the Favorite of Fate,
Swims in a anguine torrent to the Throne.
As if our Prophet only work'd for him:
The Heavens and all the Stars are his hir'd Servants.
As Muley-Zeydan were not worth their care,
And younger Brothers but the draft of Nature.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Be till, and learn the oothing Arts of Court;
Adore his fortune, mix with flattering Crowds,
And when they praie him mot, be you the loudet;
Your Brother is luxurious, cloe, and cruel
Generous by fits, but permanent in michief.
The hadow of a dicontent wou'd ruin us;
We mut be afe before we can be great:
Thee things oberv'd, leave me to hape the ret.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.p: You have the Key, he opens inward to you.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: So often try'd, and ever found o true,
Has given me trut, and trut has given me means
Once to be fale for all. I trut not him
For now his ends are erv'd, and he grown abolute,
How am I ure to tand who erv'd thoe ends?
I know your nature open, mild, and grateful;
In uch a Prince the People may be blet,
And I be afe.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.p: My Father! Embracing him.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: My future King! (aupicious Maley-Zeydan:)
Shall I adore you? No, the place is publick;
I worhip you within; the outward act
Shall be reerv'd till Nations follow me,
And Heaven hall envy you the kneeling World.
You know th' Alcald of Alcazar, Dorax?

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.p: The gallant Renegade you mean?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: The ame:
That gloomy outide, like a ruty Chet,
Contains the hining Treaure of a Soul,
Reolv'd and brave; he has the Souldiers hearts,
And time hall make him ours.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: He's jut upon us.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: I know him from a far,
By the long tride and by the ullen port:
Retire my Lord.
Wait on your Brothers Triumph, yours is next,
His growth is but a wild and fruitles Plant,
I'll cut his barren branches to the tock,
And graft you on to bear.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.p:
My Oracle!
Exit Muley-Zeyd.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Yes, to delude your hopes, poor credulous Fool,
To think that I wou'd give away the Fruit
Of o much toil, uch guilt, and uch damnation;
If I am damn'd, it hall be for my elf:
This eaie Fool mut be my Stale, et up
To catch the Peoples eyes; he's tame and merciful,
Him I can manage, till I make him odious
By ome unpopular act, and then dethrone him.
Now Dorax!

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: Well Bemboucar!

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Bare Bemboucar!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou wouldt have Titles, take 'em then, Chief Miniter,
Firt Hangman of the State.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Some call me Favourite.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: What's that, his Minion?
Thou art too old to be a Catamite!
Now prithee tell me, and abate thy pride,
Is not Benducar Bare, a better Name
In a Friend's mouth, than all thoe gawdy Titles,
Which I didain to give the Man I love?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: But always out of humor,—

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: I have caue:
Tho all mankind is caue enough for Satyr.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Why then thou hat reveng'd thee on mankind,
They ay in fight, thou hadt a thirty Sword,
And well 'twas glutted there.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: I pitted Frogs, I cruh'd a heap of Emmets,
A hundred of 'em to a ingle Soul,
And that but canty weight too: the great Devil
Scarce thank'd me for my pains, he wallows Vulgar
Like whip'd Cream, feels 'em not in going down.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Brave Renegade! cou'dt thou not meet Sebatian?
Thy Mater had been worthy of thy Sword.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: My Mater? By what title,
Becaue I happen'd to be born where he
Happen'd to be a King? And yet I erv'd him,
Nay, I was fool enough to love him too.
You know my tory, how I was rewarded,
For Fifteen hard Campaigns, till hoop'd in Iron,
And why I turn'd Mahometan: I'm grateful,
But whooever dares to injure me,
Let that man know, I dare to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Still you run off from bias; ay what moves
Your preent pleen?

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: You mark'd not what I told you:
I kill'd not one that was his Makers Image;
I met with none but vulgar two-leg'd Brutes.
Sebatian was my aim; he was a Man:
Nay, though he hated me, and I hate him,
Yet I mut do him right; he was a Man,
Above man's height, ev'n towring to Divinity.
Brave, pious, generous, great, and liberal:
Jut as the Scales of Heaven that weigh the Seaons,
He lov'd his People, him they idoliz'd:
And thence proceeds my mortal hatred to him,
That thus unblameable to all beides
He err'd to me alone:
His goodnes was diffus'd to human kind.
And all his cruelty confin'd to me.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: You cou'd not meet him then?

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: No, though I ought
Where ranks fell thicket; 'twas indeed the place
To eek Sebatian: through a track of Death
I follow'd him, by Groans of dying Foes,
But t • ll I came too late, for he was flown
Like Ligtning, wift before me to new Slaughters,
I mow'd acros, and made irregular Harvet,
Defac'd the pomp of Battel, but in vain,
For he was till upplying Death elewhere:
This mads me that perhaps ignoble hands
Have overlaid him, for they cou'd not conquer:
Murder'd by Multitudes, whom I alone
Had right to lay; I too wou'd have been lain,
That catching hold upon his flitting Ghot
I might have robb'd him of his opening Heav'n;
And drag'd him down with me, pight of Predetination.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: 'Tis of as much import as Affric's worth
To know what came of him, and of Almeyda
The Siter of the Vanquih'd Mahumet,
Whoe fatal Beauty to her Brother drew
The Lands third part, as Lucifer did Heav'ns.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I hope he dy'd in her own Female calling,
Choak'd up with Man, and gorg'd with Circumciion.
As for Sebatian we mut earch the Field,
And where we ee a Mountain of the Slain,
Send one to climb, and looking down below
There he hall find him at his Manly length
With his face up to Heav'n, in the red Monument,
Which his true Sword has digg'd.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Yet we may poibly hear farther news;
For while our Affricans puru'd the Chae,
The Captain of the Rabble iued out,
With a black hirt-les train to poil the dead,
And eize the living.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Each of 'em an Hoat,
A Million trong of Vermine ev'ry Villain:
No part of Government, but Lords of Anarchy,
Chaos of Power, and priviledg'd detruction.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Yet I mut tell you Friend the Great mut ue 'em,
Sometimes as neceary tools of tumult.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I wou'd ue 'em
Like Dogs in times of Plague, out-laws of Nature,
Fit to be hot and brain'd; without a proces,
To top infection, that's their proper death.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: No more,
Behold the Emperor coming to urvey
The Slaves in order to perform his Vow.

div.stage: Enter Muley-Moluch the Emperor, with Attendants. The Mufty, and Muley Zeydan.

sp.speaker: Moluch.
sp.l: Our Armours now may rut, our idle cymitars
Hang by our ides, for Ornament not ue:
Children hall beat our Atabals and Drums,
And all the noiie trades of War, no more
Shall wake the peaceful morn: the Xeriff's blood
No longer in divided Channels runs,
The younger Houe took end in Mahumet.
Nor hall Sebatian's formidable Name,
Be longer us'd to lull the crying babe!

sp.speaker: Mufty.
sp.l: For this Victorious day our Mighty Prophet
Expects your gratitude, the Sacrifice
Of Chritian Slaves, devoted, if you won.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: The purple preent hall be richly paid:
That Vow perform'd, fating hall be abolih'd:
None ever erv'd Heav'n well with a tarv'd face:
Preach Abtinence no more; I tell thee Mufty
Good feating is devout: and thou our Head,
Hat a Religious, ruddy Countenance:
We will have learned Luxury: our lean Faith
Gives candal to the Chritians; they feed high;
Then look for hoals of Converts, when thou hat
Reform'd us into feating.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Fating is but the Letter of the Law:
Yet it hows well to Preach it to the Vulgar.
Wine is againt our Law, that's literal too,
But not deny'd to Kings and to their Guides,
Wine is a Holy Liquor, for the Great. Dorax aide.
This Mufti in my concience is ome Englih
Renegade, he talks o avourly of toping.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Bring forth th' unhappy Relicks of the War.

div.stage: Enter Mutapha Captain of the Rabble with his followers of the Black Guard, &c. and other Moors: with them a Company of Portuguee Slaves without any of the chief Perons.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Thee are not fit to pay an Emperors Vow;
Our Bulls and Rams had been more noble Victims;
Thee are but garbidge not a Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: The Prophet mut not pick and chooe his Offrings;
Now he has giv'n the Day, 'tis pat recalling:
And he mut be content with uch as thee.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: But are thee all? Speak you who are their Maters.

sp.speaker: Muta.
sp.p: All upon my Honour: If you'll take 'em as their Fathers got 'em, o. If not, you mut tay till they get a better generation: Thee Chritians are mere bunglers; they procreate nothing but out of their own Wives; And thee have all the looks of Eldet Sons.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: Pain of your lives let none conceal a Slave.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Let every Man look to his own Concience, I am ure mine hall never hang me.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Thou peak't as thou wert privy to concealments:
Then thou art an Accomplice.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Nay if Accomplices mut uffer, it may go hard with me; but here's the Devil on't, there's a Great Man and a Holy Man too, concern'd with me. Now if I confes, he'll be ure to cape between his Greatnes and his Holines, and I hall be murder'd, becaue of my Poverty and Racality.

lg.l: Then if thy ilence-ave the Great and Holy,
'Tis ure thou halt go traight to Paradie

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: 'Tis a fine place they ay; but Doctor I am not worthy on't: I am contented with this homely World, 'tis good enough for uch a poor racally Muulman as I am: Beides I have learnt o much good manners, Doctor, as to let my Betters be erv'd before me.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Thou talk't as if the Mufty were concern'd:

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p:
Your Majety may lay your Soul on't: but for my
part, though I am a plain Fellow, yet I corn to be trick'd into Paradice, I wou'd he hou'd know it. The troth on't is an't like you, His reverence bought of me the flower of all the Market; thee — thee are but Dogs meat to 'em, and a round price he pay'd me too I'll ay that for him; but not enough for me to venture my neck for: If I get Paradice when my time comes I can't help my elf; but I'll venture nothing before-hand, upon a blind Bargain.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: Where are thoe Slaves? produce 'em.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: They are not what he ays.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: No more excues. One goes out to fetch them.
Know thou may't better dally
With a dead Prophet, than a living King.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: I but reerv'd 'em to preent thy Greatnes
An Off'ring worthy thee.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: By the ame token there was a dainty Virgin, (Virgin aid I! but I won't be too poitive of that neither) with a roguih leering eye! he paid me down for her upon the nail a thouand golden Sultanins; or he had never had her I can tell him that: Now is it very likely he would pay o dear for uch a delicious Morel, and give it away out of his own mouth; when it had uch a farewel with it too?

div.stage: Enter Sebatian conducted in mean habit, with Alvarez, Antonio, and Almeyda: her face veil'd with a Barnus.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Ay; Thee look like the Workmanhip of Heav'n:
This is the porcelain clay of human kind,
And therefore cat into thee noble moulds.
sp.stage: Dorax aide while the Emperor whipers Benducar.
sp.l: By all my wrongs
'Tis he; damnation eize me but 'tis he
My heart heaves up and wells; he's poyon to me;
My injur'd honour, and my ravih'd love,
Bleed at their Murderers ight.
The Emperor wou'd learn thee Pris'ners names;
You know 'em.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Tell him, no.
And trouble me no more. — I will not know 'em.
Shall I trut Heav'n, that Heav'n which I renounc'd, Aide.
With my revenge? then, where's my atisfaction?
No, it mut be my own; I corn a Proxy.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: 'Tis decreed,
Thee of a better apect, with the ret
Shall hare one common Doom, and Lots decide it.
For ev'ry number'd Captive put a ball
Into an Urn; three only black be there,
The ret, all white, are afe.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Hold Sir, the Woman mut not draw.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: O Mufti.
We know your reaon, let her hare the danger.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Our Law ays plainly Women have no Souls:

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: 'Tis true; their Souls are mortal, et her by:
Yet were Almeyda here, though Fame reports her
The fairet of her Sex, o much uneen,
I hate the Siter of our Rival Houe,
Ten thouand uch dry Notions of our Alcoran
Shou'd not protect her life; if not Immortal:
Dye as he cou'd, all of a piece, the better,
That none of her remain.

div.stage: Here an rn is brought in: the Pris'ners approach with great concernment; and among the ret Sebatian, Alvarez and Antonio; who come more chearfully.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Poor abject Creatures how they fear to dye! Aide.
Thee never knew one happy hour in life,
Yet hake to lay it down: is load o pleaant?
Or has Heav'n hid the happines of Death
That Men may bear to live? — Now for our Heroes.
O, thee come up with Spirits more reolv'd!
Old venerable Alvarez, well I know him,
The Fav'rite once of this Sebatian's Father;
Now Miniter; (too honet for his Trade)
Religion bears him out, a thing taught young,
In Age ill practis'd, yet his prop in Death.
O, he has drawn a black; and miles upon't,
As who hou'd ay my Faith and Soul are white
Tho my Lot warthy: Now if there be hereafter
He's blet; if not, well cheated, and dyes pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.stage: holding his Lot in his clench'd hand.
sp.l: Here I have thee,
Be what thou wilt: I will not look too oon.
Thou hat a colour; if thou prov't not right.
I have a minute good ere I behold thee.
Now, Let me rowl, and grubble thee,
Blind Men ay white feels mooth, and black feels rough;
Thou hat a rugged skin; I do not like thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: There's th' Amorous airy park, Antonio;
The wittiet Womans toy in Portugal.
Lord what a los of Treats and Serenades!
The whole She Nation will b' in mourning for him.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.l: I've a moit weaty palm; the more's my Sin;
If it be black, yet only dy'd, not odious
Damn'd Natural Ebony, there's hope in rubbing
To wah this Ethiope white.— (Looks) Pox of the Proverb!
As black as Hell: another lucky aying!
I think the Devils in me: — good again,
I cannot peak one yllable, but tends
To Death or to Damnation. Holds up his ball.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He looks uneaie at his future Journey: Aide.
And wihes his Boots off again; for fear
Of a bad Road, and a wore Inn at night.
Go to bed fool, and take ecure repoe
For thou halt wake no more.

div.stage: (Sebatian comes up to draw.)

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l:
to Ben.
Mark him who now approaches to the Lott'ry,
He looks ecure of Death, uperior greatnes,
Like Jove when he made Fate, and aid thou art
The Slave of my Creation; I admire him.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: He looks as Man was made, with face erect,
That corns his brittle Corps, and eems aham'd
He's not all pirit, his eyes with a dumb Pride,
Accuing Fortune that he fell not warm:
Yet now didains to live. (Sebat. draws a black.)

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: He has his wih;
And I have fail'd of mine!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Robb'd of my Vengeance, by a trivial chance! Aide.
Fine work above, that their anointed care
Shou'd dye uch little Death: or did his Genius
Know mine the tronger Demon, fear'd the grapple,
And looking round him, found this nook of fate
To skulk behind my Sword; hall I dicover him?
Still he wou'd dye not mine: no thanks to my
Revenge: reerv'd but to more royal hambles.
'Twere bae too; and below thoe Vulgar Souls,
That har'd his danger, yet not one diclos'd him:
But truck with Rev'rence kept an awful ilence.

I'll ee no more of this: Dog of a Prophet!
Exit Dorax.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: One of thee Three is a whole Hecatomb;
And therefore only one of 'em hall dye.
The Ret are but mute Cattle; and when Death
Comes, like a ruhing Lion, couch like Spaniels,
With lolling tongues, and tremble at the paw,
Let Lots again decide it.

div.stage: (The Three draw again: and the Lot falls on Sebatian.)

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Then there's no more to manage! if I fall
It hall be like my elf; a etting Sun
Shou'd leave a track of Glory in the Skies.
Behold Sebatian King of Portugal.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Sebatian! ha! it mut be he; no other
Cou'd repreent uch uff'ring Majety:
I aw him, as he terms himelf, a Sun
Strugling in dark Eclipe, and hooting day
On either ide of the black Orb that veil'd him.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Not les ev'n in this depicable now,
Than when my Name fill'd Affrick with affrights,
And froze your hearts beneath your torrid Zone.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l:
to M. Mol.
Extravagantly brave! ev'n to an Impudence
Of Greatnes.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Here atiate all your fury;
Let fortune empty her whole Quiver on me,
I have a Soul, that like an ample Shield
Can take in all; and verge enough for more.
I wou'd have conquer'd you; and ventur'd only
A narrow neck of Land for a third World;
To give my looen'd Subjects room to play.
Fate was not mine,
Nor am I Fate's: Now I have pleas'd my longing,
And trod the ground which I beheld from far,
I beg no pity for this mouldring Clay:
For if you give it burial there it takes
Poeion of your Earth:
If burnt and catter'd in the air: the Winds
That trow my dut, diffue my royalty,
And pread me o'er your Clime: for where one Atome
Of mine hall light; know there Sebatian Reigns.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: What hall I do to conquer thee?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Impoible!
Souls know no Conquerors.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: I'll how thee for a Monter through my Affrick.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No thou cant only how me for a Man:
Affrick is tor'd with Monters; Man's a Prodigy,
Thy Subjects have not een.

sp.speaker: Mul. M.
sp.l: Thou talk't as if
Still at the head of Battel.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou mitak't,
For then I would not talk.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Sure he wou'd leep.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Till Dooms-day; when the Trumpet ounds to rie;
For that's a Soldiers call,

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Thou'rt brave too late:
Thou hou'dt have dy'd in battel, like a Soldier,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I fought and fell like one, but Death deceiv'd me,
I wanted weight of feeble Moors upon me,
To cruh my Soul out.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Still untameable!
In what a ruine has thy head-trong Pride,
And boundles thirt of Empire plung'd thy People.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: What ay't thou, ha! No more of that.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Behold,
What Carcaes of thine thy Crimes has trew'd,
And left our Affric Vultures to devour.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Thoe Souls were thoe thy God intruted with thee,
To cherih not detroy.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Witnes, O Heaven, how much
This ight concerns me! Wou'd I had a Soul
For each of thee: How gladly wou'd I pay
The Ranom down: But ince I have but one,
'Tis a King's life, and freely 'tis betow'd.
Not your fale Prophet, but eternal Jutice
Has detin'd me the Lot, to dye for thee:
'Tis fit a Sovereign o hou'd pay uch Subjects;
For Subjects uch as they are eldom een,
Who not forook me at my greatet need;
Nor for bae lucre old their Loyalty,
But har'd my dangers to the lat event,
And fenc'd 'em with their own: Thee thanks I pay you:
And know, that when Sebatian weeps, his Tears
Come harder than his Blood.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: They plead too trongly
To be withtood: My Clouds are gath'ring too,
In kindly mixture with this Royal howr:
Be afe, and owe thy Life, not to my gift,
But to the greatnes of thy mind, Sebatian:
Thy Subjects too hall live; a due reward
For their untainted Faith, in thy concealment.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: Remember, Sir, your Vow. A general hout.

sp.speaker: Mul. M.
sp.l: Do thou remember
Thy Function, Mercy, and provoke not blood.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.p: One of his generous Fits, too trong to lat.

div.stage: Aide to Benducar.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: The Mufti reddons, mark that holy Cheek. To him.
He frets within, froths Treaon at his mouth,
And churns it through his teeth; leave me to work him.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: A mercy unexpected, undeir'd,
Surprizes more: You've learnt the art to vanquih:
You cou'd not (give me leave to tell you Sir)
Have giv'n me life but in my Subjects afety:
Kings, who are Fathers, live but in their People.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Still great, and grateful, that's thy character.
Unveil the Woman; I wou'd view the Face
That warm'd our Mufti's Zeal:
Thee pious Parrots peck the fairet Fruit:
Such Taters are for Kings.

div.stage: Officers go to Almeyda to unveil her.

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.p: Stand off ye Slaves, I will not be unveil'd.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: Slave is thy Title: Force her.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: On your lives,
Approach her not.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: How's this!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir pardon me,
And hear me peak.—

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: Hear me; I will be heard:
I am no Slave; the noblet blood of Affric
Runs in my Veins; a purer tream than thine;
For, though deriv'd from the ame Source, thy Current
Is puddl'd, and defil'd with Tyranny.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: What Female Fury have we here!

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: I hou'd be one,
Becaue of kin to thee: Wou'dt thou be touch'd
By the preuming hands of awcy Grooms?
The ame repect, nay more, is due to me:
More for my Sex; the ame for my decent.
Thee hands are only fit to draw the Curtain.

Now, if thou dar't behold Almeydas face.
nveils her elf.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Wou'd I had never een it! aide.

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: She whom thy Mufti tax'd to have no Soul;
Let Affric now be judg;
Perhaps thou think't I meanly hope to 'cape.
As did Sebatian when he own'd his greatnes.
But to remove that cruple know, bae Man,
My murther'd Father, and my Brother's Ghot
Still haunt this Bret, and prompt it to revenge.
Think not I cou'd forgive nor dare thou pardon.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: Woud't thou revenge thee, Trait'res, hadt thou pow'r?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Traitor, I wou'd; the Name's more jutly thine:
Thy Father was not more than mine, the Heir
Of this large Empire; but with arms united
They fought their way, and eiz'd the Crown by force:
And equal as their danger was their hare:
For where was Elderhip, where none had right,
But that which Conquet gave? 'Twas thy ambition
Pull'd from my peaceful Father what his Sword
Help'd thine to gain: Surpriz'd him and his Kingdom,
No provocation given, no War declar'd.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.p: I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: This is the living Coal that burning in me
Wou'd flame to vengeance, cou'd it find a vent.
My Brother too, that lies yet carcely cold
In his deep watry bed: My wandring Mother,
Who in exile died.
O that I had the fruitful Heads of Hydra,
That one might bourgeon where another ell!
Still wou'd I give thee work; till, till, thou Tyrant,
And his thee with the lat.

sp.speaker: M. Mol.
sp.l: Something, I know not what, comes over me:
Whether the Toyls of Battel, unrepaird
With due repoe, or other udden qualm.
Benducar do the ret. Goes off, the Court follows him.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Strange; in full health! This pang is of the Soul;
The Body's unconcern'd: I'll think hereafter.
Conduct thee Royal Captives to the Catle;
Bid Dorax ue 'em well, till farther order. Going off, tops.
The inferior Captives their firt owners take,
To ell, or to dipoe.—You, Mutapha,

Set ope the Market for the ale of Slaves
Exit Benducar.

div.stage: The Maters and Slaves come forward, and Buyers of everal Qualities come in and chaffer about the everal Owners, who make their Slaves do Tricks.

sp.speaker: Mutapha,
sp.p: My Chattels are come into my hands again, and my Concience will erve me to ell 'em twice over; any price now, before the Muti comes to claim 'em.

sp.speaker: Firt Merchant
sp.l:
What do't hold that old Fellow at?
Pointing to Alvarez.
He's tough, and has no ervice in his limbs.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I confes he's omewhat tough; but I uppoe you wou'd not boyl him. I ask for him a thouand Crowns.

sp.speaker: 1t. Mer.
sp.p: Thou mean't a thouand Marvedi's.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Prithee Friend, give me leave to know my own meaning.

sp.speaker: 1t. Mer.
sp.p: What virtues has he to deerve that price?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Marry come up Sir! Virtues quoth ah! I took him in the King's Company; he's of a great Family, and rich, What other Virtues wou'dt thou have in a Noble-man?

sp.speaker: 1t. Mer.
sp.p: I buy him with another man's Pure, that's my comfort.
My Lord Dorax, the Governor, will have him at any rate:—
There's Handel.
Come, old Fellow, to the Catle.

sp.speaker: Alvar.
sp.l: To what is mierable Age reerv'd! Aide.
But oh the King! And oh the fatal Secret!
Which I have kept thus long, to time it better,
And now I wou'd dicloe, 'tis pat my pow'r.

div.stage: Exit with his Mater.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Something of a Secret, and of the King I heard him mutter: A Pimp I warrant him, for I am ure he is an old Courtier.
sp.l: Now to put off t'other remnant of my Merchandize, —

Stir up, Sirrah
to Antonio.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Dog, what wou'dt thou have!

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Learn better manners, or I hall erve you a Dogtrick; come, down upon all four immediately;
I'll make you know your Rider.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou wilt not make a Hore of me?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Hore or As, that's as thy Mother made thee:—
But take earnet in the firt place for thy Sawcynes.
sp.p: Be advis'd Friend, and buckle to thy Geers: Behold my Enign of Royalty diplay'd over thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I hope one day to ue thee wore in Portugal.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Ay, and good reaon, Friend, if thou catchet me a conquering on thy ide of the water, lay me on lutily, I'll take it as kindly as thou dot this.—

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.p: Hold my dear Thrum-eap: I obey thee chearfully,
I ee the Doctrine of Non-Reitance is never practis'd thoroughly but when a Man can't help himelf.

div.stage: Enter a Second Merchant.

sp.speaker: 2d. Merchant.
sp.p: You, Friend, I wou'd ee that Fellow do his Potures.

sp.speaker: Mutapha
sp.p: Now Sirrah follow, for you have rope enough:
To your paces Villain, amble, trot, and gallop:—
Quick, about there.— Yeap, the more Money's bidden for you, the more your credit.

div.stage: Antonio follows at the end of the Bridle on his hands and feet, and does all his Potures.

sp.speaker: 2d. Merch.
sp.p: He's well chin'd, and has a tolerable good back; that's half in half. [To Mutapha.] I wou'd ee him trip, has he no Dieaes about him?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: He's the bet piece of Man's fleh in the Market, not an Eye-ore in his whole body: Feel his Legs, Mater, neither Splint, Spavin, nor Wind gall. Claps him on the houlder.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.stage: feeling about him, and then putting his hand to his ide.
sp.p: Out upon him, how, his flank heaves! The Whoron's broken-winded.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Thick breath'd a little: Nothing but a orry cold with lying out a nights in Trenches;— but ound Wind and Limb, I warrant him.
Try him at a looe trot a little.

div.stage: Puts the Bridle into his hand, he trokes him.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: For Heaven's ake Owner pare me; you know I am but new broken.

sp.speaker: 2d. Merch.
sp.p: 'Tis but a wahy Jade, I ee: What do you ask for this Bauble?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Bauble do you call him; he's a ubtantial true-bred Beat; bravely forehanded; mark but the cleannes of his hapes too; his Dam may be a Spanih Gennet, but a true Barb by the Sire, or I have no skill in Hore-fleh. —
Marry I ask Six Hundred Xeriffs for him.

div.stage: Enter Mufti.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: What's that you are asking, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Marry, I ask your Reverence Six Hundred Pardons; I was doing you a mall piece of ervice here, putting off your Chattel for you.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: And putting the Mony into your own Pocket.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Upon vulgar reputation, no my Lord, it was for your profit and emolument. What, wrong the Head of my Religion? I was enible you wou'd have damn'd me, or any man that hou'd have injur'd you in a ingle Farthing; for I knew that was Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: Sacriledge you mean, Sirrah,—and damning hall be the leat part of your punihment; I have taken you in the manner, and will have the Law upon you.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Good my Lord, take pity upon a poor man in this World, and damn me in the next.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: No Sirrah, o you may repent, and cape punihment: Did not you ell this very Slave amongt the ret to me, and take Mony for him.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Right my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: And elling him again? Take Mony twice for the ame Commodity? Oh, Villain!
But did you not know him to be my Slave, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Why hou'd I lye to your Honor, I did know him; and thereupon, eeing him wander about; I took him up for a tray, and impounded him, with intention to retore him to the right Owner.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: And yet at the ame time was elling him to another: How rarely the Story hangs together.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Patience, my Lord.

I took him up, as your Heriot, with intention to have made the bet of him, and then have brought the whole product of him in a Pure to you; for I know you wou'd have pent half of it upon your pious Pleaures, have hoarded up the other half, and given the remainder in Charities to the Poor.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: And what's become of my other Slave? Thou hat old him too I have a villainous upicion.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I know you have, my Lord; but while I was managing this young robutous Fellow, that old Spark who was nothing but Skin and Bone, and by conequence, very nimble, lipt through my fingers like an Eel, for there was no hold fat of him, and ran away to buy himelf a new Mater.

Follow me home, Sirrah: [to Mut.] I hall remember you ome other time.
Exit Mufti with Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p:
I never doubted your Lordhips memory, for an ill turn: And I hall remember him too in the next riing of the Mobile, for this act of Reumption; and more epecially for the Ghotly Counel he gave me before the Emperor, to have hang'd my elf in ilence, to have av'd his Reverence. The
bet on't is, I am beforehand with him, for elling one of his Slaves twice over.—And if he had not come jut in the nick, I might have pocketed up t'other: For what hould a poor Man do, that gets his living by hard labor, but pray for bad times when he may get it eaily. O, for ome incomparable Tumult! Then hou'd I naturally wih, that the beaten Party might prevail, becaue we have plundered t'other ide already, and there's nothing more to get of 'em.
sp.l: Both rich and poor for their own interet pray,
'Tis ours to make our Fortunes while we may;
For Kingdoms are not conquer'd every day.

div.stage: Exit Mutaph.

div.head: Scene 1. Suppos'd to be a terrace Walk, on the ide of the Catle of Alcazar.
div.stage: Emperor. Benducar.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.p: AND thinket thou not it was dicovered?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: No:
The thoughts of Kings are like religious Groves,
The Walks of muffled Gods Sacred retreat,
Where none but whom they pleae t'admit, approach.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Did not my concious Eyes flah out a Flame
To lighten thoe brown horrors, and dicloe
The ecret path I trod?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: I cou'd not find it, 'till you lent a Clue
To that cloe Labarynth; how then hou'd they?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I wou'd be loth they hou'd: it breeds contempt
For Herds to liten, or preume to pry,
When the hurt Lion groans within his Den:
But is 't not trange?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: To love? not more than 'tis to live; a Tax
Impos'd on all by Nature, paid in kind,
Familiar as our being.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Still 'tis trange
To me: I know my Soul as wild as winds,
That weep the Dearts of our moving Plains;
Love might as well be ow'd upon our Sands,
As in a bret o barren:
To love an Enemy, the only One
Remaining too, whom yeter Sun beheld,
Mut'ring her charms, and rolling as he pat,
By every Squadron her alluring eyes:
To edge her Champions Swords, and urge my ruin.
The houts of Soldiers, and the burt of Cannon,
Maintain ev'n till a deaf and murm'ring noie;
Nor is Heav'n yet recover'd of the ound
Her Battel rows'd; Yet pight of me I love.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: What then controuls you?
Her Peron is as protrate as her Party.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: A thouand things controul this Conqueror,
My native pride to own th'unworthy paion,
Hazard of Int'ret, and my Peoples love:
To what a Storm of Fate am I expos'd!
What if I had her murder'd? 'tis but what
My Subjects all expect, and he deerves.
Wou'd not th' impoibility
Of ever, ever eeing, or poeing,
Calm all this rage, this Hurrican of Soul?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: That ever, ever,
I mark'd the double, hows extream reluctance
To part with her for ever.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Right thou hat me,
I wou'd, but cannot kill: I mut enjoy her:
I mut, and what I mut be ure I will.
What's Royalty but pow'r to pleae my elf?
And if I dare not, then am I the Slave,
And my own Slaves the Sovereigns, — 'tis reolv'd,
Weak Princes flatter when they want the pow'r
To curb their People; tender Plants mut bend,
But when a Government is grown to trength,
Like ome old Oak, rough with its armed Bark,
It yields not to the tug, but only nods,
And turns to ullen State.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Then you reolve
T'implore her pity, and to beg relief?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Death, mut I beg the pity of my Slave?
Mut a King beg? Yes, Love's a greater King;
A Tyrant, nay a Devil that poees me:
He tunes the Organs of my voice, and peaks
Unknown to me within me; puhes me,
And drives me on by force. —
Say I hou'd wed her, wou'd not my wie Subjects
Take check, and think it trange? perhaps revolt?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: I hope they wou'd not.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Then thou doubt't they wou'd?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: To her
Perhaps, or to my Brother, or to Thee.
To me! me did you mention? how I tremble!
The name of Treaon hakes my honet Soul.
If I am doubted, Sir,
Secure your elf this moment, take my life.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: No more: if I upected thee — I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: I thank your kindnes: Guilt had almot lot me! Aide.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: But clear my doubts: think't thou they may rebel.
This goes as I wou'd wih: — (to th' Emp.) 'Tis poible.
A ecret Party till remains, that lurks
Like Embers rak'd in ahes — wanting but
A breath to blow aide th'involving dut,
And then they blaze abroad.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: They mut be trampled out.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: But firt be known.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Torture hall force it from 'em.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: You wou'd not put a Nation to the rack?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Yes, the whole World; o I be afe, I care not.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Our Limbs and Lives
Are yours, but mixing Friends with Foes is hard.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: All may be foes; or how to be ditinguih'd,
If ome be friends?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: They may with eae be winnow'd:
Suppoe ome one, who has deerv'd your trut,
Some one who knows Mankind, hou'd be employ'd
To mix among 'em, eem a Malcontent,
And dive into their breats, to try how far
They dare oppoe your love?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: I like this well: 'Tis wholeom wickednes.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Whomever he upects, he fatens there,
And leaves no cranny of his Soul unearch'd:
Then, like a Bee bag'd with his honey'd venome,
He brings it to your Hive: if uch a Man
So able, and o honet, may be found;
If not, my project dyes. —

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: By all my hopes thou hat decrib'd thy elf: —
Thou, thou alone art fit to play that Engine,
Thou only coudt contrive.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Sure I cou'd erve you:
I think I cou'd: — but here's the difficulty,
I'm o entirely yours,
That I hou'd curvily diemble hate;
The cheat wou'd be too gros.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Art thou a Stateman
And cant not be a Hypocrite? Impoible:
Do not ditrut thy Vertues.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: If I mut peronate this eeming Villain,
Remember 'tis to erve you.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No more words:
Love goads me to Almeyda, all affairs
Are troubleom but that; and yet that mot.
Bid Dorax treat Sebatian like a King;
I had forgot him; — but this Love marrs all,
And takes up my whole bret. Exit Emperor.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: (to the Emp.) Be ure I'll tell him. —
With all the aggravating Circumtances Alone.
I can, to make him well at that Command,
The Tyrant firt upected me:
Then, with a udden gut, he whirld about,
And truted me too far: Madnes of Pow'r!
Now, by his own conent, I ruin him.
For, hou'd ome feeble Soul, for fear or gain
Bolt out t'accue me, ev'n the King is cozen'd,
And thinks he's in the ecret.
How weet is Treaon when the Traytor's afe!
sp.stage: (Sees the Mufti and Dorax entring and eeming to confer.)
sp.l: The Mufti, and with him my ullen Dorax,
That firt is mine already.
'Twas eaie work to gain a cov'tous mind,
Whom rage to looe his Pris'ners had prepar'd:
Now, caught himelf,
He wou'd educe another; I mut help him:
For Church-men, though they itch to govern all,
Are illy, woful, awkard Politicians;
They make lame michief, though they mean it well:
Their Int'ret is not finely drawn, and hid,
But eams are coarly bungled up, and een.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: He'll tell you more.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I've heard enough already
To make me loath thy Morals.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l:
to Dor.
You eem warm:
The good Man's zeal, perhaps has gon too far.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not very far; not farther than zeal goes
Of coure; a mall days journey hort of Treaon.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: By all that's Holy, Treaon was not nam'd:
I par'd the Emperors broken Vows to ave
The Slaves from Death; though it was cheating Heav'n,
But I forgave him that.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And lighted o'er cornfully.
The wrongs himelf utain'd in property:
When his bought Slaves were eiz'd by force, no los
Of his conider'd, and no cot repaid.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: Not wholly lighted o'er, not abolutely:
Some modet hints of private wrongs I urg'd.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Two thirds of all he aid: there he began;
To hew the fulnes of his heart, there ended:
Some hort excurions of a broken Vow,
He made indeed, but flat inipid tuff:
But when he made his los the Theme, he flourih'd,
Reliev'd his fainting Rhetorick with new Figures,
And thunder'd at oppreing Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: Why not, when Sacrilegious Pow'r wou'd eize
My Property, 'tis an affront to Heav'n,
Whoe Peron, though unworthy, I utain.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: You've made uch trong Alliances above,
That 'twere Profanenes in us Laiety
To offer earthly Aid.
I tell thee, Mufti, if the World were wie,
They wou'd not wag one finger in your quarrels.
Your Heav'n you promie, but our Earth you covet.
The Phaethons of mankind, who fire that World,
Which you were ent by Preaching but to warm.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: This goes beyond the mark.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: No, let him rail;
His Prophet works within him;
He's rare Convert.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Now his Zeal yearns,
To ee me burnt; he damns me from his Church,
Becaue I wou'd retrain him to his Duty;
Is not the care of Souls a load ufficient?
Are nor your holy tipends pay'd for this?
Were you not bred apart from worldly noie,
To tudy Souls, their Cures and their Dieaes?
If this be o, we ask you but our own:
Give us your whole Employment, all your care:
The Province of the Soul is large enough
To fill up every Cranny of your time,
And leave you much to anwer, if one Wretch
Be damn'd by your neglect.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p:
to the Mufti.
He peaks but reaon.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Why then thee forein thoughts of State-Employments,
Abhorrent to your Function and your Breeding?
Poor droaning Truants of unpractis'd Cells,
Bred in the Fellowhip of bearded Boys,
What wonder is it if you know not Men?
Yet there, you live demure, with down-cat Eyes,
And humble as your Dicipline requires:
But, when let looe from thence to live at large,
Your little tincture of Devotion dies:
Then Luxury ucceeds, and et agog
With a new Scene of yet untated Joys,
You fall with greedy hunger to the Feat.
Of all your College Vertues, nothing now
But your Original Ignorance remains:
Bloated with Pride, Ambition, Avarice,
You well, to counel Kings and govern Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: He prates as if Kings had not Conciences,
And none requir'd Directors but the Crowd.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: As private men they want you, not as Kings;
Nor wou'd you care t' inpect their publick Concience,
But that it draws dependencies of Pow'r,
And Earthly Interet which you long to way.
Content you with monopolizing Heav'n,
And let this little hanging Ball alone
For give you but a foot of Concience there,
And you, like Archimedes, tos the Globe.
We know your thoughts of us that Laymen are
Lag Souls, and rubbih of remaining Glay,
Which Heav'n, grown weary of more perfect work,
Set upright with a little puff of breath,
And bid us pas for Men.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.l: I will not anwer,
Bae foul mouth'd Renegade; but I'll pray for thee

To hew my Charity.
Exit Mufti.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Do; but forget not him who needs it mot:
Allow thy elf ome hare: He's gone too oon;
I had to tell him of his holy jugglings;
Things that wou'd tartle Faith, and make us deem
Not this or that, but all Religions fale.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Our Holy Oratour has lot the Caue: Aide.
But I hall yet redeem it.— (to Dorax) let him go;
For I have ecret Orders from the Emperour,
Which none but you mut hear: I mut confes
I cou'd have wih'd ome other hand had brought 'em.
When did you ee your Pri'ner Great Sebatian?

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: You might as well have ask'd me when I aw
A creted Dragon, or a Bailisk;
Both are les Poion to my Eyes and Nature.
He knows not I am I; nor hall he ee me
Till time has perfected a lab'ring thought,
That rouls within my bret.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: 'Twas my mitake:
I gues'd indeed that time, and his misfortunes,
And your returning duty had effac'd
The mem'ry of pat wrongs; they wou'd in me;
And I judg'd you as tame and as forgiving.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Forgive him! no, I left my foolih Faith
Becaue it wou'd oblige me to forgivenes.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: I can but grieve to find you obtinate:
For you mut ee him; 'tis our Emp'rours will,
And trict Command.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: I laugh at that Command.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: You mut do more than ee; erve, and repect him.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: See, erve him, and repect, and after all
My yet uncancell'd wrongs, I mut do this!
But I forget my elf.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Indeed you do.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: The Emp'rour is a tranger to my wrongs;
I need but tell my tory, to revoke
This hard Commiion.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Can you call me Friend,
And think I cou'd neglect to peak, at full
Th' Affronts you had from your ungrateful Mater?

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: And yet enjoyn'd my Service, and Attendance?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: And yet enjoyn'd 'em both: wou'd that were all;
He cru'd his Face into a harden'd mile,
And aid, Sebatian knew to govern Slaves.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Slaves are the growth of Africk, not of Europe:
By Heav'n I will not lay down my Commiion;
Not at his foot, I will not toop o low;
But if there be a part in all his Face
More acred than the ret, I'll throw it there.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: You may; but then you loe all future means
Of Vengeance on Sebatian, when no more
Alcalde of this Fort.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: That thought ecap'd me.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Keep your Command; and be reveng'd on both:
Nor ooth your elf; you have no pow'r t' affront him;
The Emp'rours love protects him from inults.
And he, who poke that proud ill natur'd word,
Following the bent of his impetuous temper,
May force your reconcilement to Sebatian:
Nay bid you kneel, and kis th' offending foot,
That kick'd you from his Preence.
But think not to divide their punihment;
You cannot touch a hair of loath'd Sebatian,
While Muley-Moluch lives.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: What means this Riddle?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: 'Tis out: there needs no Oedipus to olve it.
Our Emp'rour is a Tyrant, fear'd and hated;
I carce remember in his Reign, one day
Pas guiltles o'er his execrable head.
He thinks the Sun is lot that ees not bloud:
When none is hed we count it Holiday.
We, who are mot in favour, cannot call
This hour our own?— you know the younger Brother
Mild Muley Zeydan;—

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: Hold and let me think.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: The Soldiers Idolize you,
He truts you with the Catle,
The Key of all his Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: Well; and he truts you too.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Ele I were mad,
To hazard uch a daring Enterprize.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: He truts us both; mark that, hall we betray him?
A Mater who repoes Life and Empire
On our fidelity: I grant he is a Tyrant,
That hated name my nature mot abhors;
More, as you ay, has loaded me with corn:
Ev'n with the lat contempt, to erve Sebatian.
Yet more I know he vacates my revenge;
Which, but by this revolt I cannot compas:
But, while he truts me, 'twere o bae a part
To fawn and yet betray, I hou'd be his'd
And whoop'd in Hell for that Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Conider well what I have done for you.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: Conider thou what thou woud't have me do.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: You've too much honour for a Renegade.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: And thou too little faith to be a Fav'rite.
Is not the bread thou eat't, the Robe thou wear't,
Thy Wealth, and Honours, all the pure indulgence
Of him thou wou'dt detroy?
And wou'd his Creature, nay his Friend betray him?
Why then no Bond is left on human kind:
Ditruts, debates, immortal trifes enue;
Children may murder Parents, Wives their Husbands;
All mut be Rapine, Wars, and Deolation,
When trut and gratitude no longer bind.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Well have you argued in your own defence:
You, who have burt aunder all thoe bonds,
And turn'd a Rebel to your Native Prince.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: True, I rebell'd: but when did I betray?
Indignities, which Man cou'd not upport,
Provok'd my vengeance to this noble Crime.
But he had trip'd me firt of my Command,
