Dimis'd my Service, and abolv'd my Faith;
And, with didainful Language, dar'd my wort.
I but accepted War, which he denounc'd.
Ele had you een, not Dorax, but Alonzo,
With his couch'd Lance againt your foremot Moors:
Perhaps too turn'd the fortune of the day;
Made Affrick mourn, and Portugal triumph.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Let me embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Stand off Sycophant,
And keep Infection ditant.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Brave and honet.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.p: In pight of thy Temptations.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Call 'em Trials:
They were no more: thy faith was held in Balance,
And nicely weigh'd by jealouie of Pow'r;
Vat was the trut of uch a Royal Charge;
And our wie Emperour, might jutly fear
Sebatian might be freed and reconcil'd,
By new Obligements to thy former love.

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: I doubt thee till; thy reaons were too trong,
And driv'n too near the head, to be but Artifice.
And after all, I know thou art a Stateman,
Where truth is rarely found.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Behold the Emperour;
Ask him, I beg thee to be jutify'd,
If he employ'd me not to foord thy Soul,
And try the footing whether fale or firm

sp.speaker: Dorax,
sp.l: Death to my Eyes, I ee Sebatian with him!
Mut he be erv'd! avoid him, if we meet,
It mut be like the cruh of Heav'n and Earth,

T' involve us both in ruin.
Exit Dorax.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: 'Twas a bare aving game I made with Dorax,
But better o than lot; he cannot hurt me,
That I precaution'd: I mut ruin him.
But now this Love; Ay, there's the gath'ring torm!
The Tyrant mut not wed Almeyda; no,
That ruins all the Fabrick I am raiing,
Yet eeming to approve it, gave me time,
And gaining time gains all.

div.stage: (Benducar goes and waits behind the Emperour.)
(The Emperour; Sebatian and Almeyda advance to the front of the Stage.) Guards and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l:
to Seb.
I bad 'em erve you, and if they obey not,
I keep my Lions keen within their Dens,
To top their maws with diobedient Slaves.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If I had Conquer'd,
They cou'd not have with more obervance waited:
Their eyes, hands, feet,
Are all o quick they eem t' have but one motion,
To catch my flying words. Onely the Alcayde
Shuns me, and with a grim Civility,
Bows, and declines my Walks.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: A Renegade:
I know not more of him: but that he's brave,
And hates your Chritian Sect. If you can frame
A farther wih, give wing to your deires,
And name the thing you want.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: My Liberty:
For were ev'n Paradie it elf my Prion,
Still I hou'd long to leap the Chrytal walls.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Sure our two Souls have omewhere been acquainted:
In former beings; or, truck out together,
One park to Africk flew, and one to Portugal.
Expect a quick deliverance: (turning to Alm:) here's a third,
Of kindred Soul to both: pity our Stars
Have made us Foes! I hou'd not wih her death.

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: I ask no pity; if I thought my Soul
Of kin to thine, oon wou'd I rend my heart-trings,
And tear out that Alliance: but thou Viper
Hat cancell'd kindred, made a rent in Nature,
And through her holy bowels gnaw'd thy way,
Through thy own Bloud to Empire.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: This again: —
And yet he lives; and only lives t' upbraid me.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: What honour is there in a Womans death!
Wrong'd as he ays, but helples to revenge
Strong in her Paion, impotent of Reaon,
Too weak to hurt, too fair to be detroy'd.
Mark her Majetick Fabrick; She's a Temple
Sacred by birth, and built by Hands Divine
Her Soul's the Deity, that lodges there:
Nor is the Pile unworthy of the God.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: She's all that thou cant ay or I can think.
But the pervernes of her clam'rous Tongue
Strikes Pity deaf.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Then onely hear her Eyes;
Though they are mute they plead; nay more, command;
For beauteous Eyes have Arbitrary Power.
All Females have prerogative of Sex,
The Shes ev'n of the alvage herd are afe;
And when they narl or bite, have no return
But Courthip from the Male.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Were She not She, and I not Muley-Moluch,
She's Mitres of unevitable Charms,
For all but me; nor am I o exempt,
But that — I know not what I was to ay —
But I am too obnoxious to my Friends;
And way'd by your Advice.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Sir, I advis'd not.
By Heav'n, I never counell'd Love but Pity.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: By Heav'n thou didt: deny it not, thou didt:
For what was all that Prodigality
Of praie, but to onflame me? —

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Sir, —

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No more:
Thou hat convinc'd me, that he's worth my Love.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Was ever Man o ruin'd by himelf! Aide.

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: Thy Love; that odious Mouth was never fram'd
To peak a word o oft:
Name Death again, for that thou cant pronounce
With horrid grace, becoming of a Tyrant.
Love is for human hearts, and not for thine,
Where the brute Beat extinguihes the Man.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: Such if I were, yet rugged Lions love,
And grapple, and compel their avage Dames.—
Mark my Sebatian, how that ullen frown, She frowns
Like flahing Lightning, opens angry Heaven;
And while it kills delights. But yet, inult not
Too oon, proud Beauty, I confes no love.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No Sir, I aid o, and I witnes for you,
Not love; but noble pity mov'd your mind:
Int'ret might urge you too to ave her life;
For thoe who wih her party lot, might murmur
At hedding Royal Blood.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Right, thou intruct't me;
Int'ret of State requires not Death, but Marriage;
T'unite the jarring Titles of our Line.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let me be dumb for ever, all I plead, Aide.
Like Wild-fire thrown againt the Wind, returns
With double force to burn me.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Cou'd I but bend to make my beauteous Foe
The Partner of my Throne, and of my Bed.—

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: Still thou diemblet, but I read thy heart,
And know the power of my own Charms; thou lov't,
And I am pleas'd for my revenge thou dot.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: And thou hat caue.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I have; for I have pow'r to make thee wretched.
Be ure I will, and yet depair of freedom.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Well then, I love,—
And 'tis below my greatnes to diown it:
Love thee implacably, yet hate thee too;
Wou'd hunt thee bare-foot, in the mid-day Sun,
Through the parch'd Dearts, and the corching Sands,
T'enjoy thy Love, and once enjoy'd to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: 'Tis a fale Courage, when thou threat'net me;
Thou cant not tir a hand to touch my Life:
Do not I ee thee tremble while thou peak't?
Lay by the Lions Hide, vain Conqueror,
And take the Ditaff; for thy Soul's my Slave.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Confuion! How thou viewet my very Heart!
I cou'd as oon,
Stop a Spring-tide, blown in, with my bare hand,
As this impetuous Love:—Yes, I will wed thee;
In pight of thee, and of my elf, I will.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: For what? To people Affric with new Monters,
Which that unnatural mixture mut produce?
No, were we joyn'd, e'vn tho it were in death,
Our Bodies burning in one Funeral Pile,
The Prodigy of Thebes wou'd be renew'd,
And my divided flame hou'd break from thine.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Serpent, I will engender Poyon with thee;
Joyn Hate with Hate, add Venom to the birth;
Our Off-pring, like the eed of Dragons Teeth,
Shall iue arm'd, and fight themelves to death.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I'm calm again; thou cant not marry me.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: As gleams of Sun-hine often torms to how'rs,
So, if you mile, the loudnes of my rage
In gentle Whipers hall return, but this,—
That nothing can divert my Love, but Death.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: See how thou art deceiv'd, I am a Chritian;
'Tis true, unpractis'd in my new Belief,
Wrongs I reent, nor pardon yet with eae:
Thoe Fruits come late, and are of low increae
In haughty Hearts, like mine: Now, tell thy elf
If this one word detroy not thy deigns:
Thy Law permits thee not to marry me.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: 'Tis but a pecious Tale, to blat my hopes,
And baffle my pretenions. Speak, Sebatian,
And, as a King, peak true.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Then, thus adjur'd,
On a King's word 'tis truth, but truth ill tim'd;
For her dear Life is now expos'd anew;
Unles you wholly can put on Divinity,
And graciouly forgive.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Now learn by this,
The little value I have left for life,
And trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I thank thee Woman;
Thou hat retor'd me to my native Rage;
And I will eize my happines by force.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Know Muley-Moluch when thou dar't attempt.—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Beware, I wou'd not be provok'd to ue
A Conqueror's right, and therefore charge thy ilence.
If thou wou'dt merit to be thought my Friend,
I leave thee to perwade her to compliance:
If not, there's a new gut in Ravihment,
Which I have never try'd.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: They mut be watch'd; aide.
For omething I oberv'd creates a doubt.

div.stage: Exeunt Emperour and Benducar.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I've been too tame, have baely born my Wrongs,
And not exerted all the King, within me;
I heard him, O weet Heavens, he threat'ned Rape;
Nay inolently urg'd me to perwade thee,
Ev'n thee, thou Idol of my Soul and Eyes;
For whom I uffer Life, and drag this being.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: You turn my Prion to a Paradie;
But I have turn'd your Empire to a Prion:
In all your Wars good fortune flew before you;
Sublime you ate in Triumph on her Wheel;
Till in my fatal Caue your Sword was drawn;
The weight of my misfortunes drag'd you down.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And is't not trange, that Heav'n hou'd bles my Arms
In common Caues, and deert the bet?
Now in your greatet, lat extremity,
When I wou'd, ayd you mot, and mot deire it,
I bring but Sighs, the uccors of a Slave.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Leave then the luggage of your fate behind,
To make your flight more eaie, leave Almeyda.
Nor think me left a bae ignoble Prey,
Expos'd to this inhuman Tyrant's lut;
My Virtue is a guard beyond my trength,
And Death, my lat defence, within my call.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Death may be call'd in vain, and cannot come;
Tyrants can tye him up from your relief:
Nor has a Chritian privilege to dye.
Alas thou art too young in thy new Faith;
Brutus and Cato might dicharge their Souls,
And give 'em Furlo's for another World:
But we, like Centry's, are oblig'd to tand
In tarles Nights, and wait the pointed hour.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: If hunning ill be good, then Death is good
To thoe who cannot hun it but by Death:
Divines but peep on undicover'd Worlds,
And draw the ditant Landhape as they pleae:
But who has e'er return'd from thoe bright Regions,
To tell their Manners, and relate their Laws?
I'll venture landing on that happy hoar
With an unully'd Body, and white Mind;
If I have err'd, ome kind Inhabitant
Will pity a tray'd Soul, and take me home.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Beware of Death, thou cant not dye unperjur'd,
And leave an unaccomplih'd Love behind:
Thy Vows are mine; nor will I quit my claim:
The tye of Minds are but imperfect Bonds,
Unles the Bodies joyn to eal the Contract.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: What Joys can you poes or can I give?
Where groans of Death ucceed the ighs of Love.
Our Hymen has not on his Saffron Robe;
But muffled up in Mourning, downward holds
His dropping Torch, extinguih'd with his Tears.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The God of Love tands ready to revive it
With his etherial breath.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: 'Tis late to joyn, when we mut part o oon.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay rather let us hate it, ere we part:
Our Souls, for want of that acquaintance here,
May wander in the tarry Walks above,
And, forc'd on wore Companions, mis our elves.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: The Tyrant will not long be abent hence;
And oon I hall be ravih'd from your arms.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Wilt thou thy elf become the greater Tyrant,
And give not Love, while thou hat Love to give?
In dang'rous days, when Riches are a Crime,
The wie betimes make over their Etates:
Make oer thy Honour, by a deed of trut,
And give me eizure of the mighty wealth.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: What hall I do! O teach me to refue!
I wou'd; and yet I tremble at the grant.
For dire preages fright my Soul by day,
And boding Viions haunt my Nightly Dreams:
Sometimes, methinks, I hear the groans of Ghots;
Thin, hollow ounds, and lamentable creams;
Then, like a dying Eccho, from afar,
My Mothers Voice, that cries, Wed not Almeyda!
Forewarn'd Almeyda, Marriage is thy Crime.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Some envious Demon, to delude our joys;
Love is not Sin, but where 'tis inful Love.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Mine is a flame o holy, and o clear,
That the white taper leaves no oot behind;
No moak of Lut; but chat as Siter's love,
When coldly they return a Brothers kis,
Without the zeal that meets at lovers mouths.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Laugh then at fond preages; I had ome;
Fam'd Notradamus, when he took my Horocope,
Foretold my Father I hou'd wed with Incet:
Ere this unhappy War my Mother dy'd;
And Siters I had none; vain Augury!
A long Religious Life, a Holy Age,
My Stars aign'd me too; impoible.
For how can Incet uit with Holines,
Or Prietly Orders with a Princely State?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Old venerable Alvarez! — (ighing.)

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: But why that igh in naming that good Man?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Your Fathers Counellor and Confident —

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He was; and, if he lives, my econd Father:

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Mark'd our farewel, when going to the ight,
You gave Almeyda for the word of Battel;
'Twas in that fatal Moment, he dicover'd
The Love that long we labour'd to conceal.
I know it; though my eyes tood full of tears,
Yet, through the mit, I aw him tedfat gaze:
Then knock'd his Aged breat, and inward groan'd;
Like ome ad Prophet, that foreaw the doom
Of thoe whom bet he lov'd, and cou'd not ave.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It tartles me! and brings to my remembrance,
That, when the hock of Battel was begun,
He wou'd have much complain'd (but had not time)
Of our hid paion; then, with lifted hands,
He beg'd me by my Fathers Sacred Soul,
Not to epoue you, if he dy'd in fight:
For if he liv'd, and we were Conquerors,
He had uch things to urge againt our Marriage,
As, now declar'd, wou'd blunt my word in Battel;
And datardize my Courage.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: My blood cruddles;
And cakes about my heart.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'll breath a igh, o warm into thy boom,
Shall make it flow again. My Love, he knows not
Thou art a Chritian; that produc'd his fear:
Let thou houd't ooth my Soul with charms o trong,
That Heav'n might prove too weak.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: There mut be more:
This cou'd not blunt your Sword.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yes, if I drew it, with a curt intent,
To take a Misbeliever to my Bed;
It mut be o.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Yet —

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No, thou halt not plead
With that fair mouth, againt the Caue of Love.
Within this Catle is a Captive Priet,
My Holy Confeor, whoe free acces
Not ev'n the barb'rous Victors have refus'd;
This happy hour his hands hall make us one.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I go; with Love and Fortune, two blind Guides,
To lead my way: half loth and half conenting.
If, as my Soul fore-bodes, ome dire event
Purue this Union, or ome Crime unknown,
Forgive me Heav'n; and all ye Blet above,
Excue the frailty of unbounded Love.

div.stage: Exeunt Ambo.

div.head: Scene 2. Suppo'd a Garden; with Lodging Rooms behind it; or on the ides.
div.stage: Enter Mufti; Antonio as a Slave; and Johayma the Mufti's Wife.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: ANd how do you like him, look upon him well; he's a peronable Fellow of a Chritian Dog. Now I think you are fitted, for a Gardiner: Ha what ay't thou Johayma?

sp.speaker: Johayma.
sp.p: He may make a hift to ow lettice, raie Melons, and water a Garden plat.
But otherwie a very filthy Fellow; how odiouly he mells of his Country garlike! fugh, how he tinks of Spain.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Why honey-bird I bought him a purpoe for thee; didt not thou ay thou long'dt for a Chritian Slave?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Ah, but the ight of that loathom creature has almot cur'd me; And how can I tell that he's a Chritian? and he were well earch'd he may prove a Jew for ought I know.
And beides I have always long'd for an Eunuch; for they ay that's a Civil Creature, and almot as harmles as your elf Husband: peak fellow, are not you uch a kind of peaceable thing?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I was never taken for one in my own Country; and not very peaceable neither, when I am well provok'd.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: To your Occupation Dog; bind up the Jeamines in yond Arbor, and handle your pruning knife with dexterity; tightly I ay, go tightly to your buines; you have cot me much; and mut earn it in your work; here's plentiful proviion for you, racal, allating in the Garden, and water in the tanck, and on Holydays the licking of a platter of Rice, when you deerve it.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: What have you been bred up to Sirrah, and what can you perform to recommend you to my ervice?

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.p: Why Madam, I can perform as much as any Man, in a fair Ladies Service.

I can play upon the Flute, and Sing; I can carry your Umbrella, and fan your Ladyhip, and cool you when you are too hot: in fine, no Service either by day or by night hall come amis to me; and beides am of o quick an apprehenion, that you need but wink upon me at any time, to make me undertand my duty.

div.stage: She winks at him.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Very fine, he has tipt the wink already. — Aide.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: The Whelp may come to omething in time, when I have enter'd him into his buines.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: A very malapert Cur, I can tell him that; I do not like his fawning, you mut be taught your ditance Sirrah.

div.stage: (Strikes him.)

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hold, hold. —
sp.p: He ha's deerv'd it I confes; but for once let his ignorance plead his pardon; we mut not dicourage a beginner. Your Reverence has taught us Charity ev'n to Birds and Beats: here you filthy brute you: — take this little Alms, to buy you plaiters. (gives him a piece of money)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Money and a Love pinch in the inide of my palm into the bargain. Aide.
Sir, my Lord Benducar is coming to wait on you, and is already at the Palace Gate.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Come in Johayma, regulate the ret of my Wives and Concubines, and leave the Fellow to his work.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Look how tupidly he tares about him, like a Calf new come into the World: I hall teach you Sirrah to know your buines, a little better. — this way you awkard racal, here lyes the Arbour, mut I be howing you eternally?

div.stage: (turning him about.)

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Come away Minion; you hall how him nothing.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I'll but bring him into the Arbor, where a Roe-tree and a Myrtle are jut falling for want of a prop; if they were bound together they wou'd help to keep up one another: — He's a raw Gardiner, and 'tis but Charity to teach him.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: No more deeds of Charity to day; come in, or I hall think you a little better dipos'd than I cou'd wih you.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Well, go before, I will follow my Pator.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: So you may cat a heeps eye behind you: In before me. And you, awcines, mind your pruning knife; or I may chance to ue it for you.

div.stage: Exeunt Mufti and Johayma.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: alone. Thank you for that; but I am in no uch hat to be made a Muulman. For his Wedlock, with all her haughtines, I find her coming. How far a Chritian hou'd reit, I partly know; but how far a lewd young Chritian can reit is another quetion. She's tolerable, and I am a poor Stranger, far from better Friends, and in a bodily neceity: Now have I a trange temptation to try what other Females are belonging to this Family: I am not far from the Womens apartment I am ure; and if thee Birds are within ditance, here's that will chuckle 'em together. (pulls out his Flute) If there be variety of Moors fleh in this Holy Market 'twere madnes to lay out all my money upon the firt bargain.

div.stage: He plays.
A Grate opens and Morayma the Mufti's Daughter appears at it.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Ay there's an Apparition! This is a Morel worthy of a Mufti; this is the relihing bit in ecret; this is the Mytery of his Alcoran, that mut be reerv'd from the knowledg of the profane Vulgar. This is his Holyday Devotion; ee, he beckons too. —

div.stage: (She beckons to him.)

sp.speaker: Morayma.
sp.p: Come a little nearer and peak oftly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I come, I come I warrant thee; the leat twinckle had brought me to thee; uch another kind yllable or two, wou'd turn me to a Meteor and draw me up to thee.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I dare not peak, for fear of being over-heard; but if you think my Peron worth your hazard, and can deerve my love — the ret this Note hall tell you — (throws down a handkerchief.) No more, my heart goes with you.

div.stage: Exit from the Grate.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: O thou pretty little heart; art thou flown hither, I'll keep it warm I warrant it, and brood upon it in the newnet: but now for my Treaure trove, that's wrapt up in the handkerchief: No peeping here, though I long to be pelling her Arabick crawls and pot-hooks. But I mut carry off my prize, as Robbers do; and not think of haring the booty, before I am free from danger, and out of eye-hot from the other Windows. If her wit be as poynant as her Eyes, I am a double Slave. Our Northern Beauties are meer dough to thee: Inipid white Earth, meer Tobaccopipe-clay; With no more Soul and Motion in 'em, than a Fly in Winter.
sp.l: Here the warm Planet ripens, and ublimes
The well bak'd Beauties of the Southern Climes;
Our Cupid's but a bungler in his Trade;
His keenet Arrows are in Affrick made.

div.stage: Exit Antonio.

div.head: Scene 1. A Terrace-walk; or ome other publick place in the Catle of Alcazar.
div.stage: Emperor Muley-Moluch; Benducar.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: MArry'd! I'll not believe it; 'tis impoture;
Improbable they hou'd preume t'attempt,
Impoible they hou'd effect their wih.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Have patience till I clear it.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I have none:
Go bid our moving Plains of Sand lye till,
And tir not, when the tormy South blows high
From top to bottom thou hat to'd my Soul,
And now 'tis in the madnes of the Whirl,
Requir't a udden top? unay thy lye,
That may in time do omewhat.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: I have done:
For, ince it pleaes you it hou'd be forg'd,
'Tis fit it hou'd: far be it from your Slave,
To raie diturbance in your Sacred bret.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Sebatian is my Slave as well as thou;
Nor durt offend my love by that preumption.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Mot ure he ought not.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Then all means were wanting;
No Priet, no Ceremonies of their Sect;
Or, grant we thee defects cou'd be upply'd,
How cou'd our Prophet do an Act o bae,
So to reume his gifts, and cure my Conquets
By making me unhappy! No, the Slave
That told thee o aburd a tory, ly'd.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Yet, till this moment I have found him faithful:
He aid he aw it too.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Dipatch; what aw he?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Truth is, conidering with what earnetnes,
Sebatian pleaded for Almeyda's life,
Inhanc'd her beauty, dwelt upon her praie, —

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: O tupid, and unthinking as I was!
I might have mark'd it too: 'twas gros and palpable!

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Methought I trac'd a Lover ill diguis'd;
And ent my py, a harp oberving Slave,
T'inform me better, if I gues'd aright.
He told me, that he aw Sebatians Page
Run cros the Marble Square; who oon return'd,
And after him there lag'd a puffing Fryar;
Cloe wrap'd he bore ome ecret Intrument
Of Chritian Supertition in his hand:
My ervant follow'd fat, and through a chink,
Perceiv'd the Royal Captives hand in hand:
And heard the hooded Father mumbling charme,
That make thoe Misbelievers Man and Wife.
Which done, the Spoues kis'd with uch a fervour,
And gave uch furious earnet of their flames,
That their eyes parkled, and their mantling blood
Flew fluhing o'er their faces.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Hell confound 'em!

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: The Reverend Father, with a Holy leer,
Saw he might well be par'd, and oon withdrew:
This forc'd my Servant to a quick retreat,
For fear to be dicover'd; gues the ret.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I do. My fancy is too exquiite,
And tortures me with their imagin'd blis
Some Earthquake hou'd have ris'n, and rent the ground,
Have wallow'd him; and left the longing Bride,
In Agony of unaccomplih'd Love. (Walks diorderly)

div.stage: Enter the Mufti.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: In an unlucky hour Aide.
That Fool intrudes, raw in this great affair,
And unintructed how to tem the tide.
sp.stage: Coming up to the Mufti aide.
sp.l: The Emp'ror mut not marry, nor enjoy;
Keep to that point; tand firm, for all's at take.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: You, Druggerman of Heaven, mut I attend
Your droaning Prayers? Why came you not before?
Do't thou not know the Captive King has dar'd
To wed Almeyda? Cancel me that Marriage,
And make her mine; about the buines, quick,
Expound thy Mahomet; make him peak my ene,
Or he's no Prophet here, and thou no Mufti,
Unles thou know't the trick of thy vocation,
To wret and rend the Law to pleae thy Prince.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: Why, verily the Law is montrous plain:
There's not one doubtful Text in all the Alchoran,
Which can be wrench'd in favor to your Project.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Forge one, and foit it into ome by-place,
Of ome old rotten Roll; do't, I command thee:
Mut I teach thee thy Trade?

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: It cannot be.
For Matrimony being the dearet point
Of Law, the People have it all by heart:
A Cheat on Procreation will not pas.
Beides th' offence is o exorbitant, In a higher tone.
To mingle with a misbelieving Race,
That peedy Vengeance wou'd purue your Crime,
And holy Mahomet launch himelf from Heav'n,
Before th' unready Thunderbolt were form'd.

div.stage: Emperor taking him by the Throat with one hand, natches out his Sword with the other, and points it to his Bret.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Slave, have I rais'd thee to this pomp and pow'r,
To preach againt my Will? Know I am Law;
And thou, not Mahomet's Meenger, but mine:
Make it, I charge thee, make my pleaure lawful:
Or firt I trip the of thy ghotly greatnes,
Then end thee pot, to tell thy Tale above;
And bring thy vain Memorials to thy Prophet
Of Jutice done below for Diobedience.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: For Heaven's ake hold, the repite of a moment,—
To think for you.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: And for thy elf.—

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: For both.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Digrace, and Death, and Avarice have lot him! Aide.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: 'Tis true, our Law forbids to wed a Chritian;
But it forbids you not to ravih her.
You have a Conqueror's right upon your Slave;
And then, the more depight you do a Chritian,
You erve the Prophet more who loaths that Sect.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Oh now it mends; and you talk reaon, Mufti.
But tay! I promis'd freedom to Sebatian:
Now hou'd I grant it, his revengeful Soul
Wou'd ne'er forgive his violated Bed.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.l: Kill him, for then you give him liberty:
His Soul is from his earthly Prion freed.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: How happy is the Prince who has a Churchman
So learn'd and pliant to expound his Laws.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Two things I humbly offer to your prudence.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Be brief; but let not either thwart my love.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Firt, ince our holy Man has made Rape lawful,
Fright her with that: proceed not yet to force:
Why hou'd you pluck the green ditatful Fruit
From the unwilling Bough,
When it may ripen of it elf and fall?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Grant her a day; tho that's too much to give
Out of a Life which I devote to Love.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Then next, to bar
All future hopes of her deir'd Sebatian,
Let Dorax be enjoyn'd to bring his head.

Go Mufti, call him to receive his Orders.
Exit Mufti.
I tate thy Counel, her deires new rowz'd,
And yet unlak'd, will kindle in her fancy,
And make her eager to renew the Feat.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: aide. Dorax, I know before, will diobey:
There's a Foe's Head well cropt.—
But this hot love precipitates my Plot;
And brings it to projection ere its time.

div.stage: Enter Sebatian and Almeyda hand in hand; upon ight of the Emperor, they eparate and eem diturb'd.

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: He breaks, at unawares, upon our Walks,
And like a mid-night Wolf invades the Fold:
Make peedy preparation of your Soul,
And bid it arm apace: He comes for anwer,
And brutal michief its upon his brow.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Not the lat ounding, cou'd urprize me more,
That ummons drowzy Mortals to their doom,
When call'd in hate, they fumble for their Limbs,
And tremble unprovided for their charge:
My ene has been o deeply plung'd in Joys,
The Soul out-lept her hour; and, carce awake,
Wou'd think too late, and cannot! But brave Minds
At wort can dare their Fate.—

div.stage: Emperor coming up to them.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Have you perform'd
Your Embay, and treated with ucces?

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: I had not time.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No, not for my Affairs,
But for your own too much.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: You talk in Clouds, explain your meaning, Sir.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Explain yours firt: What meant you hand in hand,
And when you aw me, with a guilty tart,
You loos'd your hold, affrighted at my preence?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Affrighted?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Yes, atonih'd, and confounded.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What mak't thou of thy elf, and what of me?
Art thou ome Ghot, ome Demon, or ome God?
That I hou'd tand atonih'd at thy ight?
If thou cou'dt deem o meanly of my Courage,
Why didt thou not engage me man for man,
And try the virtue of that Gorgon Face,
To tare me into tatue?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Oh, thou art now recover'd, but by Heav'n,
Thou wert amaz'd at firt, as if urpriz'd
At unexpected baenes brought to light.
For know, ungrateful man, that Kings, like Gods,
Are every where; walk in th' abys of minds,
And view the dark recees of the Soul.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bae and ungrateful never was I thought;
Nor till this turn of fate, durt thou have call'd me;
But, ince thou boat't th' omnicience of a God,
Say, in what cranny of Sebatian's Soul,
Unknown to me, o loath'd a Crime is lodg'd?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Thou hat not broke my trut repos'd in thee?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Impos'd, but not receiv'd: Take back that falehood.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Thou art not marry'd to Almeyda?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: And own't the uurpation of my Love?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I own it in the face of Heav'n and thee
No Uurpation; but a lawful claim,
Of which I tand poet.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Sh' has choen well,
Betwixt a Captive and a Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Almeyda,
sp.l: Betwixt a Monter and the bet of Men.
He was the envy of his neighb'ring Kings;
For him their ighing Queens depis'd their Lords,
And Virgin Daughters bluh'd when he was nam'd.
To hare his noble Chains is more to me,
Than all the alvage greatnes of thy Throne.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Were I to chooe again, and knew my fate,
For uch a night I wou'd be what I am.
The Joys I have poet are ever mine;
Out of thy reach behind Eternity,
Hid in the acred treaure of the pat;
But bles'd remembrance bring's 'em hourly back.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Hourly indeed, who hat but hours to live:
O mighty purchae of a boated blis!
To dream of what thou hadt one fugitive night,
And never halt have more.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Barbarian, thou cant part us but a moment;—
We hall be one again in thy depight:
Life is but air,
That yields a paage to the whitling Sword,
And cloes when 'tis gone.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: How can we better dye than cloe embrac'd,
Sucking each others Souls while we expire?
Which o transfus'd, and mounting both at once,
The Saints deceiv'd, hall by a weet mitake,
Hand up thy Soul for mine, and mine for thine.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No, I'll untwit you:
I have occaion for your tay on earth:
Let him mount firt, and beat upon the Wing,
And wait an Age for what I here detain.
Or icken at immortal Joys above,
And languih for the Heav'n he left below.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Thou wilt not dare to break what Heav'n has joyn'd?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Not break the Chain, but change a rotten link,
And rivet one to lat.
Think't thou I come to argue right and wrong?
Why lingers Dorax thus? Where are my Guards,
sp.stage: Benducar goes out for the Guards, and returns.
sp.l:
To drag that Slave to death?
Pointing to Sebat.
Now torm and rage,
Call vainly on thy Prophet, then defie him
For wanting power to ave thee.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: That were to gratifie thy Pride: I'll hew thee
How a Man hou'd, and how a King dare dye:
So even, that my Soul hall walk with eae
Out of its fleh, and hut out Life as calmly
As it does words; without a Sigh, to note
One truggle in the mooth diolving frame.
Expect revenge from Heav'n, inhuman Wretch;
Nor hope t' acend Sebatian's holy Bed.
Flames, Daggers, Poyons, guard the acred teps:
Thoe are the promis'd Pleaures of my love.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: And thee might fright another, but not me.
Or me, if I deign'd to give you pleaure;
I eek my own, and while that lats, you live.
Go, bear the Captive to a peedy death,
And et my Soul at eae.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I charge you hold, ye Miniters of death,
Speak my Sebatian;
Plead for thy life: Oh ask it of the Tyrant;
'Tis no dihonor, trut me, Love, 'tis none:
I wou'd die for thee, but I cannot plead;
My haughty heart didains it, ev'n for thee.
Still ilent! Will the King of Portugal
Go to his death, like a dumb Sacrifice?
Beg him to ave my life in aving thine.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Farewel, my life's not worth another word.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: to the Guards. Perform your Orders.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Stay, take my farewel too:
Farewel the greatnes of Almeyda's Soul!
Look, Tyrant, what exces of love can do,
It pulls me down thus low, as to thy feet; Kneels to him.
Nay to embrace thy Knees with loathing hands,
Which bliter when they touch thee: Yet ev'n thus,
Thus far I can to ave Sebatian's life.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: A ecret pleaure trickles through my Veins:
It works about the inlets of my Soul,
To feel thy touch; and pity tempts the pas;
But the tough metal of my heart reits;
'Tis warm'd with the oft fire, not melted down.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: A flood of calding Tears will make it run,
Spare him, Oh pare; can you pretend to love,
And have no pity? Love and that are Twins.
Here will I grow;
Thus compas you with thee upplanting Cords,
And pull o long till the proud Fabrick falls.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Still kneel, and till embrace; 'tis double pleaure
So to be hugg'd, and ee Sebatian dye.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Look. Tyrant, when thou nam't Sebatian's death,
Thy very Executioners turn pale,
Rough as they are, and harden'd in the trade
Of Death, they tart at an anointed Head,
And tremble to approach:—He hears me not;
Nor minds th' impreion of a God on Kings;
Becaue no tamp of Heav'n was on his Soul:
But the reiting Mas drove back the Seal.
Say, though thy heart be rock of Adamant,
Yet Rocks are not impregnable to Bribes:
Intruct me how to bribe thee: Name thy price;
Lo, I reign my Title to the Crown;
Send me to exile with the Man I love,
And banihment is Empire.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Here's my claim; Clapping his hand to his Sword.
And this extinguih'd thine; thou giv't me nothing.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: My Father's, Mothers, Brothers death I pardon:
That's omewhat ure; a mighty Sum of Murther,
Of innocent and kindred blood trook off.
My Prayers and Penance hall dicount for thee,
And beg of Heav'n to charge the Bill on me:
Behold what price I offer, and how dear
To buy Sebatian's life.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Let after reck'nings trouble fearful fools;
I'll tand the tryal of thoe trivial Crimes:
But, ince thou beg't me to precribe my terms,
The only I can offer are thy love;
And this one day of repite to reolve.
Grant or deny, for thy next word is Fate;
And Fate is deaf to Pray'r.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: May Heav'n be o Riing up.
At thy lat breath to thine: I cure thee not,
For who can better cure the Plague or Devil,
Than to be what they are? That Cure be thine.
Now, do not peak Sebatian, for you need not,
But dye, for I reign your Life: Look Heav'n,
Almeyda dooms her dear Sebatian's death!
But is there Heav'n, for I begin to doubt;
The Skyes are huh'd; no grumbling Thunders roul:
Now take your wing, ye impious; Sin unpunih'd;
Eternal providence eems overwatch'd,
And with a lumb'ring Nod aents to Murther.

div.stage: Enter Dorax attended by three Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Thou mov't a Tortoie pace to my relief.
Take hence that, once a King; that ullen pride
That wells to dumbnes; lay him in the Dungeon,
And ink him deep with Irons; that when he wou'd,
He hall not groan to hearing, when I end
The next Commands are death.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Then Prayers are vain as Cures.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Much at one
In a Slaves mouth, againt a Monarch's Pow'r.
This day thou hat to think;
At night, if thou wilt cure, thou halt cure kindly;
Then I'll provoke thy lips; lay iege o cloe,
That all thy allying breath hall turn to Bleings.
Make hate, eize, force her, bear her hence.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Farewel, my lat Sebatian!
I do not beg, I challenge Jutice now;
O Pow'rs, if Kings be your peculiar care,
Why plays this Wretch with your Prerogative?
Now flah him dead, now crumble him to ahes;
Or henceforth live confin'd in your own Palace;
And look not idely out upon a World
That is no longer yours.

div.stage: She is carried off trugling, Emperour and Benducar follow.
Sebatian truggles in his Guards Arms, and hakes off one of them, but two others come in, and hold him; he peaks not all the while.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I find I'm but a half-train'd Villain yet; Aide.
But mungril-michievous; for my Blood boyl'd,
To view this brutal act; and my tern Soul
Tug'd at my arm to draw in her defence.
Down thou rebelling Chritian in my heart;
Redeem thy fame on this Sebatian firt;
Then think on others wrongs, when thine are righted.
But how to right 'em? on a Slave diarm'd,
Defenceles, and ubmitted to my rage?
A bae revenge is vengeance on my elf? walks again.
I have it; and I thank thee, honet head,
Thus preent to me at my great neceity: —
You know me not?

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: I hear Men call thee Dorax.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis well, you know enough for once: you peak too;
You were truck mute before.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: Silence became me then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yet we may talk hereafter.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hereafter is not mine: —
Dipatch thy work, good Executioner.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: None of my blood were hangmen; add that falhood
To a long Bill that yet remains unreckon'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: A King and thou can never have a reck'ning.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A greater umm perhaps than you can pay.
Mean time I hall make bold t'increae your debt,
Take this, and ue it at your greatet need.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This hand and this, have been acquainted well;
It hou'd have come before into my grap,
To kill the Raviher.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou heardt the Tyrants orders; Guard thy life
When 'tis attack'd, and guard it like a Man.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I'm till without thy meaning but I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Thank me when I ask thanks; thank me with that.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Such urly kindnes did I never ee!

div.stage: (Dorax to the Captain of his Guards.)

sp.speaker: Muza,
sp.l: draw out a file, pick man by man,
Such who dare dye, and dear will ell their death.
Guard him to th' utmot; now conduct him hence,
And treat him as my Peron.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Something like
That voice methinks I hou'd have omewhere heard:
But floods of woes have hurry'd it far off;
Beyond my kenn of Soul.

div.stage: Exit Sebatian with the Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But I hall bring him back ungrateful Man, Solus.
I hall, and et him full before thy ight,
When I hall front thee, like ome taring Ghot,
With all my wrongs about me. — What o oon
Return'd? This hat is boding.

div.stage: Enter to him Emperor, Benducar, Mufti.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: She's till inexorable, till Imperious;
And loud, as if like Bacchus born in thunder.
Be quick, ye fale Phyicians of my mind,
Bring peedy Death or Cure.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: What can be counell'd while Sebatian lives?
The Vine will cling, while the tall poplar tands:
But that cut down creeps to the next upport,
And twines as cloely there.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: That's done with eae, I peak him dead: proceed.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Proclaim your Marriage with Almeyda next,
That Civil Wars may ceae; this gains the Crowd;
Then you may afely force her to your will:
For People ide with violence and injutice,
When done for publick good.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Preach thou that doctrine.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Th' unreaonable fool has broach'd a truth Aide.
That blats my hopes; but ince 'tis gone o far,
He hall divulge Almeyda is a Chritian:
If that produce no tumult I depair.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Why peaks not Dorax?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Becaue my Soul abhors to mix with him.
Sir, let me bluntly ay, you went too far
To trut the Preaching pow'r on State Affairs,
To him or any Heavenly Demagogue.
'Tis a limb lopt from your Prerogative,
And o much of Heav'ns Image blotted from you.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Sure thou hat never heard of Holy Men
(So Chritians call 'em) fam'd in State Affairs;
Such as in Spain Ximenes, Albornoz,
In England Wooley; match me thee with Laymen.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: How you triumph in one or two of thee,
Born to be Statemen, hap'ning to be Church-men:
Thou callt 'em holy; o their function was;
But tell me, Mufti, which of 'em were Saints?
Next, Sir, to you; the umm of all is this;
Since he claims pow'r from Heav'n, and not from Kings,
When 'tis his int'ret, he can int'ret Heav'n
To preach you down; and Ages oft depend
On hours, uninterrupted, in the Chair.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I'll trut his Preaching while I rule his pay.
And I dare trut my Affricans, to hear
Whatever he dare Preach.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You know 'em not.
The genius of your Moors is mutiny;
They carcely want a Guide to move their madnes:
Prompt to rebel on every weak pretence,
Blutring when courted, crouching when oppret.
Wie to themelves, and fools to all the World.
Retles in change, and perjur'd to a Proverb.
They love Religion weetn'd to the ene;
A good, luxurious, palatable faith.
Thus Vice and Godlines, prepot'rous pair,
Ride cheek by joul; but Churchmen hold the Reins.
And, when ere Kings wou'd lower Clergy greatnes,
They learn too late what pow'r the Preachers have,
And whoe the Subjects are; the Mufti knows it;
Nor dares deny what pas'd betwixt us two.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: No more; what ere he aid was by Command.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why then no more, ince you will hear no more;
Some Kings are reolute to their own ruin.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Without your medling where you are not ask'd,
Obey your Orders, and dipatch Sebatian.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Trut my revenge; be ure I wih him dead.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: What mean't thou! what's thy wihing to my will;
Dipatch him, rid me of the Man I loath,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I hear you Sir, I'll take my time and do't —

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Thy time? what's all thy time, what's thy whole life
To my one hour of eae? no more replies,
But ee thou do't it; Or —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Choak in that threat: I can ay Or, as loud.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I ee my words have no effect,
But I may end a Meage to dipoe you.

div.stage: Is going off.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Expect an anwer worthy of that Meage.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: The Prophet ow'd him this: Aide.
And thank'd be Heav'n, he has it.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: By Holy Alha, I conjure you tay,
And judge not rahly of o brave a Man.
sp.stage: (Draws the Emperor aide and whipers him.)
sp.l: I'll give you reaons why he cannot execute
Your Orders now, and why he will hereafter.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Benducar is a fool to bring him off, Aide.
I'll work my own revenge, and peedily.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: The Fort is his, the Soldiers hearts are his;
A thouand Chritian Slaves are in the Catle,
Which he can free to reinforce his pow'r;
Your Troops far off, beleaguering Larache,
Yet in the Chritians hands.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I grant all this;
But grant me he mut dye.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: He hall; by poyon:
'Tis here, the deadly drug prepar'd in powder,
Hot as Hell fire: — then, to prevent his Soldiers
From riing to revenge their Gen'rals death,
While he is truggling with his Mortal pangs,
The Rabble on the udden may be rais'd
to eize the Catle.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.p: Do't; 'tis left to thee.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Yet more; but clear your brow; for he oberves.

div.stage: (They whiper again.)

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What will the Fav'rite prop my falling fortunes,
O Prodigie of Court! Aide.

div.stage: Emperor and Benducar return to Dorax.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Your Friend has fully clear'd your Innocence;
I was too haty to condemn unheard,
And you perhaps too prompt in your replies.
As far as fits the Majety of Kings,
I ask excue.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'm ure I meant it well.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I know you did: — this to our love renew'd. —

div.stage: Emperor drinks.
Benducar fill to Dorax.
Benducar turns and mixes a powder in it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Let it go round for all of us have need
To quench our heats; 'tis the Kings health Benducar. —
And I wou'd pledge it though I knew 'twere poyon.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Another Bowl, for what the King has touch'd,
And you have pledg'd, is acred to your loves. —

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Since Charity becomes my calling, thus
Let me provoke your friendhip: and heav'n bles it
As I intend it well. —

div.stage: Drinks; and turning aide pours ome drops out of a little Vial into the Bowl; then preents it to Dorax.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Heav'n make thee honet,
On that condition we hall oon be friends. — Drinks.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Yes, at our meeting in another World; Aide.
For thou hat drunk thy pasport out of this.
Not the Nonacrian fount, nor Lethe's Lake,
Cou'd ooner numb thy nimble faculties
Than this, to leep eternal.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Now farewel Dorax; this was our firt quarrel,
And I dare propheie will prove our lat.

div.stage: Exit Emperor with Benducar and the Mufti.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It may be o: I'm trangely dicompos'd;
Quick hootings through my limbs, and pricking pains,
Qualms at my heart, Convulions in my nerves,
Shiv'rings of cold, and burnings of my entrails
Within my little World make medley War,
Loe and regain, beat and are beaten back;
As momentary Victors quit their ground.
Can it be poyon! poyon's of one tenour,
Or hot or cold; this neither, and yet both.
Some deadly Draught, ome enemy of life
Boils in my bowels, and works out my Soul.
Ingratitude's the growth of ev'ry Clime;
Affrick, the Scene remov'd, is Portugal.
Of all Court-ervice learn the common lot;
To day 'tis done, to morrow 'tis forgot.
Oh were that all! my honet Corps mut lye
Expos'd to corn, and publick Infamy:
My hameful Death will be divulg'd alone;
The worth and honour of my Soul unknown.

div.stage: Exit.

div.head: Scene 2. Is a Night Scene of the Mufti's Garden where an Arbour is dicover'd.
div.stage: Enter Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: SHE names her elf Morayma; the Mufti's only Daughter, and a Virgin! This is the time and place that he appointed in her letter, yet he comes not. Why thou weet delicious Creature, why to torture me with thy delay! dar't thou be fale to thy Aignation? What, in the cool and ilence of the night, and to a new Lover? Pox on the Hypocrite thy Father, for intructing thee o little in the weetet point of his Religion. Hark, I hear the rutling of her Silk Mantle. Now he comes; now he comes; no, hang't, that was but the whitling of the wind through the Orange Trees. Now again, I hear the pit a pat of a pretty foot through the dark Alley: No, 'tis the Son of a Mare that's broken looe and munching upon the Melons: — Oh the miery of an expecting Lover! Well I'll e'en depair, go into my Arbour, and try to leep; in a dream I hall enjoy her in depight of her. Goes into the Arbour and lyes down.

div.stage: Enter Johayma wrapt up in a Moorih Mantle.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Thus far my love has carry'd me, almot without my knowledg whither I was going: Shall I go on, hall I dicover my elf! — What an injury am I doing to my old Husband! — Yet what injury, ince he's old, and has three Wives and ix Concubines beides me! 'Tis but tealing my own Tythe from him.

div.stage: She comes a little nearer the Arbour.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.stage: raiing himelf a little and looking.
sp.p: At lat 'tis he: this is no illuion I am ure; 'tis a true Shedevil of Fleh and Blood; and he cou'd never have taken a fitter time to tempt me. —

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: He's young and handome. —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, well enough I thank nature. Aide.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: And I am yet neither old nor ugly: ure he will not refue me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, thou mayt pawn thy Maiden-head upon't he wonnot. Aide.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: The Mufti wou'd feat himelf upon other Women, and keep me fating.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, the holy Curmudgeon! Aide.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Wou'd Preach abtinence, and practice luxury! but I thank my Stars, I have edify'd more by his example than his precept.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Mot divinely argu'd; he's the bet Cauit in all Affrick. Aide.
sp.stage: He ruhes out and embraces her.
sp.p: I can hold no longer from embracing thee my dear Morayma: the old unconcionable Whoron thy Father, cou'd he expect cold chatity from a Child of his begetting?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: What nonene do you talk? do you take me for the Mufti's Daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why are you not Madam?

div.stage: throwing off her Barnus.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I find you had an appointment with Morayma.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: By all that's good, the naueous Wife. Aide.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: What you are confounded and tand mute?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Somewhat nonplut I confes; to hear you deny your name o poitively; why are not you Morayma the Mufti's Daughter? Did not I ee you with him, did not he preent me to you? Were you not o charitable as to give me Money? Ay and to tread upon my foot, and queeze my hand too, if I may be o bold to remember you of pat favours.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: And you ee I am come to make 'em good, but I am neither Morayma nor the Mufti's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, I know not that: but I am ure he is old enough to be your Father: and either Father, or Reverend Father, I heard you call him.

sp.speaker: Johayma,
sp.p: Once again, how came you to name Morayma?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Another damn'd mitake of mine: For, asking one of my fellow Slaves, who were the chief Ladies about the houe; he anwer'd me Morayma and Johayma; but he it eems is his Daughter, with a Pox to her, and you are his beloved Wife.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Say your beloved Mitris, if you pleae; for that's the Title I deire. This Moon-hine grows offenive to my Eyes, come, hall we walk into the Arbor? There we may rectifie all mitakes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's cloe and dark.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: And are thoe faults to Lovers?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But there I cannot pleae my elf, with the ight of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Perhaps you may do better.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But there's not a breath of air tirring.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: The breath of Lovers is the weetet air; but you are fearful.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am conidering, indeed, that if I am taken with you.—

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: The bet way to avoid it, is to retire, where we may not be dicover'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where lodges your Husband?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Jut againt the face of this open Walk.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then he has een us already, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: You make o many Difficulties, I fear I am dipleaing to you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: aide. If Morayma comes and takes me in the Arbor with her, I have made a fine exchange of that Diamond for this Pebble.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: You are much fall'n off, let me tell you, from the fury of your firt embrace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I confes, I was omewhat too furious at firt, but you will forgive the tranport of my paion; now I have conider'd it better, I have a qualm of Concience.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Of Concience! Why, what has Concience to do with two young Lovers that have opportunity?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why truly Concience is omething to blame for interpoing in our matters: But how can I help it, if I have a Scruple to betray my Mater?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: There mut be omething more in it; for your Concience was very quiet when you took me for Morayma.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I grant you, Madam, when I took you for his Daughter: For then I might have made you an honorable amends by Marriage.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: You Chritians are uch peeking Sinners, you tremble at a Shadow in the Moon-hine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you Affricans are uch Termagants, you top at nothing. I mut be plain with you, you are married, and to a Holy Man, the Head of your Religion: Go back to your Chamber, go back, I ay, and conider of it for this night; as I will do on my part: I will be true to you, and invent all the Arguments I can to comply with you; and who knows, but at our next meeting, the weet Devil may have more power over me: I am true fleh and blood, I can tell you that for your comfort.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Fleh without blood I think thou art; or if any, 'tis as cold as that of Fihes. But I'll teach thee, to thy cot, what Vengeance is in tore for refuing a Lady, who has offer'd thee her Love: —Help, Help, there; will no body come to my aitance?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What do you mean, Madam, for Heaven's ake peace; your Husband will hear you; think of your own danger, if you will not think of mine.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Ingrateful Wretch, thou deerv't no pity: Help, Help, Husband, or I hall be ravih'd: The Villain will be too trong for me. Help, help, for pity of a poor ditreed Creature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then I have nothing but impudence to ait me: I mut drown her clamor what e'er comes on't.

div.stage: He takes out his Flute, and plays as loud as he can poibly, and he continues crying out.
Enter the Mufti in his Night-gown, and two Servants.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p:
O thou Villain, what horrible impiety art thou committing? What ravihing the Wife of my Boom? Take him
away, ganch him, impale him, rid the World of uch a Monter.

div.stage: Servants eize him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mercy, dear Mater, Mercy: Hear me firt, and after, if I have deerved hanging, pare me not: What have you een to provoke you to this cruelty?

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: I have heard the out-crys of my Wife; the bleatings of the poor innocent Lamb: Seen nothing, ay't thou? If I ee the Lamb lye bleeding, and the Butcher by her with his Knife drawn and bloody, is not that evidence ufficient of the Murther? I come too late, and the Execution is already done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray think in reaon, Sir, is a Man to be put to death for a imilitude? No Violence has been committed; none intended: The Lamb's alive; and if I durt tell you o, no more a Lamb than I am a Butcher.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: How's that, Villain, dar't thou accue me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be patient Madam, and peak but truth, and I'll do any thing to erve you: I ay again, and wear it too, I'll do any thing to erve you.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: aide. I undertand him; but I fear, 'tis now too late to ave him:—Pray hear him peak, Husband; perhaps he may ay omething for himelf; I know not.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: Speak thou, has he not violated my Bed and thy Honor?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I forgive him freely; for he has done nothing: What he will do hereafter, to make me atisfaction, himelf bet knows.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Any thing, any thing, weet Madam: I hall refue no drudgery.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: But, did he mean no michief? Was he endeavouring nothing?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: In my Concience, I begin to doubt he did not.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: 'Tis impoible: Then what meant all thoe out-crys?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I heard Muick in the Garden, and at an uneaonable time of night; and I tole oftly out of my Bed, as imagining it might be he.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: How's that Johayma? Imagining it was he, and yet you went?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Why not, my Lord? Am not I the Mitris of the Family? And is it not my place to ee good Orders kept in it? I thought he might have allur'd ome of the Shee-laves to him; and was reolv'd to prevent what might have been betwixt him and them; when on the udden he ruh'd out upon me, caught me in his arms, with uch a fury.—

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: I have heard enough, away with him.—

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Mitaking me, no doubt, for one of his fellow Slaves: With that, affrighted as I was, I dicover'd my elf, and cry'd aloud: But as oon as ever he knew me, the Villain let me go, and I mut needs ay, he tarted back, as if I were ome Serpent; and was more afraid of me than I of him.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: O thou corrupter of my Family, that's caue enough of death; once again, away with him.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: What, for an intended Trepas? No harm has been done, whatever may be. He cot you five hundred Crowns I take it.—

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Thou ay't true, a very coniderable Sum: He hall not dye, tho he had committed folly with a Slave; 'tis too much to loe by him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My only fault has ever been to love playing in the dark, and the more he cry'd, the more I play'd; that it might be een I intended nothing to her.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: To your Kennel, Sirrah, mortifie your fleh, and conider in whoe Family you are.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: And one thing more; remember from henceforth to obey better.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: aide. For all her moothnes, I am not quite cur'd of my Jealouie; but I have thought of a way that will clear my doubts.

div.stage: Exit Mufti with Johayma and Servants.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I am mortify'd ufficiently already, without the help of his ghotly Counel. Fear of Death has gone farther with me in two Minutes, than my Concience wou'd have gone in two Months. I find my elf in a very dejected condition all over me; poor Sin lyes dormant, Concupicence is retir'd to his winter
quarters; and if Morayma hou'd now appear, I ay no more, but alas for her and me!

div.stage: (Morayma comes out of the Arbour; he teals behind him, and claps him on the back.)

sp.speaker: Morayma,
sp.p: And if Morayma hou'd appear, as he does appear, alas you ay for her and you!

sp.speaker: Antonio,
sp.p: Art thou there, my weet temptation! my Eyes, my Life, my Soul, my all!

sp.speaker: Morayma,
sp.p: A mighty Complement, when all thee, by your own Confeion, are jut nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nothing, till thou cam't to new create me; thou dot not know the power of thy own Charms: let me embrace thee, and thou halt ee how quickly I can turn wicked.

sp.speaker: Morayma
sp.p: tepping back. Nay, if you are o dangerous, 'tis bet keeping you at a ditance; I have no mind to warm a frozen Snake in my boom; he may chance to recover, and ting me for my pains.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Conider what I have uffer'd for thy ake already; and make me ome amends: two diappointments in a night, O cruel Creature!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And you may thank your elf for both: I came eagerly to the Charge, before my time, through the back walk behind the Arbour; and you, like a freh-water Soldier, tood guarding the Pas before: if you mis'd the Enemy, you may thank your own dulnes.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Nay, if you will be uing tratagems, you hall give me leave to make ue of my advantages, now I have you in my power: we are fairly met; I'll try it out, and give no quarter.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, we meet upon treaty now, and not upon defiance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If that be all, you hall have Carte blanche immediately; for I long to be ratifying.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
No, now I think on't, you are already enter'd into Articles with my Enemy Johayma: Any thing to erve you Madam; I hall refue no drudgery: whoe words were thoe
Gentleman? was that like a Cavalier of honour?

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.p: Not very heroick; but elf preervation is a point above Honour and Religion too — Antonio was a Rogue I mut confes; but you mut give me leave to love him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To beg your life o baely; and to preent your Sword to your Enemy; Oh Recreant!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I had died honourably, my fame indeed wou'd have ounded loud, but I hou'd never have heard the blat: Come, don't make your elf wore natur'd than you are: to ave my life, you wou'd be content I hou'd promie any thing.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, if I were ure you wou'd perform nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Can you upect I wou'd leave you for Johayma?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No; but I can expect you wou'd have both of us: Love is covetous, I mut have all of you; heart for heart is an equal truck. In hort, I am younger; I think handomer; and am ure I love you better, he has been my tep-mother thee fifteen years: you think that's her face you ee, but 'tis only a dawb'd Vizard: he wears an Armour of proof upon't: an inch thick of Paint, beides the Wah: her Face is o fortifi'd that you can make no approaches to it, without a Shovel. But for her contancy, I can tell you for your comfort, he will love till death, I mean till yours: for when he has worn you out, he will certainly dipatch you to another world, for fear of telling tales; as he has already erv'd three Slaves, your Predeceors of happy memory in her favours. She has made my pious Father a three pil'd Cuckold to my knowledg: and now he wou'd be robbing me of my ingle Sheep too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee prevent her then; and at leat take the hearing of me firt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No; I'll have a Butchers Pen'worth of you; firt ecure the Carcas, and then take the fleece into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why ure, you did not put your elf and me to all this trouble, for a dry come off: by this hand — (taking it:)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Which you hall never touch; but upon better aurances than you imagine. (Pulling her hand away.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll marry thee, and make a Chritian of thee thou pretty damn'd Infidel.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
I mean you hall: but no earnet, till the bargain be made before witnes: there's love enough to be had, and as much as
you can turn you to; never doubt it, but all upon honourable terms.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow and wear by Love; and he's a Deity in all Religions.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But never to be truted in any: he has another name too, of a wore ound. Shall I trut an Oath, when I ee your Eyes languihing, your Cheeks fluhing, and can hear your heart throbbing? no, I'll not come near you: He's a foolih Phyitian who will feel the pule of a Patient, that has the Plague-pots upon him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Did one ever hear a little Moppet, argue o perverly againt o good a Caue! Come, prithee, let me anticipate a little of my Revenue.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You wou'd feign be fingring your Rents before-hand; but that makes a man an ill Husband ever after. Conider, Marriage is a painful Vocation, as you hall prove it, manage your Incomes as thriftily as you can, you hall find a hard task on't, to make even at the years end, and yet to live decently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I came with a Chritian intention, to revenge my elf upon thy Father; for being the head of a fale Religion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And o you hall; I offer you his Daughter for your Second: but ince you are o preing, meet me under my Window, to morrow night, body for body, about this hour; I'll lip down out of my Lodging, and bring my Father in my hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How, thy Father!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I mean all that's good of him; his Pearls, and Jewels, his whole contents, his heart, and Soul; as much as ever I can carry. I'll leave him his Alchoran; that's revenue enough for him: every page of it is Gold and Diamonds. He has the turn of an Eye, a demure Smile, and a godly Cant, that are worth Millions to him. I forgot to tell you, that I will have a Slave prepar'd at the Potern gate, with two Hores ready adled: no more, for I fear, I may be mis'd; and think I hear 'em calling me, — if you have contancy and Courage. —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Never doubt it: and love, in abundance to wander with thee all the World over.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The value of twelve hundred thouand Crowns in a Caket!—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A heavy burden Heaven knows! but we mut pray for patience to upport it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Beides a willing Titt that will venture her Corps with you:— Come, I know you long to have a parting blow with me; and therefore to hew I am in Charity — (He kies her.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Once more, for pity; that I may keep the flavour upon my lips till we meet again.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No; frequent Charities make bold Beggars: and beides I have learnt of a Falconer, never to feed up a Hawk when I wou'd have him fly: that's enough — but if you will be nibling, here's a hand to tay your tomach. (Kiing her hand.)

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Thus Conquer'd Infidels, that Wars may ceae,
Are forc'd to give their hands, and ign the Peace.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Thus Chritians are outwitted by the Foe;
You had her in your Pow'r, and let her go.
If you releae my hand, the fault's not mine,
You hou'd have made me eal, as well as ign.

div.stage: She runs off, he follows her to the door; then comes back again, and goes out at the other.

div.head: Scene 1. Benducar's Pallace in the Catle of Alcazar.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: MY future Fate, the colour of my life, Solus.
My all depends on this important hour:
This hour my Lott is weighing in the Scales,
And Heav'n, perhaps, is doubting what to do.
Almeyda and a Crown, have puh'd me forward;
'Tis fix'd, the Tyrant mut not ravih her:
He and Sebatian tand betwixt my hopes;
He mot; and therefore firt to be dipatch'd.
Thee and a thouand things are to be done
In the hort compas of this rowling Night,
And nothing yet perform'd,
None of my Emiaries yet return'd.
Oh Haly, thou hat held me long in pain.
What hat thou learnt of Dorax? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Haly,
sp.l: Two hours I warily have watch'd his Palace;
All doors are hut, no Servant peeps abroad;
Some Officers with triding hat pas'd in,
While others outward went on quick dipatch;
Sometimes huh'd ilence eem'd to reign within;
Then Cries confus'd, and a joint clamour follow'd;
Then Lights went gliding by, from room to room,
And hot like thwarting Meteors cros the houe:
Not daring farther to enquire: I came
With peed, to bring you this imperfect news.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Hence I conclude him either dead or dying:
His mournful Friends, ummon'd to take their leaves,
Are throng'd about his Couch, and it in Council,
What thoe Caballing Captains may deign,
I mut prevent,
By being firt in Action.
To Muley Zeydan fly with peed, deire him
To take my lat intructions; tell th' importance

And hat his preence here.
Exit Haly.
How has this Poion lot its wonted way?
It hou'd have burnt its paage, not have linger'd
In the blind Labyrinths and crooked turnings
Of human Compoition; now it moves
Like a low Fire that works againt the Wind,
As if his tronger Stars had interpos'd.
Well Hamet, are our Friends the Rabble rais'd?
From Mutafa, what Meage?

sp.speaker: Hamet,
sp.l: What you wih:
The treets are thicker in this noon of Night:
Than at the Mid-day Sun: a drowzy horrour
Sits on their Eyes, like fear not well awake,
All crowd in heaps, as at a Night Alarm
The Bees drive out upon each others backs,
T' imbos their Hives in cluters; all ask news:
Their buie Captain runs the weary round
To whiper Orders; and commanding ilence
Makes not noie ceae; but deafens it to murmurs.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Night wats apace: when, when will he appear?

sp.speaker: Hamet,
sp.p: He only waits your Summons.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Hat their coming.
Let ecrecy and ilence be enjoin'd
In their cloe march: what news from the Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Hamet,
sp.l: I left him at the Gate, firm to your Interet,
T' admit the Townmen at their firt appearance.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Thus far 'tis well: go haten Mutafa.
O, Orchan, did I think thy diligence
Wou'd lag behind the ret? what from the Mufti?

sp.speaker: Orchan,
sp.l: I ought him round his Palace; made enquiry
Of all the Slaves: in hort, I us'd your name
And urg'd th' importance home; but had for anwer
That ince the hut of Evening none had een him.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: O the curt fate of all Conpiracies!
They move on many Springs, if one but fail
The retiff Machine tops. — In an ill hour he's abent;
'Tis the firt time, and ure will be the lat
That e'er a Mufti was not in the way,
When Tumult and Rebellion hou'd be broach'd.
Stay by me; thou art reolute and faithful;
I have Employment worthy of thy Arm. Walks.

div.stage: Enter Muley Zeydan.

sp.speaker: Muley Zeyd.
sp.l: You ee me come impatient of my hopes,
And eager as the Courer for the Race:
Is all in readines?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: All but the Mufti.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.p: We mut go on without him.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: True we mut;
For 'tis ill topping in the full Career,
How e'er the leap be dangerous and wide.

sp.speaker: Orchan
sp.l: I ee the blaze of Torches from afar;
And hear the trampling of thick beating feet;
This way they move.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: No doubt the Emperour.
We mut not be urpriz'd in Conference.
Trut to my management the Tyrants death;
And hat your elf to join with Mutafa.
The Officer who guards the Gate is yours;
When you have gain'd that Pas, divide your Force;
Your elf in Peron head one choen half,
And march t' oppres the Faction in Conult
With dying Dorax: Fate has driv'n 'em all
Into the Net: you mut be bold and udden:
Spare none, and if you find him trugling yet
With pangs of Death, trut not his rowling Eyes
And heaving gaps; for Poion may be fale,
The home-thrut of a friendly Sword is ure.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.l: Doubt not my Conduct: they hall be urpriz'd;
Mercy may wait without the Gate one Night,
At Morn I'll take her in.—

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Here lies your way,
You meet your Brother there.

sp.speaker: Mul. Zeyd.
sp.l: May we ne'er meet:
For, like the Twins of Leda, when I mount
He gallops down the Skies.—

div.stage: Exit Muley Zeyd.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: He comes: now Heart
Be rib'd with Iron for this one attempt:
Set ope thy Sluces, end the vigorous bloud
Through every active Limb for my relief:
Then, take thy ret within thy quiet Cell,
For thou halt drum no more.

div.stage: Enter Muley Moluch and Guards attending him.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: What news of our Affairs, and what of Dorax?
Is he no more? ay that, and make me happy.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: May all your Enemies be like that Dog,
Whoe parting Soul is lab'ring at the Lips.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.p: The People, are they rais'd?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: And Marhall'd too;
Jut ready for the March.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.p: Then I'm at eae.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: The Night is yours, the glitt'ring Hoat of Heav'n
Shines but for you; but mot the Star of Love,
That twinckles you to fair Almeyda's Bed.
Oh there's a joy, to melt in her embrace,
Diolve in pleaures;
And make the gods cure Immortality,
That o they cou'd not dye.
But hate, and make 'em yours.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: I will; and yet
A kind of weight hangs heavy at my Heart;
My flagging Soul flyes under her own pitch;
Like Fowl in air too damp, and lugs along,
As if he were a body in a body,
And not a mounting ubtance made of Fire.
My Senes too are dull and tupifi'd,
Their edge rebated; ure ome ill approaches,
And ome kind Spirit knocks oftly at my Soul,
To tell me Fate's at hand.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Mere Fancies all.
Your Soul has been beforehand with your Body,
And drunk o deep a Draught of promis'd blis,
She lumbers o'er the Cup; no danger's near,
But of a Surfeit at too full a Feat.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: It may be o; it looks o like the Dream
That overtook me at my waking hour
This Morn; and Dreams they ay are then divine,
When all the balmy Vapors are exhal'd,
And ome o'er-pow'ring God continues leep.
'Twas then methought Almeyda, miling, came
Attended with a Train of all her Race,
Whom in the rage of Empire I had murther'd.
But now, no longer Foes, they gave me Joy
Of my new Conquet, and with helping hands
Heav'd me into our Holy Prophet's arms,
Who bore me in a purple Cloud to Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Good Omen, Sir, I wih you in that Heaven
Your Dream portends you.
Which preages death.— Aide.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: Thou too wert there;
And thou methought didt puh me from below,
With thy full force to Paradie.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Yet better.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.p: Ha! What's that grizly Fellow that attends thee?

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: Why ask you Sir?

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: For he was in my Dream;
And help'd to heave me up.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: With Pray'rs and Wihes;
For I dare wear him honet.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: That may be;
But yet he looks Damnation.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: You forget,
The Face wou'd pleae you better: Do you love,
And can you thus forbear?

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: I'll head my People;
Then think of dalliance, when the danger's o'er.
My warlike Spirits work now another way;
And my Soul's tun'd to Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: You debae your elf,
To think of mixing with th' ignoble Herd.
Let uch perform the fervile Work of War,
Such who have no Almeyda to enjoy.
What hall the People know their God-like Prince
Skulk'd in a nightly Skirmih? Stole a Conquet,
Headed a Rabble, and profan'd his Peron,
Shoulder'd with Filth, born in a tide of Ordure,
And tifled with their rank offenive Sweat?

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: I am off again: I will not protitute
The Regal Dignity o far, to head 'em.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: There poke a King.
Dimis your Guards to be employ'd elewhere
In ruder Combats: You will want no Seconds
In thoe Alarms you eek.

sp.speaker: Mul. Mol.
sp.l: Go joyn the Crowd; to the Guards.
Benducar; thou halt lead 'em, in my place. Exeunt Guards.
The God of Love once more has hot his Fires
Into my Soul; and my whole Heart receives him.
Almeyda now returns with all her Charms;
I feel her as he glides along my Veins,
And dances in my Blood: So when our Prophet
Had long been ham'ring in his lonely Cell,
Some dull, inipid, tedious Paradie,
A brisk Arabian Girl came tripping by;
Paing he cat at him a ide-long glance,
And look'd behind in hopes to be puru'd:
He took the hint, embrac'd the flying Fair;

And having found his Heav'n, he fix'd it there.
Exit Mul. Mol.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: That Paradie thou never halt poes.
His death is eaie now, his Guards are gone;
And I can in but once to eize the Throne.
All after Acts are anctify'd by pow'r.

sp.speaker: Orchan.
sp.p: Command my Sword and Life.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: I thank thee Orchan,
And hall reward thy Faith: This Mater Key
Frees every Lock, and leads us to his Peron:
And hou'd we mis our blow, as Heav'n forbid,
Secures retreat: Leave open all behind us;
And firt et wide the Mufti's Garden Gate,
Which is his private paage to the Palace.
For there our Mutineers appoint to meet,
And thence we may have aid. Now leep ye Stars
That ilently o'erwatch the fate of Kings;
Be all propitious Influences barr'd,
And none but murd'rous Planets mount the Guard.

div.stage: Exit with Orcha·

div.head: A Night Scene of the Mufti's Garden.
div.stage: Enter the Mufti alone, in a Slave's habit, like that of Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p:
This 'tis to have a ound Head-piece; by this I h ••• got to be chief of my Religion; that is, honetly peaking <> teach others what I neither know nor believe my elf. F ••
what's Mahomet to me, but that I get by him? Now for my Policy of this night: I have mew'd up my upected Spoue in her Chamber. No more Embaies to that luty young Stallion of a Gardiner. Next my habit of a Slave; I have made my elf as like him as I can, all but his youth and vigor; which when I had, I pas'd my time as well as any of my Holy Predeceors. Now walking under the Windows of my Seraglio, if Johayma look out, he will certainly take me for Antonio, and call to me; and by that I hall know what Concupicence is working in her; he cannot come down to commit Iniquity, there's my afety; but if he peep, if he put her Noe abroad, there's demontration of her pious Will: And I'll not make the firt precedent for a Church-man to forgive Injuries.

div.stage: Enter Morayma running to him with a Casket in her hand, and embracing him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Now I can embrace you with a good Concience; here are the Pearls and Jewels, here's my Father.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: I am indeed thy Father; but how the Devil didt thou know me in this diguie? And what Pearls and Jewels dot thou mean?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: going back,— What have I done, and what will now become of me!

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Art thou mad, Morayma?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I think you'll make me o.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Why, what have I done to thee? Recollect thy elf, and peak ene to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then give me leave to tell you, you are the wort of Fathers.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Did I think I had begotten uch a Monter? Proceed my dutiful Child, proceed, proceed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You have been raking together a mas of Wealth, by indirect and wicked means; the Spoils of Orphans are in thee Jewels, and the Tears of Widows in thee Pearls.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Thou amazet me!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I wou'd do o. This Casket is loaded with your Sins; 'tis the Cargo of Rapines, Simony, and Extortions; the Iniquity of thirty Years Muftihip, converted into Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Wou'd ome rich rayling Rogue would ay as much to me, that I might queeze his Pure for candal.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No Sir, you get more by pious Fools than Raylers, when you ininuate into their Families, manage their Fortunes while they live, and beggar their Heirs by getting Legacies when they dye. And do you think I'll be the receiver of your Theft? I dicharge my Concience of it: Here take again your filthy Mammon, and retore it you had bet to the true Owners.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: I am finely documented by my own Daughter.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And a great credit for me to be o: Do but think how decent a Habit you have on, and how becoming your Function to be diguis'd like a Slave, and eyes-dropping under the Womens Windows, to be aluted, as you deerve it richly, with a Pis-pot: If I had not known you caually by your hambling gate, and a certain reverend awkardnes that is natural to all of your Function, here you had been expos'd to the laughter of your own Servants; who have been in earch of you through your whole Seraglio, peeping under every Petticoat to find you.

sp.speaker: Muf.
