sp.p: Prithee Child reproach me no more of human Failings; they are but a little of the pitch and pots of the World that are till ticking on me; but I hope to cour 'em out in time: I am better at bottom than thou think't; I am not the Man thou tak't me for.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, to my orrow Sir you are not.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: It was a very odd beginning, tho methought, to ee thee come running in upon me with uch a warm embrace; prithee what was the meaning of that violent hot Hug?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am ure I meant nothing by it, but the zeal and affection which I bear to the Man of the World, whom I may love lawfully.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: But thou wilt not teach me at this age the nature of a cloe Embrace?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No indeed; for my Mother in Law complains, that you are pat teaching: But if you mitook my innocent Embrace for Sin, I wih heartily it had been given where it wou'd have been more acceptable.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Why, this is as it hou'd be now: Take the Treaure again, it can never be put into better hands.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, to my knowledg but it might. I have confes'd my Soul to you, if you can undertand me rightly; I never diobey'd you till this night, and now ince through the violence of my Paion, I have been o unfortunate, I humbly beg your pardon, your bleing, and your leave, that upon the firt opportunity, I may go for ever from your ight; for Heaven knows, I never deire to ee you more.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Wiping his Eyes. Thou mak't me weep at thy unkindnes; indeed dear Daughter we will not part.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed dear Daddy but we will.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Why if I have been a little pilfering, or o, I take it bitterly of thee to tell me of it; ince it was to make thee rich; and I hope a Man may make bold with his own Soul, without offence to his own Child: Here take the jewels again, take'em I charge thee upon thy Obedience.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well then, in vertue of Obedience I will take 'em; but on my Soul, I had rather they were in a better hand.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Meaning mine, I know it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Meaning his whom I love better than my life.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: That's me again.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I wou'd have you think o.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: How thy good nature works upon me; well I can do no les than venture damning for thee, and I may put fair for it, if the Rabble be order'd to rie to Night.

div.stage: Enter Antonio in an Affrican rich habit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What do you mean my Dear, to tand talking in this upicious place, jut underneath Johayma's Window? (to the Mufti) You are well met Comerade, I know you are the friend of our flight? are the hores ready at the potern gate?

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Antonio, and in diguie! now I begin to mell a rat.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I another, that out-tinks it; fale Morayma, hat thou thus betray'd me to thy Father!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Alas, I was betray'd my elf: He came diguis'd like you, and I poor Innocent ran into his hands.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: In good time you did o; I laid a trap for a Bitch Fox, and a wore Vermine has caught himelf in it: you wou'd fain break looe now, though you left a limb behind you; but I am yet in my own Territories and in call of Company, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Antonio,
sp.p: No; I have a trick left to put thee pat thy queeking: I have giv'n thee the quinzey; that ungracious tongue hall Preach no more fale Doctrin.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What do you mean? you will not throttle him? conider he's my Father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee let us provide firt for our own afety; if I do not conider him, he will conider us with a vengeance afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You may threaten him for crying out, but for my ake give him back a little cranny of his Wind-pipe, and ome part of Speech.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not o much as one ingle Interjection: Come away Father-in-Law, this is no place for Dialogues, when you are in the Moque you talk by hours, and there no Man mut interrupt you; this is but like for like, good Father-in-Law; now I am in the Pulpit 'tis your turn to hold your tongue.
Nay if you will be hanging back, I hall take care you hall hang forward.

div.stage: (Pulls him along the Stage; with his Sword at his reins.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: T'other way to the Arbour with him; and make hat before we are dicover'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I only bind and gag him there, he may commend me hereafter for civil uage; he deerves not o much favour by any action of his life.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, pray bate him one, for begetting your Mitres.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I wou'd, if he had not thought more of thy Mother than of thee; once more come along in ilence, my Pythagorean Father-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: At the Balcony. — A Bird in a Cage may peep at leat; though he mut not fly; what butle's there beneath my Window? Antonio by all my hopes, I know him by his habit; but what makes that Woman with him, and a Friend, a Sword drawn, and hating hence? this is no time for ilence: Who's within, call there, where are the Servants, why Omar, Abedin, Haan and the ret, make hat and run into the Garden; there are Thieves and Villains; arm all the Family, and top 'em.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.p: O that Schriech Owl at the Window! we hall be puru'd immediatly; which way hall we take?

sp.speaker: Morayma
sp.p: 'Tis impoible to ecape them; for the way to our Hores lyes back again by the Houe; and then we hall meet 'em full in the teeth; here take thee Jewels; thou may't leap the Walls and get away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And what will become of thee then poor kind Soul?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I mut take my fortune; when you are got afe into your own Country, I hope you will betow a igh on the memory of her who lov'd you!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It makes me mad, to think how many a good night will be lot betwixt us! take back thy Jewels; 'tis an empty Casket without thee; beides I hou'd never leap well with the weight of all thy Fathers ins about me, thou and they had been a bargain.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Prithee take 'em, 'twill help me to be reveng'd on him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No; they'll erve to make thy peace with him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I hear 'em coming; hift for your elf at leat; remember I am yours for ever.

div.stage: (Servants crying this way, this way, behind the Scenes.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I but the empty hadow of my elf without thee! farewel Father-in-Law, that hou'd have been, if I had not been curt in my Mothers belly — Now which way fortune. —

div.stage: (Runs amazedly backwards and forwards.)
Servants within. Follow, follow, yonder are the Villains.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O here's a gate open; but it leads into the Catle; yet I mut venture it. Going out.

div.stage: (A hout behind the Scenes where Antonio is going out)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There's the Rabble in a Mutiny; what is the Devil up at Midnight! — however 'tis good herding in a Crowd.

div.stage: Runs out.
(Mufti runs to Morayma and lays hold on her, then natches away the Casket.)

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Now, to do things in order, firt I eize upon the Bag, and then upon the Baggage: for thou art but my fleh and blood, but thee are my Life and Soul.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then let me follow my fleh and blood, and keep to your elf your Life and Soul.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Both or none; come away to durance.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, if it mut be o, agreed; for I have another trick to play you; and thank your elf for what hall follow.

div.stage: Enter Servants.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: From above. One of them took through the private way into the Catle; follow him be ure, for thee are yours already.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Help here quickly Omar Abedin; I have hold on the Villain that tole my jewels; but 'tis a luty Rogue, and he will prove too trong for me; what, help I ay, do you not know your Maters Daughter?

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Now if I cry out they will know my voice; and then I am digrac'd for ever: O thou art a venomous Cockatrice!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Of your own begetting. The Servants eize him.

sp.speaker: Firt Servant.
sp.p: What a glorious deliverance have you had Madam from this bloody-minded Chritian!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Give me back my Jewels, and carry this notorious Malefactor to be punih'd by my Father.
I'll hunt the other dry-foot. (Takes the Jewels and runs out after Antonio at the ame Paage.)

sp.speaker: Firt Servant.
sp.p: I long to be handelling his hide, before we bring him to my Mater.

sp.speaker: Second Servant.
sp.p: Hang him, for an old Covetous Hypocrite: he deerves a wore punihment himelf for keeping us o hardly.

sp.speaker: Firt Servant.
sp.p: Ay, wou'd he were in this Villains place; thus I wou'd lay him on, and thus.

div.stage: Beats him.

sp.speaker: Second Servant.
sp.p: And thus wou'd I revenge my elf of my lat beating,

div.stage: (He beats him too, and then the ret.)

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Firt Servant.
sp.l: Now uppoing you were the Mufti, Sir, —

div.stage: Beats him again.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: The Devil's in that uppoing Racal; I can bear no more; and I am the Mufti: Now uppoe your elves my Servants, and hold your hands; an anointed halter take you all.

sp.speaker: Firt Servant.
sp.p: My Mater! you will pardon the exces of our zeal for you, Sir, indeed we all took you for a Villain, and o we us'd you.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Ay o I feel you did; my back and ides are abundant tetimonies of your zeal. Run Rogues, and bring me back my Jewels, and my Fugitive Daughter: run I ay.

div.stage: (They run to the Gate and the firt Servant runs back again.)

sp.speaker: Firt Servant.
sp.p: Sir, the Catle is in a mot terrible combution; you may hear 'em hither.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: 'Tis a laudable commotion: The voice of the Mobile is the voice of Heaven. I mut retire a little, to trip me of the Slave, and to aume the Mufti; and then I will return: for the piety of the People mut be encouraged; that they may help me to recover my Jewels, and my Daughter.

div.stage: Exit Mufti and Servants.
Scene changes to the Catle-yard, and dicovers Antonio Mutafa, and the Rabble houting, they come forward.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And o at length, as I inform'd you, I ecap'd out of his covetous clutches; and now fly to your illutrious feet for my protection.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Thou halt have it, and now defie the Mufti. 'Tis the firt Petition that has been made to me ince my exaltation to Tumult; in this econd Night of the Month Abib, and in the year of the Hegyra; the Lord knows what year; but 'tis no matter; for when I am ettled, the Learned are bound to find it out for me: for I am reolv'd to date my Authority over the Rabble, like other Monarchs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have always had a longing to be yours again; though I cou'd not compas it before, and had deign'd you a Casket of my Maters jewels too; for I knew the Cutom, and wou'd not have appear'd before a Great Peron, as you are, without a preent: But he has defrauded my good intentions, and baely robb'd you of 'em, 'tis a prize worth a Million of Crowns, and you carry your Letters of mark about you.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p:
I hall make bold with his Treaure, for the upport of my New Government. The People gather about him. What do thee vile Ragga-muffins o near our Peron? your avour is offenive to us; bear back there, and make room for honet Men to approach us; thee fools and knaves are always impudently
crowding next to Princes, and keeping off the more deerving, bear back I ay.

That's dutifully done; now hout to how your Loyalty. (A great hout.) Hear't thou that, Slave Antonio? thee obtreperous Villains hout, and know not for what they make a noie. You hall ee me manage 'em, that you may judge what ignorant Beats they are. For whom do you hout now? who's to Live and Reign? tell me that the wiet of you.

sp.speaker: Firt Rabble.
sp.p: Even who you pleae Captain.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: La you there; I told you o.

sp.speaker: Second Rabble.
sp.p: We are not bound to know who is to Live and Reign; our buines is only to rie upon command, and plunder.

sp.speaker: Third Rabble.
sp.p: Ay, the Richet of both Parties; for they are our Enemies.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: This lat Fellow is a little more enible than the ret; he has enter'd omewhat into the merits of the Caue.

sp.speaker: Firt Rabble.
sp.p: If a poor Man may peak his mind, I think, Captain, that your elf are the fittet to Live and Reign, I mean not over, but next and immediatly under the People; and thereupon I ay, A Mutafa, A Mutafa.

sp.speaker: (All Cry)
sp.p: A Mutafa, A Mutafa.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I mut confes the ound is pleaing, and tickles the ears of my Ambition; but alas good People, it mut not be: I am contented to be a poor imple Vice-Roy; but Prince Muley-Zeydan is to be the Man: I hall take care to intruct him in the arts of Government; and in his duty to us all: and therefore mark my Cry: A Muley-Zeydan, A Muley-Zeydan.

sp.speaker: (All Cry)
sp.p: A Muley-Zeydan, A Muley-Zeydan.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: You ee Slave Antonio, what I might have been.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: I oberve your Modety.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: But for a foolih promie I made once to my Lord Benducar, to et up any one he pleas'd.

div.stage: (Re-enter the Mufti with his Servants.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here's the Old Hypocrite again; now tand your ground, and bate him not an inch. Remember the Jewels, the Rich and Glorious Jewels; they are detin'd to be yours, by virtue of Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Let me alone to pick a quarrel, I have an old grudge to him upon thy account.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: Good People, here you are met together.

sp.speaker: Firt Rabble.
sp.p: Ay, we know that without your telling, but why are we met together, Doctor? for that's it which no body here can tell.

sp.speaker: Second Rabble.
sp.p: Why to ee one another in the Dark; and to make Holy-day at Midnight.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: You are met, as becomes good Muulmen; to ettle the Nation; for I mut tell you, that though your Tyrant is a lawful Emperor, yet your lawful Emperor is but a Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What tuff he talks!

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: 'Tis excellent fine matter indeed, Slave Antonio; he has a rare tongue; Oh, he wou'd move a Rock of Elephant!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Aide. What a Block have I to work upon, To him.
But till remember the Jewels, Sir, the Jewels.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Nay that's true on t'other ide: the Jewels mut be mine; but he has a pure fine way of talking; my Concience goes along with him, but the Jewels have et my heart againt him.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: That your Emperor is a Tyrant is mot manifet; for you were born to be Turks, but he has play'd the Turk with you; and is taking your Religion away.

sp.speaker: Second Rabble.
sp.p: We find that in our decay of Trade; I have een for thee hunder'd years, that Religion and Trade always go together.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: He is now upon the point of Marrying himelf, without your Sovereign conent; and what are the effects of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Third Rabble.
sp.p: A coulding, domineering Wife, if he prove honet; and if a Whore, a fine gawdy Minx, that robs our Counters every Night, and then goes out, and pends it upon our Cuckold-makers.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: No, the natural effects of Marriage are Children: Now on whom wou'd he beget thee Children? Even upon a Chritian! Oh horrible; how can you believe me, though I am ready to wear it upon the Alcoran! Yes, true Believers, you may believe me, that he is going to beget a Race of Misbelievers.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: That's fine, in earnet; I cannot forbear hearkening to his enchanting Tongue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But yet remember.—

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, the Jewels! Now again I hate him; but yet my Concience makes me liten to him.

sp.speaker: Mufti,
sp.p: Therefore to conclude all, Believers, pluck up your Hearts, and pluck down the Tyrant: Remember the Courage of your Ancetors; remember the Majety of the People; remember your elves, your Wives and Children; and latly, above all, remember your Religion, and our holy Mahomet; all thee require your timous aitance; hall I ay they beg it? No, they claim it of you, by all the nearet and dearet Tyes of thee three P's Self-Preervation, our Property, and our Prophet. Now anwer me with an unanimous chearful Cry, and follow me, who am your Leader to a glorious Deliverance.

div.stage: (All cry, A Mufti, A Mufti, and are following him off the Stage.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now you ee what comes of your foolih Qualms of Concience: The Jewels are lot, and they are all leaving you.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: What am I foraken of my Subjects? Wou'd the Rogue purloin my liege People from me! I charge you in my own Name come back ye Deerters; and hear me peak.

sp.speaker: 1t. Rabble,
sp.p: What will he come with his Balderdah, after the Mufti's eloquent Oration?

sp.speaker: 2d. Rabble,
sp.p: He's our Captain, lawfully pick'd up, and elected upon a Stall; we will hear him.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Speak Captain, for we will hear you.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Do you remember the glorious Rapines and Robberies you have committed? Your breaking open and gutting of Houes, your rummaging of Cellars, your demolihing of Chritian Temples, and bearing off in triumph the upertitious Plate and Pictures, the Ornaments of their wicked Altars, when all rich Moveables were entenc'd for idolatrous, and all that was idolatrous was eiz'd? Anwer firt for your remembrance, of all thee weetnees of Mutiny; for upon thoe Grounds I hall proceed.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Yes we do remember, we do remember.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Then make much of your retentive Faculties. And who led you to thoe Hony-Combs? Your Mufti? No, Believers, he only preach'd you up to it; but durt not lead you; he was but your Counellor, but I was your Captain; he only lood you, but 'twas I that led you.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: That's true, that's true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There you were with him for his Figures.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I think I was, Slave Antonio. Alas I was ignorant of my own Talent.—Say then, Believers, will you have a Captain for your Mufti? Or a Mufti for your Captain? And further to intruct you how to Cry, Will you have a Mufti, or no Mufti?

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: No Mufti, no Mufti.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: That I laid in for'em, Slave Antonio.—
sp.p: Do I then pet upon your Faces? Do I dicourage Rebellion, Mutiny, Rapine, and Plundering? You may think I do, Believers, but Heaven forbid: No, I encourage you to all thee laudable Undertakings; you hall plunder, you hall pull down the Government; but you hall do this upon my Authority, and not by his wicked Intigation.

sp.speaker: 3d. Rabble,
sp.p: Nay, when his turn is erv'd, he may preach up Loyalty again, and Retitution, that he might have another Snack among us.

sp.speaker: 1t. Rabble,
sp.p:
He may indeed; for 'tis but his aying 'tis Sin, and then we mut retore; and therefore I wou'd have a new Religion,
where half the Commandments hou'd be taken away, the ret mollifi'd and there hou'd be little or no Sin remaining.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Another Religion, a new Religion, another Religion.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: And that may eaily be done, with the help of a little Inpiration: For I mut tell you, I have a Pigeon at home, of Mahomet's own breed; and when I have learnt her to pick Peae out of my Ear, ret atisfi'd 'till then, and you hall have another. But now I think on't, I am inpir'd already, that 'tis no Sin to depoe the Mufti.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And good reaon; for when Kings and Queens are to be dicarded, what hou'd Knaves do any longer in the pack?

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: He is depos'd, he is depos'd, he is depos'd.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Nay, if he and his Clergy will needs be preaching up Rebellion, and giving us their Bleing, 'tis but jutice they hou'd have the firt fruits of it.—Slave Antonio, take him into cutody; and dot thou hear, Boy, be ure to ecure the little tranitory Box of Jewels: If he be obtinate, put a civil Quetion to him upon the Rack, and he queaks I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: eizing the Mufti. Come my quondam Mater, you and I mut change Qualities.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: I hope you will not be o barbarous to torture me, we may preach Suffering to others, but alas, holy Fleh is too well pamper'd to endure Martyrdom.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Now, late Mufti, not forgetting my firt Quarrel to you, we will enter our elves with the Plunder of your Palace: 'tis good to anctifie a Work and begin a God's name.

sp.speaker: 1t. Rabble,
sp.p: Our Prophet let the Devil alone with the lat Mob.

sp.speaker: Mob.
sp.p: But he takes care of this himelf.
sp.stage: As they are going out enter Benducar leading Almeyda: He with a Sword in one hand; Benducar's Slave follows with Muly-Moluch's Head upon a Spear.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Not o much hat Maters; come back again: you are o bent upon michief, that you take a man upon the firt word of Plunder. Here's a ight for you: the Emperour is come upon his head to viit you. [Bowing] Mot Noble Emperour, now I hope you will not hit us in the teeth, that we have pull'd you down, for we can tell you to your face, that we have exalted you.

div.stage: [They all hout.]

sp.speaker: Benducar
sp.l: Think what I am, and what your elf may be,
In being mine: refue not proffer'd Love that brings a Crown.

sp.speaker: Almeyda
sp.l: I have reolv'd,
And thee hall know my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: On that I build.—
Joy to the People for the Tyrants Death!
Oppreion, Rapine, Banihment and Bloud
Are now no more; but peechles as that tongue
That lyes for ever till.
How is my grief divided with my joy,
When I mut own I kill'd him! bid me peak,
For not to bid me, is to diallow
What for your akes is done.

sp.speaker: Mutafa.
sp.p: In the name of the People we command you peak: But that pretty Lady hall peak firt; for we have taken omewhat of a likeing to her Peron, be not afraid Lady to peak to thee rude Ragga-muffians: there's nothing hall offend you, unles it be their tink, and pleae you. Making a Legg.

sp.speaker: Almeyda.
sp.l: Why hou'd I fear to peak who am your Queen?
My peacefull Father way'd the Scepter long;
And you enjoy'd the Bleings of his Reign,
While you deerv'd the name of Affricans.
Then not commanded, but commanding you,
Fearles I peak: know me for what I am.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.p: How he aumes! I like not this beginning. aide

sp.speaker: Almeyda.
sp.l: I was not born o bae, to flatter Crowds,
And move your pitty by a whining tale:
Your Tyrant would have forc'd me to his Bed;
But in th' attempt of that foul brutal Act,

Thee Loyall Slaves ecur'd me by his Death.
Pointing to Ben.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Makes he no more of me then of a Slave? aide.

Madam, I thought I had intructed you
to Alm.
To frame a Speech more uiting to the times:
The Circumtances of that dire deign,
Your own depair, my unexpected ayd,
my Life endanger'd by his bold defence,
And after all, his Death, and your Deliv'rance,
Were themes that ought not to be lighted o're.

sp.speaker: Mutafa.
sp.p: She might have pas'd over all your petty buinees and no great matter: But the Raiing of my Rabble is an Exploit of conequence; and not to be mumbled up in ilence for all her pertnes.

sp.speaker: Almeyda.
sp.l: When force invades the gift of Nature, Life,
The eldet Law of nature bids defend:
And if in that defence, a Tyrant fall, his Death's his Crime not ours:
Suffice it that he's Dead: all wrongs dye with him;
When he can wrong no more I pardon him:
Thus I abolve my elf; and him excue,
Who av'd my life, and honour; but praie neither.

sp.speaker: Benducar.
sp.l: 'Tis cheap to pardon, whom you would not pay;
But what peak I of payment and reward?
Ungratefull Woman, you are yet no Queen;
Nor more than a proud haughty Chritian lave:
As uch I eize my right. going to lay hold on her.

sp.speaker: Almyda
sp.l: Dare not to approach me;
Now Affricans,
He hows himelf to you; to me he tood
Confet before, and own'd his Inolence
T'epoue my peron, and aume the Crown,
Claym'd in my Right: for this he lew your Tyrant;
Oh no, he only chang'd him for a wore;
Imbas'd your Slavery by his own vilenes,
And loaded you with more ignoble bonds:
Then think me not ungratefull, not to hare,
Th' Imperial Crown with a preuming Traytor.
He ays I am a Chritian; true I am,
But yet no Slave: If Chritians can be thought,
Unfit to govern thoe of other Faith,
'Tis left for you to judge.

sp.speaker: Benducar.
sp.l: I have not patience; he conumes the time
In Idle talk, and owns her fale Belief:
Seize her by force, and bear her hence unheard.

Almeyda to the People.
No, let me rather dye your acrifice
Than live his Tryumph;
I throw my elf into my Peoples armes;
As you are Men compaionate my wrongs,
And as good men Protect me.

Antonio aide
Something mut be done to ave her.
To Mutafa. This is all addres'd to you Sir: She ingled you out with her eye, as Commander in chief of the Mobility.

sp.speaker: Mutafa.
sp.p: Think't thou o Slave Antonio?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Mot certainly Sir; and you cannot in honour but protect her, Now look to your hits, and make your fortune.

sp.speaker: Mutafa.
sp.p: Methought indeed he cat a kind leer towards me: Our Prophet was but jut uch another Scoundrell as I am, till he rais'd himelf to power, and conequently to Holynes, by marrying his maters Widow: I am reolved I'le put forward for my elf: for why hould I be my Lord Benducars Fool and Slave, when I may be my own fool and his Mater?

sp.speaker: Benducar.
sp.p: Take her into poeion, Mutafa.

sp.speaker: Mutafa.
sp.p: That's better Counell than you meant it: Yes I do take her into poeion, and into protection too: what ay you, Maters, will you tand by me?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: One and all; One and all.

sp.speaker: Benducar.
sp.l: Hat thou betray'd me Traytor?

l.U: peak & mind 'em of Religion. Mufti hakes his head.

sp.speaker: Mutafa.
sp.p: Alas the poor Gentleman has gotten a cold, with a Sermon of two hours long, and a prayer of four: and beides, if he durt peak, mankind is grown wier at this time of day, than to cut one anothers throats about Religion. Our Mufti is a Green coat, and the Chritians is a black coat; and we mut wiely go together by the ears, whether green or black hall weep our poils. Drums within and houts.

sp.speaker: Benducar.
sp.l: Now we hall ee whoe numbers will prevail:
The Conquering Troups of Muley Zeydan, come
To cruh Rebellion, and epoue my Caue.

sp.speaker: Mutafa.
sp.p: We will have a fair Tryall of Skill for't, I can tell him that. When we have dipatch'd with Muley Zeydan, your Lordhip hall march in equall proportions of your body, to the four gates of the City: and every Tower hall have a Quarter of you, Antonio draws them up and takes Almeyda by the hand

div.stage: Shouts again and Drums.
Enter Dorax and Sebatian attended by Affrican Soldiers and Portuguees. (Almeyda and Sebatian run into each others armes and both peak together.

sp.speaker: Seb. and Alm.
sp.p: My Sebatian! My Almeyda!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Do you then live?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: And live to love thee ever.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: How! Dorax and Sebatian till alive!
The Moors and Chritians joyn'd! I thank thee Prophet.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: The Citadell is ours; and Muley Zeydan
Safe under Guard, but as becomes a Prince.
Lay down your armes: uch bae Plebeian bloud
Would only tain the brightnes of my Sword,
And blunt it for ome nobler work behind.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I uppoe you may put it up without offence to any man here preent? For my part, I have been Loyall to my Soveraign Lady: though that Villain Benducar, and that Hypocrite the Mufti, would have corrupted me; but if thoe two cape publick Jutice, then I and all my late honet Subjects here, deerve hanging.

sp.speaker: Benducar
sp.l: I'm ure I did my part to poyon thee,
What Saint oe're has Sodder'd thee again.
A Doe les hot had burt through ribs of Iron.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.l: Not knowing that, I poyon'd him once more,
And drench'd him with a draught o deadly cold
That, had't not thou prevented, had congeal'd
The channell of his bloud, and froze him dry.

sp.speaker: Bend.
sp.l: Thou interpoing Fool, to mangle michief,
And think to mend the perfect work of Hell.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: Thus, when Heaven pleaes, double poyons cure.
I will not tax thee of Ingratitude
To me thy Friend, who hat betray'd thy Prince:
Death he deerv'd indeed, but not from thee.
But fate it eems reerv'd the wort of men
To end the wort of Tyrants.
Go bear him to his fate.
And end him to attend his Maters Ghot.
Let ome ecure my other poys'ning Friend,
Whoe double dilligence preerv'd my life.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are fall'n into good hands, Father in law; your parkling Jewells, and Morayma's eyes may prove a better bail than you deerve.

sp.speaker: Muf.
sp.p: The bet that can come of me, in this condition; is to have my life begg'd firt, and then to be begg'd for a Fool afterwards.

div.stage: Exit Antonio with the Mufti, and at the ame time Benducar is carry'd off.

sp.speaker: Dorax
sp.l: You and your hungry herd depart untouch'd;
For Jutice can not toop o low, to reach
The groveling in of Crowds: but curt be they
Who trut revenge with uch mad Intruments,
Whoe blindfold bus'nes is but to detroy:
And like the fire Commiion'd by the Winds,
Begins on heds, but rouling in a round,
On Pallaces returns. Away ye skum,
That till rie upmot when the Nation boyls:
Ye mungrill work of Heaven, with humane hapes,
Not to be damn'd, or av'd, but breath, and perih,
That have but jut enough of ence, to know
The maters voice, when rated, to depart.

sp.speaker: Almeyda
sp.l: With gratitude as low, as knees can pay
To thoe blet holy Fires, our Guardian Angells,
Receive thee thanks; till Altars can be rais'd.

sp.speaker: Dorax
sp.l: Arie fair Excellence, and pay no thanks,
Till time dicover what I have deerv'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: More then reward can anwer.
If Portugall and Spain were joyn'd to Affrique,
And the main Ocean cruted into Land,
If Univerall Monarchy were mine,
Here hould the gift be plac'd.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: And from ome hands I hou'd refue that gift:
Be not too prodigall of Promies;
But tint your bounty to one only grant,
Which I can ask with honour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What I am
Is but thy gift, make what thou cant of me.
Secure of no Repule.

sp.speaker: Dorax
sp.l:
to Sebatian:
Dimis your Train.
To Almeyda. You, Madam, pleae one moment to retire.
sp.stage: Sebatian ignes to the Portugnees to go off. Almeyda bowing to him, goes off alo: The Affricans follow her.
sp.l: Dorax To the Captain of his Guard. With you one word in private. Goes out with the Captain.

sp.speaker: Sebatian
sp.l: Reerv'd behaviour, open Noblenes,
A long miterious Track of a torn bounty.
But now the hand of Fate is on the Curtain,
And draws the Scene to ight.

div.stage: Re-enter Dorax, having taken off his Turbant and put on a Peruque Hat and Crevat.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.p: Now do you know me?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Thou houldt be Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: So you hou'd be Sebatian:
But when Sebatian ceas'd to be himelf,
I ceas'd to be Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: As in a Dream.
I ee thee here, and carce believe mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: Is it o trange to find me, where my wrongs,
And your Inhumane Tyranny have ent me?
Think not you dream: or, if you did, my Injuries
Shall call o loud, that Lethargy hould wake;
And Death hould give you back to anwer me.
A Thouand Nights have bruh'd their balmy wings
Over thee eyes, but ever when they clos'd,
Your Tyrant Image forc'd 'em ope again,
And dry'd the dewes they brought.
The long expected hour is come at length,
By manly Vengence to redeem my fame;
And that once clear'd, eternall leep is welcome.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: I have not yet forgot I am a King
Whoe Royall Office is redres of Wrongs:
If I have wrong'd thee, charge me face to face;
I have not yet forgot I am a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: 'Tis the firt Jutice thou hat ever done me.
Then, though I loath this Womans War of tongues,
Yet hall my Caue of Vengeance firt be clear
And, Honour, be thou Judge.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Honour be friend us both.
Beware, I warn thee yet, to tell thy griefs
In terms becoming Majety to hear:
I warn thee thus, becaue I know thy temper
Is Inolent and haughty to Superiours:
How often hat thou brav'd my peacefull Court,
Fill'd it with noiy brawls, and windy boats;
And, with pat ervice, naueouly repeated,
Reproach'd ev'n me thy Prince?

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: And well I might, when you forgot reward,
The part of Heav'n in Kings: for punihment
Is Hangmans work, and drudgery for Devils.
I mut and will reproach thee with my ervice,
Tyrant, (it irks me o to call my Prince.
But jut reentment and hard uage coyn'd
Th' unwilling word; and grating as it is
Take it, for 'tis thy due.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: How Tyrant?

sp.speaker: Dorax
sp.p: Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Traytour? that name thou cant not Eccho back
That Robe of Infamy, that Circumciion
Ill hid beneath that Robe, proclaim thee Traytor:
And, if a Name
More foul than Traytor be, 'tis Renegade.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: If I'm a Traytor, think and bluh, thou Tyrant,
Whoe Injuries betray'd me into treaon.
Effac'd my Loyalty, unhing'd my Faith,
And hurryed me from hopes of Heaven to Hell.
All thee, and all my yet unfinih'd Crimes,
When I hall rie to plead before the Saints,
I charge on thee, to make thy damning ure.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Thy old preumptuous Arrogance again,
That bred my firt dilike, and then my loathing.
Once more be warn'd, and know me for thy King.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: Too well I know thee; but for King no more:
This is not Lisbonne, nor the Circle this,
Where, like a Statue, thou hat tood beieg'd,
By Sycophants and Fools, the growth of Courts:
Where thy gull'd eyes, in all the gawdy round,
Met nothing but a lye in every face;
And the gros flattery of a gaping Crowd,
Envious who firt hould catch, and firt applaud.
The Stuff of Royall Nonence: when I poke,
My honet homely words were carp'd, and cenur'd,
For want of Courtly Stile: related Actions,
Though modetly reported, pas'd for boats:
Secure of Merit if I ask'd reward,
Thy hungry Minions thought their rights invaded,
And the bread natch'd from Pimps and Paraits.
Enriquez anwer'd, with a ready lye,
To ave his King's, the boon was begg'd before.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: What ayt thou of Enriquez? now by Heaven
Thou mov't me more by barely naming him,
Than all thy foul unmanner'd curril taunts.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: And therefore 'twas to gaul thee, that I nam'd him:
That thing, that nothing, but a cringe and mile;
That Woman, but more dawb'd; or if a man,
Corrupted to a Woman: thy Man Mitres.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: All fale as Hell or thou.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: Yes; full as fale
As that I erv'd thee fifteen hard Campaignes,
And pitch'd thy Standard in thee Forreign Fields:
By me thy greatnes grew; thy years grew with it,
But thy Ingratitude outgrew 'em both.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: I ee to what thou tend't, but tell me firt
If thoe great Acts were done alone for me;
If love produc'd not ome, and pride the ret?

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: Why Love does all that's noble here below;
But all th' advantage of that love was thine.
For, coming fraughted back, in either hand
With Palm and Olive, Victory and Peace,
I was indeed prepar'd to ask my own:
(For Violante's vows were mine before:)
Thy malice had prevention, ere I poke:
And ask'd me Violante for Enriquez.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I meant thee a reward of greater worth:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Where jutice wanted, could reward be hop'd?
Could the robb'd Paenger expect a bounty,
From thoe rapacious hands who tript him firt?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He had my promie, e're I knew thy love,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My Services deerv'd thou hould't revoke it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thy Inolence had cancell'd all thy Service:
To violate my Laws, even in my Court,
Sacred to peace, and afe from all affronts;
E'ven to my face, as done in my depight,
Under the wing of awfull Majety
To trike the man I lov'd!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Even in the face of Heaven, a place more Sacred,
Would I have truck the man, who propt by power,
Would Seize my right, and rob me of my Love:
But, for a blow provok'd by thy Injutice,
The haty product of a jut depair,
When he refus'd to meet me in the field,
That thou houd't make a Cowards Caue thy own!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He durt; nay more deir'd and begg'd with tears,
To meet thy Challenge fairly: 'twas thy fault
• o make it publique; but my duty, then,
To interpoe; on pain of my dipleaure,
Betwixt your Swords,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: On pain of Infamy
He hould have diobey'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Th' Indignity thou didt, was ment to me;
Thy gloomy eyes were cat on me, with corn,
As who hould ay the blow was there intended;
But that thou didt not dare to lift thy hands
Againt Annointed power: o was I forc'd
To do a Soveraign jutice to my elf;
And purn thee from my preence.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou hat dar'd
To tell me, what I durt not tell my elf:
I durt not think that I was purn'd, and live;
And live to hear it boated to my face.
All my long Avarice of honour lot,
Heap'd up in Youth, and hoarded up for Age;
Has honours Fountain then uck'd back the tream?
He has; and hooting Boys, may dry hod pas,
And gather pebbles from the naked Foord.
Give me my Love, my Honour; give 'em back:—
Give me revenge; while I have breath to ask it.—

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now, by this honour'd Order which I wear,
More gladly would I give, than thou dar't ask it:
Nor hall the Sacred Character of King
Be urg'd, to hield me from thy bold appeal.
If I have injur'd thee, that makes us equall:
The wrong, if done, debas'd me down to thee.
But thou hat charg'd me with Ingratitude:
Hat thou not charg'd me; peak?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou know't I have:
If thou diown't that Imputation, draw,
And prove my Charge a lye.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No; to diprove that lye, I mut not draw:
Be concious to thy worth, and tell thy Soul
What thou hat done this day in my defence:
To fight thee, after this, what were it ele,
Than owning that Ingratitude thou urget?
That Ithmus tands betwixt two ruhing Seas;
Which, mounting, view each other from afar;
And trive in vain to meet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'le cut that Ithmus.
Thou know't I meant not to preerve thy Life,
But to reprieve it, for my own revenge.
I av'd thee out of honourable malice:
Now draw; I hould be loath to think thou dar't not:
Beware of uch another vile excue.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: O patience Heaven!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Beware of Patience too;
That's a Supicious word: it had been proper
Before thy foot had purn'd me; now 'tis bae:
Yet, to diarm thee of thy lat defence,
I have thy Oath for my ecurity:
The only boon I begg'd was this fair Combat:
Fight or be Perjur'd now; that's all thy choice.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Now I can thank thee as thou wouldt be thank'd:
Never was vow of honour better pay'd,
If my true Sword but hold, than this hall be.
The prightly Bridegroom, on his Wedding Night,
More gladly enters not the lits of Love.
Why 'tis enjoyment to be ummon'd thus.
Go: bear my Meage to Henriquez Ghot;
And ay his Mater and his Friend reveng'd him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: His Ghot! then is my hated Rivall dead?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The quetion is beide our preent purpoe;
Thou eet me ready; we delay too long.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A minute is not much in eithers Life,
When their's but one betwixt us; throw it in,
And give it him of us, who is to fall.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: He's dead: make hat, and thou mayt yet o're take him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: When I was haty, thou delay't me longer.
I prethee let me hedge one moment more
Into thy promie; for thy life preerv'd:
Be kind: and tell me how that Rivall dy'd,
Whoe Death next thine I wih'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If it would pleae thee thou hould't never know:
But thou, like Jealouy, enquir't a truth,
Which, found, will torture thee: He dy'd in Fight:
Fought next my peron; as in Conort fought:
Kept pace for pace, and blow for every blow;
Save when he heav'd his Shield in my defence;
And on his naked ide receiv'd my wound.
Then, when he could no more, he fell at once:
But rowl'd his falling body cros their way;
And made a Bulwark of it for his Prince

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I never can forgive him uch a death!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I prophecy'd thy proud Soul could not bear it.
Now, judge thy elf, who bet deerv'd my Love.
I knew you both; (and durt I ay) as Heaven
Foreknew among the hining Angell hot
Who would tand firm, who fall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Had he been tempted o, o had he fall'n;
And o, had I been favour'd, had I tood.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What had been is unknown; what is appears:
Confes he jutly was preferr'd to thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Had I been born with his indulgent Stars,
My fortune had been his, and his been mine.
O, wore than Hell! what Glory have I lot,
And what has he acquir'd, by uch a death!
I hould have fallen by Sebatians ide;
My Corps had been the Bulwark of my King.
His glorious end was a patch'd work of fate,
Ill orted with a oft effeminate life:
It uited better with my life than his
So to have dy'd: mine had been of a peice,
Spent in your ervice, dying at your feet.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The more effeminate and oft his life,
The more his fame, to truggle to the field,
And meet his glorious fate: Confes, proud Spirit,
(For I will have it from thy very mouth)
That better he deerv'd my love than thou.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O, whether would you drive me! I mut grant,
Yes I mut grant, but with a welling Soul,
Henriquez had your Love with more deert:
For you he fought, and dy'd; I fought againt you;
Through all the mazes of the bloudy field,
Hunted your Sacred life; which that I mis'd
Was the propitious errour of my fate,
Not of my Soul; my Soul's a Regicide.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou might't have given it a more gentle name:
[more calmly.] Thou mean't to kill a Tyrant, not a King:
Speak didt thou not, Alonzo?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Can I peak!
Alas, I cannot anwer to Alonzo:
No, Dorax cannot anwer to Alonzo:
Alonzo was too kind a name for me.
Then, when I fought and conquer'd with your Armes,
In that blet Age I was the man you nam'd:
Till rage and pride debas'd me into Dorax;
And lot like Lucifer, my name above.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Yet, twice this day I ow'd my life to Dorax.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I av'd you but to kill you; there's my grief.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay, if thou can't be griev'd, thou can't repent:
Thou coud't not be a Villain, though thou woud't:
Thou own't too much, in owning thou hat err'd;
And I too little, who provok'd thy Crime.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O top this headlong Torrent of your goodnes:
It comes too fat upon a feeble Soul,
Half drown'd in tears, before; pare my confuion:
For pitty pare, and ay not, firt, you err'd.
For yet I have not dar'd, through guilt and hame,
[Falls at his feet] To throw my elf beneath your Royall feet.
Now purn this Rebell, this proud Renegade:
'Tis jut you hould, nor will I more complain.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Indeed thou houd't not ask forgivenes firt,
taking him up. But thou preventt me till, in all that's noble.
Yet I will raie thee up with better news:
Thy Violante's heart was ever thine;
Compell'd to wed, becaue he was my Ward,
Her Soul was abent when he gave her hand:
Nor could my threats, or his puruing Courthip,
Effect the Conummation of his Love:
So, till indulging tears, he pines for thee,
A Widdow and a Maid.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Have I been curing Heav'n while Heav'n blet me!
I hall run mad with extay of joy:
What, in one moment, to be reconcil'd
To Heaven, and to my King, and to my Love!
But pitty is my Friend, and tops me hort,
For my unhappy Rivall: poor Henriquez!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Art thou o generous too, to Pitty him?
Nay, then I was unjut to love him better.
Embracing him. Here let me ever hold thee in my arms:
And all our quarrells be but uch as thee,
Who hall love bet, and cloet hall embrace:
Be what Enriquez was; be my Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What, my Alonzo ayd you? my Alonzo!
Let my tears thank you; for I cannot peak:
And if I cou'd,
Words were not made to vent uch thoughts as mine.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou cant not peak, and I can ne're be ilent.
Some Strange revere of Fate mut, ure attend
This vat profuion, this extravagance
Of Heaven, to bles me thus. 'Tis Gold o pure
It cannot bear the Stamp, without allay.
Be kind, ye Powers, and take but half away:
With eae the gifts of Fortune I reign;
But, let my Love, and Friend, be ever mine.

div.stage: Exeunt

div.head: ACT V. The Scene is a Room of State.
div.stage: Enter Dorax and Antonio.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: JOy is on every face, without a Cloud:
As, in the Scene of opening Paradice,
The whole Creation danc'd at their new being:
Pleas'd to be what they were; pleas'd with each other.
Such Joy have I, both in my elf, and Friends:
And double Joy, that I have made 'em happy.

sp.speaker: Antonio,
sp.l: Pleaure has been the bus'nes of my life;
And every change of Fortune eay to me,
Becaue I till was eay to my elf.
The los of her I lov'd would touch me nearet;
Yet, if I found her, I might love too much;
And that's uneay Pleaure.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If he be fated
To be your Wife, your fate will find her for you:
Predetinated ills are never lot.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: I had forgot
T'Enquire before, but long to be inform'd,
How, poion'd and betray'd, and round beet,
You could unwind your elf from all thee dangers;
And move o peedily to our relief!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The double poions, after a hort Combat,
Expell'd each other in their Civill War,
By natures benefit: and rows'd my thoughts
To Guard that life which now I found Attack'd.
I ummon'd all my Officers in hat,
On whoe experienc'd Faith I might rely:
All came; reolv'd to dye in my defence,
Save that one Villain who betray'd the Gate.
Our diligence prevented the urprize
We jutly fear'd: o, Muley-Zeydan found us
Drawn-up in Battle, to receive the charge

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But how the Moors and Chritian laves were joyn'd,
You have not yet unfolded.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That remains.
We knew their Int'ret was the ame with ours:
And though I hated more than Death, Sebatian;
I could not ee him dye by Vulgar hands:
But prompted by my Angell, or by his,
Freed all the Slaves, and plac'd him next my elf,
Becaue I would not have his Peron known,
I need not tell the ret, th' event declares it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your Conquet came of coure; their men were raw,
And yours were diciplin'd: one doubt remains,
Why you indutriouly conceal'd the King,
Who, known, had added Courage to his Men?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I would not hazard civill broils, betwixt
His Friends and mine: which might prevent our Combat:
Yet had he fall'n, I had dimis'd his Troops;
Or, if Victorious, order'd his ecape.
But I forgot a new increae of Joy,
To feat him with urprize; I mut about it:

Expect my wift return.
Exit Dorax.

div.stage: Enter a Servant to Antonio.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here's a Lady at the door, that bids me tell you, he is come to make an end of the game, that was broken off betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What manner of Woman is he? Does he not want two of the four Elements? has he any thing about her but ayr and fire?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Truly, he flys about the room, as if he had wings intead of legs; I believe he's jut turning into a bird: a houe-bird I warrant her: and o haty to fly to you, that, rather than fail of entrance, he wou'd come tumbling down the Chimney, like a Swallow.

div.stage: Enter Morayma.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.stage: running to her and Embracing her.
sp.p: Look if he be not here already: what, no deniall it eems will erve your turn? why! thou little dun, is thy debt o preing?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Little Devill if you pleae: your leae is out, good Mr. Conjurer; and I am come to fetch you Soul and Body; not an hour of lewdnes longer in this world for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where the Devill hat thou been? and how the Devill didt thou find me here?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I follow'd you into the Catle yard: but there was nothing but Tumult, and Confuion: and I was bodily afraid of being pick'd up by ome of the Rabble conidering I had a double charge about me,—my Jewells & my Mayden-head.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Both of 'em intended for my Worhips ole ue and Property.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And what was poor little I among 'em all?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not a mouthfull a piece: 'twas too much odds in Concience.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
So eeking for helter, I naturally ran to the old place
of Aignation, the Garden-houe: where for want of intinct, you did not follow me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well for thy Comfort, I have ecur'd thy Father; and I hope thou hat ecur'd his effects for us.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes truly I had the prudent foreight to conider that when we grow old, and weary of Solacing one another, we might have, at leat, wherewithall to make merry with the World; and take up with a wore pleaure of eating and drinking, when we were diabled for a better.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thy fortune will be e'en too good for thee: for thou art going into the Country of Serenades, and Gallantries; where thy treet will be haunted every Night, with thy foolih Lovers, and my Rivals; who will be ighing, and inging under thy inexorable windows, lamentable ditties, and call thee Cruell, & Goddes, & Moon, and Stars, and all the Poeticall names of wicked rhyme: while thou and I, are minding our bus'nes, and jogging on, and laughing at 'em; at leiure-minuts, which will be very few, take that by way of threatning.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am afraid you are not very valiant, that you huff o much before hand: but, they ay, your Churches are fine places for Love-devotion: many a he-Saint is there worhip'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Temples are there, as they are in all other Countries, good conveniences for dumb enterviews: I hear the Protetants an't much reform'd in that point neither; for their Sectaries call • heir Churches by the naturall name of Meeting-houes. therefore I warn thee in good time, not more of devotion than needs mut, good future Spowe; and allways in a veile; for thoe eyes of thine are damn'd enemies to mortification.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The bet thing I have heard of Chritendom, is that we women are allow'd the priviledge of having Souls; and I aure you, I hall make bold to betow mine, upon ome Lover, when ever you begin to go atray, and, if I find no Convenience in a Church, a private Chamber will erve the turn.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: When that day comes, I mut take my revenge and turn Gardener again: for I find I am much given to Planting.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But take heed, in the mean time, that ome young Antonio does not pring-up in your own Family; as fale as his Father, though of another mans planting.

div.stage: Reenter Dorax with Sebatian and Almeyda. Sebatian enters peaking to Dorax, while in the mean time Antonio preents Morayma to Almeyda.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: How fares our Royall Pris'ner, Muley Zeydan?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Dipos'd to grant whatever I deire,
To gain a Crown, and Freedom: well I know him,
Of eay temper, naturally good,
And faithfull to his word.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yet one thing wants,
To fill the meaure of my happines
I'm till in pain for poor Alvarez's life.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Releae that fear; the good old man is afe:
I pay'd his ranome:
And have already order'd his Attendance.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O bid him enter for I long to ee him.
sp.stage: Enter Alvarez with a Servant, who departs when Alvarez is enter'd.

sp.speaker: Alvarez
sp.stage: [falling down and embracing the Kings knees.]
sp.l: Now by my Soul, and by thee hoary hairs,
I'm o ore-whelm'd with pleaure, that I feel
A latter pring within my with'ring limbs,
That Shoots me out again.

sp.speaker: Sebatian,
sp.l: Thou good old Man!
Thou hat deceiv'd me into more, more joys;
Who tood brim-full before.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: O my dear Child!
I love thee o, I cannot call thee King,
Whom I o oft have dandled in thee arms!
What, when I gave thee lot to find thee living!
'Tis like a Father, who himelf had cap'd
A falling houe, and after anxious earch,
Hears from afar, his only Son within:
And digs through rubbih, till he drags him out
To ee the friendly light.
Such is my hat o trembling is my joy
To draw thee forth from underneath thy Fate.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The Tempet is ore-blown; the Skys are clear,
And the Sea, charm'd into a Calm o till,
That not a wrinkle ruffles her mooth face.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Jut uch he hows before a riing torm:
And therefore am I come, with timely peed,
To warn you into Port.

sp.speaker: Almeyda.
sp.l: My Soul fore-bodes aide.
Some dire event involv'd in thoe dark words;
And jut dicloing, in a birth of fate.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Is there not yet an Heir of this vat Empire,
Who till Survives, of Muley-Moluchs branch?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes uch an one there is, a Captive here,
And Brother to the Dead.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: The Power's above
Be prais'd for that: My prayers for my good Mater
I hope are heard.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou hat a right in Heav'n,
But why thee prayers for me?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: A door is open yet for your deliv'rance,
Now you my Country-men, and you Almeyda,
Now all of us, and you (my all in one)
May yet be happy in that Captives life.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We have him here an honourable Hotage
For terms of peace: what more he can Contribute
To make me blet, I know not.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Vatly more:
Almeyda may be ettled in the Throne;
And you review your Native Clime with fame:
A firm Alliance, and eternall Peace,
(The glorious Crown of honourable War,)
Are all included in that Princes life:
Let this fair Queen be giv'n to Muley-Zeydan;
And make her love the Sanction of your League.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No more of that: his life's in my dipoe;
And Pris'ners are not to init on terms.
Or if they were, yet he demands not thee.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: You hou'd exact 'em.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Better may be made;
Thee cannot: I abhor the Tyrants race;
My Parents Murtherers, my Throne's Uurpers.
But, at one blow to cut off all dipute,
Know this, thou buy, old, officious Man,
I am a Chritian; now be wie no more;
Or if thou woud't be till thought wie, be ilent.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: O! I perceive you think your Int'ret touch'd:
'Tis what before the Battail I oberv'd:
But I mut peak, and will.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I prethee peace;
Perhaps he thinks they are too near of bloud·

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: I wih he may not wod to bloud more near.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: What if I make her mine?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Now Hea'vn forbid!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Wih rather Hea'vn may grant.
For, if I cou'd deerve, I have deerv'd her:
My toyls, my hazards, and my Subjects lives,
(Provided he conent) may claim her love:
And, that once granted, I appeal to thee,
If better, I cou'd chue a beauteous Bride.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The fairet of her Sex.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The pride of Nature.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He only merits her; he only him.
So payr'd, o uited in their minds and Perons,
That they were fram'd the Tallyes for each other.
If any Alien love had interpos'd
It mut have been an eyeore to beholders,
And to themelves a Cure.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: And to themelves.
The greatet Cure that can be, were to joyn.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Did I not love thee, pat a change to hate,
That word had been thy ruine; but no more,
I charge thee on thy life, pervere old man.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Know, Sir, I wou'd be ilent if I durt:
But, if on Shipbord,, I hou'd ee my Friend,
Grown frantique in a raging Calenture,
And he, imagining vain flowry fields,
Wou'd headlong plunge himelf into the deep,
Shou'd I not hold him from that mad attempt,
Till his ick fancy were by reaon cur'd?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I pardon thee th' effects of doting Age;
Vain doubts, and idle cares, and over-caution;
The econd Non-age of a Soul, more wie;
But now decay'd; and unk into the Socket,
Peeping by fits and giving feeble light.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Have you forgot?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou mean't my Fathers Will,
In bar of Marriage to Almeyda's bed:
Thou eet my faculties are till entire,
Though thine are much impair'd, I weigh'd that Will,
And found 'twas grounded on our diff'rent Faiths;
But, had he liv'd to ee her happy change,
He wou'd have cancell'd that harh Interdict,
And joyn'd our hands himelf.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Still had he liv'd and een this change,
He till had been the Same.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I have a dark remembrance of my Father;
His reas'nings and his Actions both were jut;
And, granting that, he mut have chang'd his meaures.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Yes, he was jut, and therefore cou'd not change.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: 'Tis a bae wrong thou offer't to the Dead.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Now Hea'vn forbid,
That I hou'd blat his pious Memory:
No, I am tender of his holy Fame:
For, dying he bequeath'd it to my charge.
Believe I am; and eek to know no more,
But pay a blind obedience to his will.
For to preerve his Fame I wou'd be ilent.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Craz'd fool, who woud't be thought an Oracle.
Come down from off thy Tripos, and peak plain;
My Father hall be jutify'd, he hall:
'Tis a Son's part to rie in his defence;
And to confound thy malice, or thy dotage.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: It does not grieve me that you hold me craz'd;
But, to be clear'd at my dead Maters cot,
O there's the wound! but let me firt adjure you,
By all you owe that dear departed Soul,
No more to think of Marriage with Almeyda.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Not Hea'vn and Earth combin'd, can hinder it.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Then, witnes Hea'vn and Earth, how loath I am
To ay, you mut not, nay you cannot wed.
And ince not only a dead Fathers fame,
But more a Ladies honour mut be touch'd,
Which nice as Ermines will not bear a Soil;
Let all retire; that you alone may hear
What ev'n in whipers I wou'd tell your ear.

div.stage: All are going out.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Not one of you depart; I charge you tay.
And, were my voice a Trumpet loud as Fame,
To reach the round of Hea'vn, and Earth, and Sea,
All Nations hou'd be Summon'd to this place.
So little do I fear that Fellows charge:
So hou'd my honour like a riing Swan,
Bruh with her wings, the falling drops away,
And proudly plough the waves.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This noble Pride becomes thy Innocence:
And I dare trut my Fathers memory,
To tand the charge of that foul forging tongue:

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: It will be oon dicover'd if I forge:
Have you not heard your Father in his youth,
When newly marry'd, travel'd into Spain,
And made a long abode in Phillips Court?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why o remote a quetion? which thy elf
Can anwer to thy elf, for thou wert with him,
His Fav'rite, as I oft have heard thee boat:
And nearet to his Soul.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Too near indeed, forgive me Gracious Heaven
That ever I hould boat I was o near.
The Confident of all his young Amours.
[To Almeyda] And have not you, unhappy beauty, heard,
Have you not often heard, your Exil'd Parents
Were refug'd in that Court, and at that time?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: 'Tis true: and often ince, my Mother own'd
How kind that Prince was, to epoue her caue;
She Counell'd, nay, Enjoyn'd me on her bleing
To eek the Sanctuary of your Court:
Which gave me firt encouragement to come,
And, with my Brother, beg Sebatians aid.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Thou help't me well, to jutify my War:
to Alme. My dying Father wore me, then a Boy;
And made me kis the Cros upon his Sword,
Never to heath it, till that exil'd Queen
Were by my Arms retor'd.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: And can you finde
No mitery, couch'd in this exces of kindnes?
Were Kings e're known, in this degenerate Age,
So paionately fond of noble Acts,
Where Interet har'd not more than half with honour?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bae groveling Soul, who know't not honours worth;
But weigh't it out in mercenary Scales;
The Secret pleaure of a generous Act,
Is the great minds great bribe.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Show me that King, and I'le believe the Phoenix.
But knock at your own breat, and ask your Soul
If thoe fair fatall eyes, edg'd not your Sword,
More than your Fashers charge, and all your vows?
If o; and o your ilence grants it is,
Know King, your Father had, like you, a Soul;
And Love is your Inheritance from him.
Almeyda's Mother too had eyes, like her,
And not les charming, and were charm'd no les
Than your's are now with her, and her's with you.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Thou ly't Impotor, Perjur'd Fiend thou ly't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Wa't not enough to brand my Father's fame,
But thou mut load a Ladies memory?
O Infamous bae, beyond repair.
And, to what end this ill concerted lye,
Which, palpable and gros, yet granted true,
It barrs not my Inviolable vows.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Take heed and double not your Fathers crimes;
To his Adult'ry, do not add your Incet.
Know, he is the product of unlawfull Love:
And 'tis your Carnall Siter you wou'd wed.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou hallt not ay thou wert Condemn'd unheard.
Ele, by my Soul, this moment were thy lat.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: But think not Oaths hall jutify thy charge;
Nor Imprecations on thy cured head,
For who dares lye to Heaven, thinks Heaven a Jet.
Thou hat confes'd thy elf the Concious Pandar
Of that pretended paion:
A Single Witnes, infamouly known,
Againt two Perons of unquetion'd fame;

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: What Int'ret can I have, or what delight
To blaze their hame, or to divulge my own?
If prov'd you hate me if unprov'd Condemn?
Not Racks or Tortures could have forc'd this ecret,
But too much care, to ave you from a Crime,
Which would have unk you both. For let me ay,
Almeyda's beauty well deerves your love:

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Out, bae Impotor, I abhor thy praie.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: It looks not like Impoture: but a truth,
On utmot need reveal'd.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Did I expect from Dorax, this return?
Is this the love renew'd?

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: Sir, I am ilent;
Pray Heav'n my fears prove fale.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.p: Away; you all combine to make me wretched.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: But hear the tory of that fatall Love;
Where every Circumtance hall prove another;
And truth o hine, by her own native light,
That if a Lye were mixt, it mut be een.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: No; all may till be forg'd, and of a piece.
No; I can credit nothing thou can't ay:

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: One proof remains; and that's your Fathers hand:
Firm'd with his Signet; both o fully known,
That plainer Evidence can hardly be,
Unles his Soul wou'd want her Hea'vn a while,
And come on Earth to wear.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Produce that Writing.

Alv • r. to Dorax
Alonzo has it in his Cutody.
The ame, which when his noblenes redeem'd me,
And in a friendly viit own'd himelf,
For what he is, I then depoited:
And had his Faith to give it to the King.

sp.speaker: Dorax
sp.stage: giving a eal'd Paper to the King.
sp.l: Untouch'd, and Seal'd as when intruted with me,
Such I retore it, with a trembling hand,
Let ought within diturb your peace of Soul.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Draw near Almeyda: thou art mot concern'd.
For I am mot in Thee.
Alonzo, mark the Characters:
Thou know't my Fathers hand oberve it well:
And if th'Impotors Pen, have made one lip,
That hows it Counterfeit, mark that and ave me.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: It looks, indeed, too like my Maters hand:
So does the Signet; more I cannot ay;
But wih 'twere not o like.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: Methinks it owns
The black Adult'ry, and Almeyda's birth;
But uch a mit of grief comes o're my eyes,
I cannot, or I wou'd not read it plain.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Hea'vn cannot be more true, than this is fale.

sp.speaker: Sebat.
sp.l: O Coud't thou prove it, with the ame aurance!
Speak, hat thou ever een my Fathers hand?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: No; but my Mothers honour has been read
By me, and by the world, in all her Acts;
In Characters more plain, and legible
Then this dumb Evidence, this blotted lye.
Oh that I were a man, as my Soul's one,
To prove thee, Traytor, an Aainate
Of her fair ame: thus wou'd I tear thee, thus—: (Tearing the Paper)
And catter, o're the field, thy Coward limbs,
Like this foul offspring of thy forging brain.

div.stage: (Scatt'ring the Paper)

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Jut o, halt thou be torn from all thy hopes.
For know proud Woman, know in thy depight,
The mot Authentique proof is till behind.
Thou wear't it on thy finger: 'tis that Ring,
Which match'd with that on his, hall clear the doubt.
'Tis no dumb forgery: for that hall peak;
And ound a rattling peal to eithers Concience:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This Ring indeed, my Father, with a cold
And haking hand, jut in the pangs of Death,
Put on my finger; with a parting igh,
And wou'd have poke; but falter'd in his peech,
With unditinguih'd ounds.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I know it well:
For I was preent: Now, Almeyda, peak:
And, truly tell us, how you come by yours?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: My Mother, when I parted from her ight,
To go to Portugall bequeath'd it to me,
Preaging he hou'd never ee me more:
She pull'd it from her finger, hed ome tears,
Kis'd it, and told me 'twas a pledge of Love;
And hid a Mitery of great Importance
Relating to my Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Mark me now,
While I dicloe that fatall Mitery.
Yhoe rings, when you were born, and thought anothers,
Tour Parents, glowing yet in infull love,
Bid me bepeak: a Curious Artit wrought 'em:
With joynts o cloe, as not to be perceiv'd;
Yet are they both each others Counterpart.
Her part had Juan incrib'd, and his had Zayda.
)You know thoe names are theirs:) and in the midt,
A heart divided in two halves was plac'd.
Now if the rivets of thoe Rings, inclos'd,
Fit not each other, I have forg'd this lye:
But if they joyn, you mut for ever part,

sp.speaker: Seb,
sp.p: [Seb. pulling off his Ring. Alm. does the ame, and gives it to Alv. who uncrues both the Rings & fits one half to the other.] Now life, or death.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And either thine, or ours.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I'm lot for ever.— (woons)

div.stage: (The Women and Morayma, take her up and carry her off.)
[Seb. here tands amaz'd without motion, his eyes fixt upward.]

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Look to the Queen my Wife; For I am pat
All Pow'r of Aid, to her or to my elf.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: His Wife, aid he, his Wife! O fatall ound!
For, had I known it, this unwelcome news
Had never reach'd their ears.
So they had till been blet in Ignorance,
And I alone unhappy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I knew it, but too late: and durt not peak.

lg.l: I will not live: no not a moment more;
I will not add one moment more to Incet.
I'le cut it off, and end a wretched being.
For, hould I live, my Soul's o little mine,
And o much hers, that I hould till enjoy.
Ye Cruell Powers
Take me as you have made me, mierable;
You cannot make me guilty; 'twas my fate
And you made that, not I. Draws his Sword.

div.stage: Antonio and Alv. lay hold on him, and Dorax wrets the Sword out of his hand.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: For Heav'ns ake hold, and recollect your mind.

sp.speaker: Alvarez.
sp.l: Conider whom you punih, and for what;
Your elf? unjutly: You have charg'd the fault,
On Heav'n that bet may bear it.
Though Incet is indeed a deadly Crime,
You are not guilty, ince, unknown 'twas done,
And known, had been abhorr'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: By Heaven y're Traytours, all, that hold my hands.
If death be but ceation of our thought,
Then let me dye for I would think no more.
I'le boat my Innocence above;
And let 'em ee a Soul they cou'd not ully:
I hall be there before my Fathers Ghot;
That yet mut languih long, in frots and fires
For making me unhappy by his Crime:
[truggling again.] Stand off and let me take my fill of death;
For I can hold my breath in your depight,
And well my heaving Soul out, when I pleae:

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: Heav'n comfort you!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What art thou given comfort!
Wou'dt thou give comfort, who hat giv'n depair?
Thou eet Alonzo ilent; he's a man.
He knows, that men abandon'd of their hopes
Shou'd ask no leave, nor tay for ueing out
A tedious Writ of eae, from lingring Heaven,
But help themelves, as timely as they cou'd,
And teach the fates their duty.
[Dorax to Alv. and Anto.] Let him go:
He is our King; and he hall be obey'd:

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: What to detroy himelf, O Parricide!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Be not Injurious in your foolih zeal,
But leave him free; or by my word I wear,
To hew that Arm away, that tops the paage.
To his Eternal ret.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: [letting go his hold.] Let him be Guilty of his own death if he pleaes: for I'le not be guilty of mine; by holding him.

div.stage: The King hakes off Alvarez

sp.speaker: Alvarez.
sp.l:
to Dorax
Infernal Fiend,
Is this a Subjects part?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis a Friends Office,
He has convinc'd me that he ought to dye.
And, rather than he hould not, here's my word
To help him on his Journey.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My lat, my only Friend, how kind art thou
And how Inhuman thee!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To make the trifle death, a thing of moment!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And not to weigh th' Important caue I had,
To rid my elf of life?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: True; for a Crime.
So horrid in the face of Men and Angells,
As wilfull Incet is!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Not wilfull neither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, if you liv'd and with repeated Acts,
Refreh'd your Sin, and loaded crimes with crimes,
To well your cores of Guilt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: True; if I liv'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I aid o, if you liv'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: For hitherto 'was fatall ignorance:
And no intended crime.

sp.speaker: Dor,
sp.l: That you bet know.
But the Malicious World will judge the wort.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: O what a Sophiter has Hell procur'd,
To argue for Damnation!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Peace, old Dotard.
Mankind that always judge of Kings with malice,
Will think he knew this Incet, and puru'd it.
His only way to rectify mitakes,
And to redeem her honour, is to dye.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou hat it right, my dear, my bet Alonzo!
And that, but petty reparation too;
But all I have to give.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your pardon, Sir;
You may do more, and ought.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: What, more than death?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Death? Why that's Childrens port: a Stage-Play, Death.
We Act it every Night we go to bed.
Death to a Man in miery is leep.
Wou'd you, who perpetrated uch a Crime,
As frighten'd nature, made the Saints above
Shake Heav'ns Eternal pavement with their trembling,
To view that act, wou'd you but barely dye?
But tretch your limbs, and turn on t'other ide,
To lengthen out a black voluptuous lumber,
And dream you had your Siter in your arms.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: To expiate this, can I do more then dye?

sp.speaker: Dor:
sp.l: O yes: you mut do more; you mut be damn'd:
You mut be damn'd to all Eternity.
And, ure, elf-Murder is the readiet way.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: How, damn'd?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why is that News?

sp.speaker: Alvar,
sp.p: O, horrour! horrour!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What, thou a Stateman,
And make a bus'nes of Damnation?
In uch a World as this, why 'tis a trade.
The Scriv'ner, Uurer, Lawyer, Shop-keeper,
And Soldier, cannot live, but by damnation.
The Polititian does it by advance:
And gives all gone before-hand.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O thou hat giv'n me uch a glime of Hell,
So puh'd me forward, even to the brink,
Of that irremeable burning Gulph,
That looking in th' Abys; I dare not leap.
And now I ee what good thou meant my Soul,
And thank thy pious fraud: Thou hat indeed,
Appear'd a Devill, but didt an Angells work.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Twas the lat Remedy, to give you leiure.
For, if you cou'd but think, I knew you afe.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I thank thee, my Alonzo: I will live:
But never more to Portugall return:
For, to go back and reign, that were to how
Triumphant Incet, and pollute the Throne.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Since Ignorance—

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O, palliate not my wound:
When you have argu'd all you can, 'tis Incet:
No, 'tis reolv'd, I charge you plead no more;
I cannot live without Almeyda's ight,
Nor can I ee Almeyda but I in.
Hea'vn has inpir'd me with a Sacred thought,
To live alone to Hea'vn: and dye to her.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.p: Mean you to turn an Anchoret?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What ele?
The world was once too narrow for my mind,
But one poor little nook will erve me now;
To hide me from the ret of humane kinde.
Affrique has dearts wide enough to hold
Millions of Monters, and I am, ure, the greatet.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.p: You may repent, and wih your Crown too late.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O never, never: I am pat a Boy,
A Scepter's but a play thing, and a Globe
A bigger bounding Stone. He who can leave
Almeyda, may renounce the ret with eae.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: O Truly great!
A Soul fix'd high, and capable of Hea'vn.
Old as he is your Uncle Cardinall,
Is not o far enamour'd of a Cloyter,
But he will thank you, for the Crown you leave him.

sp.speaker: Seb,
sp.l: To pleae him more, let him believe me dead:
That he may never dream I may return.
Alonzo, I am now no more thy King,
But till thy Friend, and by that holy Name,
Adjure thee, to perform my lat requet.
Make our Conditions with you Captive King,
Secure me but my Solitary Cell;
'Tis all I ask him for a Crown retor'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will do more:
But fear not Muley-Zeydan; his oft mettall
Melts down with eay warmth; runs in the mould,
And needs no farther forge.

div.stage: Exit Dorax.
Re-enter Almeyda, led by Morayma, and follow • d by her Attendants.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: See where he comes again
By Hea'vn when I behold thoe beauteous eyes,
Repentance laggs and Sin comes hurrying on.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: This is too cruell!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Speak't thou of Love, of Fortune, or of Death,
Or double Death, for we mut part Almeyda.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I peak of all.
For all things that belong to us are cruell.
But what's mot cruell, we mut love no more.
O'tis too much that I mut never ee you,
But not to love you is impoible:
No, I mut love you: Hea'vn may bare me that,
And charge that Sinfull Sympathy of Souls
Upon our Parents, when they lov'd too well

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good Hea'vn, thou peakt my thoughts, and I peak thine.
Nay then there's Incet in our very Souls,
For we were form'd too like.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Too like indeed,
And yet not for each other.
Sure when we part (for I reolv'd it too
Tho' you propos'd it firt,) however ditant,
We hall be ever thinking of each other
And, the ame moment, for each other pray

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: But if a wih hou'd come a thwart our prayers!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: It wou'd do well to curb it: if we cou'd

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We cannot look upon each others face,
But, when we read our love, we read our guilt,
And yet methinks I cannot chue but love;

sp.speaker: Alm,
sp.l: I wou'd have ask'd you, if I durt for hame,
If till you lov'd? you gave it Air before me
Ah why were we not born both of a Sex:
For then we might have lov'd, without Crime
Why was not I your Brother? though that wih
Involv'd our Parents guilt, we had not parted;
We had been Friends, and Friendhip is not Incet.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Alas, I know not by what name to call thee!
Siter and Wife are the two dearet Names;
And I wou'd call thee both; and both are Sin.
Unhappy we! that till we mut confound
The dearet Names, into a common Cure.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: To love, and be belov'd, and yet be wretched!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: To have but one poor night of all our lives;
It was indeed a glorious; guilty night:
So happy, that, forgive me Hea'vn, I wih
With all its guilt, it were to come again.
Why did we know o oon, or why at all,
That Sin cou'd be conceal'd in uch a blie?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Men have a larger priviledge of words,
Ele I hou'd peak: but we mut part, Sebatian,
That's all the name that I have left to call thee.
I mut not call thee by the name I wou'd;
But when I ay Sebatian, dear Sebatian,
I kis the name I peak.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We mut make hat, or we hall never part.
I wou'd ay omething that's as dear as this;
Nay, wou'd do more than ay: one moment longer,
And I hou'd break through Laws Divine, and Humane;
And think 'em Cobwebs, pred for little man,
Which all the bulky herd of nature breaks.
The vigorous young world, was ignorant
Of thee retrictions, 'tis decrepit now;
Not more devout, but more decay'd, and cold.
All this is impious; therefore we mut part:
For, gazing thus, I kindle at thy ight,
And, once burnt down to tinder, light again
Much ooner then before.

div.stage: Reenter Dorax.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Here comes the ad denouncer of my fate,
To toul the mournfull knell of Seperation:
While I, as on my Death-bed, hear the ound,
That warns me hence for ever.
Sebatian to Dorax. Now be brief,
And I will try to liten.
And hare the minute that remains, betwixt
The care I owe my Subjects and my Love.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: Your fate has gratify'd you all he can;
Gives eay miery, and makes Exile pleaing.
I truted Muley Zeydan, as a friend,
But wore him firt to Secrey: he wept
Your fortune, and with tears, not queez'd by Art,
But hed from nature, like a kindly hower:
In hort, he proffer'd more than I demanded;
A afe retreat, a gentle Solitude,
Unvex'd with noie, and unditurb'd with fears:
I choe you one.—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: O do not tell me where:
For if I knew the place of his abode,
I hou'd be tempted to purue his teps,
And then we both were lot.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: E'vn pat redemption.
For, if I knew thou wert on that deign,
(As I mut know, becaue our Souls are one,)
I hou'd not wander but by ure Intinct,
Shou'd meet thee jut half-way, in pilgrimage
And cloe for ever: for I know my love
More trong than thine, and I more frail than thou.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Tell me not that: for I mut boat my Crime,
And cannot bear that thou houd't better love.

sp.speaker: Dorax.
sp.l: I may inform you both: for you mut go,
Where Seas, and winds, and Dearts will divide you.
Under the ledge of Atlas, lyes a Cave,
Cut in the living Rock, by Natures hands:
The Venerable Seat of holy Hermites.
Who there, ecure in eparated Cells,
Sacred ev'n to the Moors, enjoy Devotion:
And from the purling Streams and avage fruits,
Have wholeome bev'rage, and unbloudy feats.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: 'Tis pennance too Voluptuous, for my Crime.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your Subjects, concious of your life are few:
But all deirous to partake your Exile:
And to do office to your Sacred Peron.
The ret who think you dead, hall be dimis'd,
Under afe Convoy till they reach your Fleet.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: But how am wretched I to be dipos'd?
A vain Enquiry, ince I leave my Lord:
For all the world beide is Banihment!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I have a Siter, Abbee in Tercera's,
Who lot her Lover on her Bridall day.—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: There, fate provided me a fellow-Turtle;
To mingle ighs with ighs, and tears with tears.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lat, for my elf, if I have well fullfill'd
My ad Commiion, let me beg the boon,
