To hare the orrows of your lat reces:
And mourn the Common loes of our loves.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: And what becomes of me? mut I be let,
(As Age and time had worn me out of ue?)
Thee Sinews are not yet o much untrung,
To fail me when my Mater hou'd be erv'd:
And when they are, then will I teal to death:
Silent, and unoberv'd, to ave his tears.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I've heard you both: Alvarez have thy wih.
But thine Alonzo, thine, is too unjut.
I charge thee with my lat Commands, return,
And bles thy Violante with thy vows.
Antonio, be thou happy too, in thine.
Lat, let me wear you all to Secrey;
And to conceal my hame conceal my life.

sp.speaker: Dor. Ant, Mor.
sp.p: We wear to keep it ecret.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Now I wou'd peak the lat farewell, I cannot.
It wou'd be till farewell, a thouand times:
And, multiply'd in Eccho's, till farewell.
I will not peak; but think a thouand thouand;
And be thou ilent too, my lat Sebatian;
So let us part in the dumb pomp of grief.
My heart's too great; or I wou'd dye this moment:
But Death I thank him, in an hour, has made
A mighty journey, and I hat to meet him.

div.stage: (She taggers and her Women hold her up)

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Help to upport this feeble, drooping flower:
'This tender Sweet, o haken by the torm.
For thee fond arms mut, thus be tretch'd in vain,
And never, never mut embrace her more.
Tis pat:—my Souls goes in that word;—farewell.

div.stage: Alvarez goes with Sebatian to one end of the Stage. Women with Almeyda to the other.
Dorax, coming up to Antonio and Morayma, who tand on the Middle of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.l: Hat to attend Almeyda: for your ake
Your Father is forgiven: but to Antonio
He forfeits half his Wealth: be happy both:
And let Sebatian and Almeyda's Fate,
This dreadfull Sentence to the World relate,
That unrepented Crimes of Parents dead,
Are jutly punih'd on their Childrens head.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.byline: Se • t to the Authour by an unknown hand, and propos'd to be poken By Mrs. Monford dret like an Officer.

lg.l: BRight Beauties who in awfull Circle it,
And you grave Synod of the dreadfull Pit,
A • d you the pper-tire of pop-gun wit.
P • ay eae me of my wonder if you may
I • all this Crowd barely to ee the play,
Or is't the Poets Execution day?
His breath is in your hands I will preume
But I advie you to deferr his doom:
Till you have got a better in his room.
And don't maliciouly combine together,
As if in spight and spleen you were come hither,
For he has kept the Pen tho' lot the feather.
And on my Honour Ladies I avow,
This Play was writ in Charity to you,
For uch a dearth of Wit whoever know?
Sure 'tis a Judgment on this Sinfull Nation
For the abue of o great Dipenation,
And therefore I reolv'd to change Vocation.
For want of Petty-coat I've put on buff
To try what may be got by lying rough:
How think you Sirs, is it not well enough?
Of Bully Critichs I a Troup wou'd lead;
But one reply'd, thank you there's no uch need,
• at Groom-Porters Sir can afer bleed.
Another who the name of danger loaths,
•• w'd he would go, and wore me Forty Oaths,
Bu • that his Hores were in body-cloaths.
A thi • d cry'd, Dammy bloud, I'd • be content
To puh my Fortune, of the Parliament
Would but recall Claret from Banihment.
A Fourth (and I have done) made this excue
I'de draw my Sword in Ireland Sir to chue:
Had not their Women gouty leggs and wore no hoes?
Well, I may march thought I and fight and trudge,
But of thee blades the Devill a man will budge,
They there would fight e'n jut as here they judge.
Here they will pay for leave to find a faule,
But when their Honour calls they can't be bought,
Honour in danger, bloud and wounds is ought.
Lot Virtue whether fled, or where's thy dwelling,
Who can reveal, at leat 'tis pat my telling,
nles thou art Embarkt for Iniskelling.
On Carrion tits thoe Sparks denounce their rage
In boot of wisp and Leinter freee ingage,
What would you do in uch an Equipage?
The Siege of Derry does you Gallants threaten:
Not out of Errant hame of being beaten,
As fear of wanting meat or being eaten.
Were Wit like honour to be won by fighting
How few jut Judges would there be of writing,
Then you would leave this Villanous back-biting
Your Talents lye how to expres your spight,
But where is he knows how to praie aright,
You praie like Cowards but like Criticks fight.
Ladies be wie, and wean thee yearling Calves
Who in your Service too are meer faux-braves,
They Judge and write and fight, and—Love by halves.

div.head: EPILOGUE. TO Don Sebatian, King of Portugall.
div.stage: Spoken betwixt Antonio and Morayma.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I Quak'd at heart for fear the Royal Fahion
Shou'd have educ'd s two to Separation:
To be drawn in, againt our own deire,
Poor I to be a Nun, poor You a Fryar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I trembled when the Old Mans hand was in,
He would have prov'd we were too near of kin:
Dicovering old Intrigues of Love, like t'other,
Betwixt my Father and thy infull Mother;
To make s Siter Turk and Chritian Brother.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Excue me there; that League hou'd have been rather
Betwixt your Mother and my Mufti-Father;
'Tis for my own and my Relations Credit
Your Friends hou'd bear the Batard, mine hou'd get it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Suppoe us two Almeyda and Sebatian
With Incet prov'd upon us:—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Without quetion
Their Concience was too queazy of digetion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou woud't have kept the Councell of thy Brother
And inn'd till we repented of each other.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Beat as you are on Natures Laws to trample;
'Twere fitter that we follow'd their Example
And ince all Marriage in Repentance ends,
'Tis good for us to part while we are Friends,
To ave a Maids remores and Confuions
E'en leave me now before We try Concluions.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To copy their Example firt make certain
Of one good hour like theirs before our parting;
Make a debauch o're Night of Love and Madnes;
And marry when we wake in ober adnes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I'le follow no new Sects of your inventing,
One Night might cot me nine long months repenting:
Firt wed, and if you find that life a fetter,
Dye when you pleae, the ooner Sir the better:
My wealth wou'd get me love e're I cou'd ask it:
Oh there's a trange Temptation in the Casket:
All thee Young Sharpers wou'd my grace importune,
And make me thundring Votes of lives and fortune.
